After the game has finished, you earn additional money from the syndicate you secretly work for. Don’t let other players deduce who you’re working for or they will try to block you. The game ends shortly after the Loop has been completed.
Quick gameplay summary: On your turn, you will place two line cards and one route card. You can also spend your money to make bribes to buy cards or remove previously played cards. Keep in mind that the winner is the player with the most money in the end, so spend wisely! Each turn, you will earn money for each line that connects to the route card you played, and at the end of the game, you will earn money for each time your line appears and each time it connects to a station. The player with the most money at the end of the game wins.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Pattern Building, Tile Placement

name: Advanced Realm Warfare
description:
The Advanced Real Warfare expansion adds up to four players to the basic game. Four board extensions are added around the circumference of the basic board. As with the basic teams, the advanced teams all have unique abilities, strengths, and weaknesses. Advanced teams feature more offensive capabilities and less defensive capabilities than the base teams. Each advanced team starts with a facing that opposes two of the base game teams.

—user summary
categories: Abstract Strategy, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Wargame
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Player Elimination, Variable Player Powers

name: Chivalry at Bay: Tactical Battles of the Hundred Years War
description:
"As God may help, it appears to me that all the flower and honor of chivalry is there, most wisely and expertly drawn up." -- John Chandos, before the Battle of Auray (29 September 1364)

The Hundred Years War (1337 to 1453) was a dynastic struggle between the English house of Plantagenet and the French house of Valois for control of the French throne. Armies from across Europe would ally with these families, spreading combat as far from Gascony as Scotland and Portugal. Chivalry rose and fell on the backs of personalities like the Black Prince, Charles the Bad, and Pedro the Cruel, fought over battlefields at Creçy, Poitiers, and Agincourt. By the end of this period, the military code of chivalry would be in ashes and from those would be born the nations of England and France.

Chivalry At Bay is a low to medium complexity game depicting many of the individual battles that made up the Hundred Years War. Players control armies involved in each conflict that attempt to drive their opponent from the field of battle. Each battle can be completed in roughly two hours, allowing several battles to be played in a single sitting. The game takes several novel approaches toward simulating these eighteen individual battles:

LA CAPELLE (HYPOTHETICAL) - 23 October 1339
SAINT-OMER - 26 July 1340
MORLAIX - 30 September 1342
AUBEROCHE - 21 October 1345
BLANCHETAQUE - 24 August 1346
CREÇY - 26 August 1346
NEVILLE’S CROSS - 17 October 1346
CASSEL - 8 June 1347
BÉTHUNE - 13 June 1347
POITIERS - 19 September 1356
COCHEREL - 16 May 1364
AURAY - 29 September 1364
NAJERA - 3 April 1367
PONTVALLAIN - 4 December 1370
ROOSEBEKE - 27 November 1382
ALJUBARROTA - 14 August 1385
HUMBLETON HILL - 14 September 1402
AGINCOURT - 25 October 1415

Rather than the typical hex-based movement system, Chivalry At Bay uses a map that is broken up into three individual columns (or "battles" to use the historical term), each of which is made up of five "ranks" ranging from a friendly rear area, to and advance area, central area, through the enemy advance and rear areas. Units move backwards and forwards through these areas to more accurately simulate the type of movement that took place historically as waves of knights and men-at-arms advanced and were thrown back by enemy defenders (such as the feared English bowmen). Special terrain tiles may be placed in specific areas to more accurately simulate the ground over which the armies fought.

Combat is a simple process involving a "buckets-of-dice" system where "hits" on enemy units are based upon a unit's ability rating. Units range from lowly levies to the cream of chivalry, the French knight. Also represented are long bowmen, crossbowmen, men-at-arms, bill and pikemen, and light cavalry. Units that take hits may withdraw towards their friendly areas or hold their position and be ground down by the enemy onslaught. Units that have sustained enough damage may rout from the field!


The core of the game system is a deck of action cards. Each card provides a random number of command points that army leaders use to activate units on the battlefield to advance into engagement or withdraw before they're destroyed. The number of cards a player has available is based upon the quality of the army leadership. Several of these cards also allow the opportunity for players to "purchase" temporary army enhancements such as increased unit ratings or combat bonuses or even events that can shift the momentum of a battle.

In addition to the eighteen historical battles depicted, Chivalry At Bay provides players the ability to quickly and easily create their own custom armies to experiment with tactics and fight out battles on their own terms.

From La Capelle to Agincourt, relive the blood and glory of the Hundred Years War with Chivalry At Bay!

SUN OF YORK OWNERS! Use the fully mounted map board and game pieces of Chivalry at Bay to bring your Sun of York game alive! Now you can finally have that compact table top experience for the Wars of the Roses you’ve been asking for. We’ve listened, and you’ll love the new gaming experience.


Components:
Mounted Playing Surface/Mapboard
Counter Sheets (x4.5)
Terrain Tiles Sheets (x3)
55-Card Decks (x2)
Six-Sided Dice (x6)
Player Aid Cards (x2)

Time Scale: 5-10 minutes per turn
Map Scale: Abstract
Unit Scale: Leaders and 50-500 troops
Number of Players: 2
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Simulation

name: Persian Wars
description:
Persian Wars is a card-driven wargame depicting the Greco-Persian conflict from 494 to 466 B.C. Players control either the Persian empire and its generals, Xerxes, Artabazus, Artayntes, Artemisia and Mardonius or the Greek city-states and their generals, the Athenians Xanthippus, Miltiades and Themistocles and Spartans, Leonidas and Pausanias. The game is divided in two periods of 7 rounds each. During the first period, from 494 to 480 BC, the Persians are on the offensive, unleashing their invasion in Asia Minor, Thrace and the rest of the Greek peninsula, with their goal to conquer citites from their secret Objective card, while the Greeks try to prevent them from doing so. Once the first period is over, the Persian side announces the number of cities conquered from its objective. Moving to the second period, from 480 o 466 BC, the Greeks mount a counterattack, in an attempt to liberate as many cities as they can from their secret Objective card. In a similar fashion, the Persians try to prevent the Greeks from achieving their goal. With the second period over, the Greek side announces the number of cities liberated from its objective. The number of cities conquered/liberated are compared and the side with the most cities conquered/liberated wins the game.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Cooperative Game, Point to Point Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Drop Everything
description:
An abstract game of Alex Randolph. It's an evolution of Foxy (1977) adapted also for 4 players.
The board is a grid with 44 holes where the players try dropping the discs from their tube-like.
In 2 players game, each player has 2 tube-like with 11 discs each.
First player to "drop everything" (both his tubes empty) wins
the game.

—user summary

name: This One Time, I...: The Game of Ludicrous Life Choices – Girl's Night Edition
description:
Have you ever hooked up with someone within an hour of meeting them, or blacked out before 9 p.m. because you were too drunk?
Unlike most of the party games you have played, THIS ONE TIME, I... provides an explicit, hilarious opportunity for friends to relive their funny, dirty and downright crazy life experiences. We have probed deep into the dirty pasts of people to compile hundreds of ludicrous life choices that we can all relate to.
The game is played with Confession Cards, which are examples of ludicrous life choices, and Rule Cards which tell you how to play each round - that make it easy and fun to learn who’s the craziest, dirtiest, wildest friend of the group!

Every round, a player selects a Red Rule Card from the top of the pile, reads the instructions aloud and must then do as the Rule Card says.
If you are guilty of an act detailed by a Blue Confession Card given to you, you must add it to your losing pile (face up) in front of you until the end of the game, so that everyone can enjoy reliving your bad decisions. If you are not guilty of a Confession Card, you must scrap it.
The first player to have 10 Confession Cards in their losing pile loses the game. There are no winners in this game, only losers.

—description from the publisher

name: Alle Kinder, groß und klein, sparen beim Schulsparverein
description: This is a simple roll-and-move game to teach children about saving money at the school savings bank. On some spaces events benefit or hinder the players. The first player to reach space 52 wins the game.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Race, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Ancient Scrolls of Danga'in
description:
The Ancient Scrolls of Danga'in is a Lost Worlds Adventure Set designed to be used with the same plastic "castle" terrain set that originally came with Adventure Set I: In the Ruins of the Ancients.

The rules specify that the adventure set is intended to be used with 3-4 human or humanoid Lost Worlds characters and 12 Lost Worlds treasure cards. However, no character books or metal miniatures are included in the set, and there are only two sample fantasy cards (which the treasure cards would come from). Therefore the players would have to purchase or provide additional items to make use of this expansion set.

Contents of The Ancient Scrolls of Danga'in include a 12-page booklet containing the background story, player's notes about The Tome of Purple Magic, and four scenarios; an eight page booklet titled General Rules for Miniatures Play in Lost Worlds Scenarios; Special Charts & Tables for Lost Worlds Miniatures Play; the plastic castle terrain set; a printed diagram of the terrain with scenario-specific locations marked; two of the new Lost Worlds fantasy cards; eight plastic chips; and a six-sided die.

—User summary
categories: Adventure, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval, Miniatures

name: Lords of the Fjords
description:
You are an ambitious jarl of a small tribe of Vikings. Only featly leading your people and steering your tribe to wealth and prosperity you will be able to become a respected leader of your people! Improving your settlement, pillaging the villages and building the temples in the name of Odin, gain glory and become the legend, perpetuated in a Viking saga.

In Lords of the Fjords, you start your game in a poor village with just one ship at the pier and a couple of sellswords. Each turn, the players take from the сloth bag the specified number of meeples that exist in three different colors. Each of three colors means a certain type of specialists and for your turn you have to choose only one one color to perform one type of action: Builders (yellow) allow you to build new ships and temples; Counsellors (blue) are great at diplomatic and trade affairs, which can attract new skilled people to your village, which is necessary for its growth; while Warriors (red), for sure, are needed to attack other villages (because no Viking can live his life without tough fights and glorious victories).

Starting the game with identical resources, all players must find their own strategy towards the glory. Building new ships and temples brings you more gold and victory points respectively. Improving your facilities allows you to get more actions on your future turns, hire new sellswords that will fight for you to the last breath, or even send an intruder that will get in the way of your opponents and steal their gold for you.

Conquering unexplored lands you can achieve everything at once: get some useful bonuses, do some extra actions of other types on the same turn and gain the victory points. But you should be careful attacking the villages - most of tribes will call for help of their neighbours when you try to pillage their lands and some of them can also be protected by high palisade.

Lords of the Fjords is a simple but involving game of strategy that combines different game mechanisms.

—description from the publisher

name: analysis!!!
description:
Full title: "analysis!!!
THE ADULT BOARD GAME FOR NORMAL (NOT TOO NEUROTIC) PEOPLE!"

The objective is to be the first to reach "Normal!" by reducing your hand to two or less neurotic symptom cards. Game includes 72 word association cards and 28 neurotic symptom cards. The game is played as neurotic conflict dictates. If a dispute arises about your problem, ARGUE! Can't convince others? Use the Decision Maker, which flips a male/female coin.

name: Bushido: Tsubaki
description:
The only thing to match the beguiling beauty of the Roses of Silvermoon Syndicate is their athletic physique. Experts in the arts of manipulation and misdirection, they pass through their unsuspecting enemies waiting for the moment to strike. Once the veil of safety drops Tsubaki’s opponents have to contend with their foe dancing rhythmically in and out of combat, whilst they swing wildly at thin air. This is not Tsubaki’s only trick for she, like many Roses, carries an exotic mix of flower petals which, when blown into a victim’s eyes induce blindness.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Wasapu & Senpu
description:
Wasapu: It is unclear exactly where the Silvermoon source their knowledge of new technologies. Whether through a shrewd business deal or more nefarious means the Syndicate acquired the intricate, rapid, reloading mechanism showcased in their repeater crossbows. Wasapu wields this fearsome weapon with great skill and accuracy. Using the finest Minimoto steel, his bolts find the weak points in even the finest armours. On top of this Wasapu can identify the weak points of even the toughest beast.

Senpu: The only way to ascend the ranks of the Silvermoon is to show undying loyalty to one’s Oyabun, guile and cunning to advance the collective goals of your gumi and the syndicate as a whole, and finally savagely and without question removing any threats to the organisation. Senpu is a veteran of many missions and a dangerous opponent, with a target in his sights he advances upon the foe, his twin butterfly swords a blur of motion bouncing missiles aimed at him away until close enough for a flurry of blows to fell his adversary.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Sukuratchi & Animals
description:
Sukuratchi, a grizzled and season veteran of Jima’s famed fighting pits, an accolade that many in his trade cannot claim. His years training and taming animals means that Sukuratchi has a vast knowledge of skills and techniques that enable him to bring even the most fearsome of wild animals under his command or push a broken animal to amazing lengths of stamina. Always accompanied by Akuma or “Devil”, the animals named so for their constant snapping and pestering after food. Another animal Sukuratchi is an expert at handling is the Kirian Fighting bird, his current champion Okkete San is one of the most savage and aggressive birds in recent history of the fighting arenas and has won many Silvermoons for those who pass a wager on him.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Fitiaumua
description:
The Buto are a fearsome and brutal people when stirred to actions. Fituamua is no different and serves as the silent enforcer for the Syndicate. A once renowned Jumo fighter he has since worked his way into the service of the Iron Fist gumis. It makes no matter to him if the debt is a single half bronze moon to a thousand Gold ones. If his Oyabun gives him a name he will collect and those who hear the slow knock of his heavy tonfa on their door had better clear the debt or Fitiuamua will gladly give them a lesson in repayment.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Kyoaku-Han
description:
The lowest ranks of the Silvermoon are made up of the Kyoaku-Han. Violent, ambitious and driven young men and women who seek the power and wealth the Silvermoon can offer them. It is unclear the exact rites and rituals required when one joins one of the Silvermoon gumis due to the great secrecy surrounding them and the fact that once initiated there is only one way the leave. Death. There is certainly no lack of those willing to swear total loyalty and obedience to the organisation, bringing with them a cunning and tenacious hunger to the battle, using the tricks and tactics learned on the streets rather than in a traditional dojo or samurai school, to gain victory for themselves and the Silvermoon.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Old Zo
description:
Exactly how Old Zo is remains unknown as it seems he has been in service to the Gumis of the Silvermoon for decades. If the years have taken their toll on his body they have certainly not affected his cunning mind and his famed intellect. Nothing gets past the owl like eyes surveying every situation from behind his rimmed glasses, weighing up the myriad options available. There is nothing that seems to faze this esteemed Saiko-Komon as he quietly manages the ebb and flow of battle, emitting an aura of influence that seems to sap the spark and energy from enemies whilst reinvigorating friends to turn the tide in favour of the Silvermoon. Many Oyabun have felt all the more confident that the odds favour them with Zo by their side.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Saki
description:
The reach of the Jade Roses stretches far beyond the city of Jima. It is difficult to find an individual in a position of power, man or woman who hasn’t tasted or been tempted by the sweet smell and charms of a beautiful rose. No one knows exactly the training techniques that the Jade Rose implements and many suggest that their charisma and manipulative powers are supernatural and the result of some powerful enchantment. Of course no Rose would ever disclose this information such is their devotion to the Gumi. Saki is a master at the art of suggestion, without uttering a word she can draw the attention of any unlucky enough to be selected for her wiles, stumbling blindly after her in the heat of battle.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Oda & Tautolu
description:
The legendary Jumo sensei, and current Oyabun of the Iron Fist gumi, Oda is small only in stature, for everything else about this no nonsense boss is anything but. Oda likes nothing more than to drill and sculpt his famous Buto into pure weapons of mass and muscle. His physique might prevent him from demonstrating his extensive knowledge of the art of Jumo but he is a skilled and quick teacher, barking instructions and jabbing directions with his ornate fan, swiftly turning even the amateur into a competent wrestler and a warrior into a master. Tautolu is never far from his diminutive master, either stepping forward to clear his path through the streets of Jima and saddling his famous platform, allowing his sensei a better vantage point from which to command his men. Keenly aware of danger and quickly removing threats with a crushingly accurate and brutal blow from his tetsubo, Tautolu is the bite to Oda’s bark.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Hanami
description:
The head of the Jade Rose has always been the Hanami, Queen of Flowers, the identity of the Queen is never known, for the Roses never go by a real name from the moment they join the sisterhood of the Jade Rose. Despite there having been many Hanamis over the years one thing remains constant, she is always the most beautiful and attractive woman in the Jwar Isles, or even the whole of the Golden Empire. She is the embodiment of grace as she moves sensually, almost gliding, drawing all but the strongest of wills under her thrall, toying with them, a cat with mice, unescapably trapped by her bewitching allure. Those lucky or unlucky enough to receive a Kiss from the Rose are known to lose control of their actions entirely, impotent to her will.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Sukoshi Kani & Nomi
description:
The oyabun of the Silvermoon do not consider age a restriction to the entrance to their service. Many fill their numbers with youngsters eager to establish themselves within the Shatei ranks and prove themselves worthy of their oyabun’s favour. All within the Silvermoon play to their own strengths, and in doing so strengthen their gumi. Sukoshi Kani and Nomi are no different in this respect. Sukoshi, armed with her bag of makibishi, ready to scatter them wide at a moment’s notice to cover a retreat or block a path. Nomi serves as the keen eyes and ears, ready to alert his brethren to approaching or unseen dangers. Their small statures another hindrance turned help, enabling them to sneak into an enemy’s flanks and wreak havoc.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Needles
description:
Objective: rescue the Royal Baby safe and sound.

Setup:
Place the Royal Baby (pink card) at the centre of the table. Hand out the 4 blue cards to the youngest
player and the 4 red cards to the eldest.

Game progress:
Step away from the table (around 1 meter or 3 feet). The blue player starts the game and throws one of his cards towards the Royal Baby. Then it is the red player’s turn. In turns, the game continues until all the card are thrown. Beware! Hedgehogs must not prick each other. If one Hedgehog card touches the Royal Baby, its owner (the thrower) loses the game. If one Hedgehog card touches another hedgehog card, its owner (the thrower) loses the game.

End of the game:
When all the hedgehog cards are thrown and if no card touches, the player whose card is closest to the Royal Baby wins the game.

—description from the designer

name: Bushido: Dafukaia & Kami of Burning Anger
description:
Not all those children raised in the monasteries and taught the teachings of Subarashi Baransu are able to complete their training, return to their homes and continue the cycle that has been in place since the beginning of memory. Dafukaia was a promising student, however the gnawing rage that burns inside him stoked by an unknown trauma could not be dowsed by the secrets of the temple. Despite many attempts to help and guide the boy, the masters could not risk letting him continue his training such was the ferocity of his temper. So when the teenager was cast out he had no choice but to travel to the city to try and survive and survive he did. A natural fighter who has since used his teaching in the martial arts to earn his living. In the Silvermoon he has found his family and acceptance that had eluded him for so long. The Oyabun encouraging his fiery talent, unleashing Dafukaia like a fireball on those who have slighted them.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Honoko & Hakushi
description:
If Sukuratchi’s training is based on the lash, then Honoka’s is led by reward. This beautiful shatei would have been a Rose but for her love of animals. She is instantly able to form a bond with even the most wild and ferocious of beasts, turning them to her will. Her pack would lay down their lives in an instant for their pack leader, tearing to shreds any whom Honoka command. Her favourite is without question the silent stalker Hakashi, never far from her side but seldom seen, this majestic predator, a prime specimen of the Jwarian Leopard.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Rakki
description:
Of the Five Fortunes the Rakki is the embodiment of Luck. They favour those that take fate into their own hands, gifting or cursing those as they see fit. The jolly laughing Rakki are unsurprisingly found in proximity to the luck houses of Jima, chuckling away as fortunes are won or lost on the roll of a dice. The Silvermoon can only benefit now that these unusual Kami have chosen to favour them with their talents.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Malosi
description:
In the Jumo ring there can only be one winner, Malosi is that winner. The champion of the Iron Fist gumi, Oda’s best student. A Buto as strong and fearsome as any other in memory, to look into his blank stare is enough to break the spirit of even the stoutest. Few words are muttered from this hulking monster, in combat he sounds more animal than human, growling and grunting whilst handing out savaging beatings with fist or skull crushing mace, smashing the armoured like beetles beneath an angry bull’s hoof.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Misao, the Grey Rose
description:
Little is known of what becomes of the Roses of Jima when their beauty fades and bodies lose the firmness of youth. Some think they fade away, relinquishing their veils and their old identity and choosing a new one. Misao, the grey rose is a powerful member of the Jade Rose gumi, for the old rose’s eyes see far more than those around her. It is told in hushed rumour that she can see into the future, knowing the actions of men before they have even realised themselves. To anger or harm her is as foolish and unlucky as slurring the five themselves.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Pit Dogs
description:
The mongrel pit dogs of Jima’s fighting pits are bred for their ferocity and savage nature from pups, with only the most aggressive and vicious surviving. Harshly trained and conditioned into living weapons, used to create spectacle and serve as guard dogs for the Oyabun and high ranking members of the Gumis. The Iron Fist’s trainer able to guide these hounds with the crack of a whip to wreak havoc amongst their terrified victims.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Silvermoon Syndicate Silvermoon Trade Syndicate Special Card Pack 1
description:
Special cards are an interesting and flexible way to create very a focussed, individual and distinct Warband for your favourite faction. There are three types of Special Cards and each work slightly differently but each in their own way enables will enable you to customise your Warbands to fit the play style or theme you want. These packs contain an assortment of Enhancement, Event and Terrain Special cards that range from martial techniques to ancient shrines, acts of amazing heroism to soul draining terror. Each pack contains thematically fitting cards to adhere to the factions strengths, weaknesses and in game feel.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Silvermoon Trade Syndicate Special Card Pack 2
description:
Special cards are an interesting and flexible way to create a very focussed, individual and distinct Warband for your favourite faction. There are four types of Special Cards and each work slightly differently but each in their own way will enable you to customise your Warbands to fit the play style or theme you want. These packs contain an assortment of Enhancement, Event, Terrain and Theme Special cards that range from martial techniques to ancient shrines, acts of amazing heroism to soul draining terror. Each pack contains thematically fitting cards to adhere to the faction’s strengths, weaknesses and in game feel.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Orphan & Envy
description:
There are none left alive that could name the Orphan. Whether it was a trait in the boy before, he was corrupted by Yurei, matters little, his envy leads to destruction wherever he roams. Jealousy of a blind beggar led him to take his own eyes, and now he unleashes Envy to take whatever he feels should be rightfully his. Any skill or attribute an opponent has, the Orphan wants and Envy will take and use on his behalf.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Corruption: Sanctus Malum
description:
In Short: Token-based social deduction game.

In Full: Sanctus Malum pits the power of a few against the might of many in this twist on a social deduction game. Acting as a Guardian, you aid angels in ascending to their rightful place. Or are you an Imp in disguise, corrupting the virtuous?

Players are attempting to free Recruit Tokens (double-sided tokens in the center of the playing field), with one side representing Angel Recruits, and the other side representing Demon Recruits. Freed recruits are removed from the game and cannot be flipped to the other side. The Guardian's team goal is to have a majority of freed Angel Recruits; the Imp's team goal is to have a majority of freed Demon Recruits.
One player is assigned the role of Justice, and receives the Justice token and the Action Card deck (to shuffle). The Justice role moves to the player on this first Justice's left at the beginning of every round. The Justice will make important decisions that affect the outcome of every round, and ultimately the outcome of the game.

Each player, including the Justice, is dealt an Alignment Card - which makes them either a Guardian or an Imp - and a Power Card (they may look at their cards, but must keep them secret). Power Cards give the player either a single-use power, a information trade power, the ability to "mark" a player, or the ability to give your team an extra point at the end of the game. These cards help add an extra level of complexity and strategy to the game.

During the start of gameplay, Action Cards are introduced to the group. The Justice deals two Action Cards to every player, who may look at them, talk about them, but must keep them hidden from other players. Players may play both Action Cards or play one and discard the other.

Action Cards affect the Recruit Tokens:


Rise takes a single Angel Recruit out of the pool and frees it
Redeem changes a Demon Recruit into an Angel Recruit
Truce does nothing
Corrupt changes two Angel Recruits into Demon Recruits
Fall takes frees two Demon Recruits.


Justice's Decision: After all players have made their decisions on which Action Cards to play or discard, the Justice may swap players' Action Cards, up to the number of Imps in the game (so, if there are 3 Imps in the game, the Justice may swap up to three players' Action Cards). If a player plays both of their cards, the Justice can now discard both; if a player plays one and discards the other, the Justice can swap those cards around so the discarded one is now played.

The only way for a player to voluntarily discard both of their cards is for them to appeal to the Justice, hoping that the Justice will believe them when they claim that the cards will only do harm to their team.

Reveal: After the Justice has made their decisions, all played cards are collected and given face-down to the Justice, who shuffles them together. All discarded cards, and the remaining Action Card deck, are given to the player on the Justice's left (also face-down).

The Justice reveals the played cards one at a time, enacting the rules on each, continuing until all cards have been followed. At any time, if one team reaches their win condition, the game is over, and players may reveal their alignments.

Justice's Investigation: The final major piece to the game is the Justice's Investigation - on the round that the 10th Recruit is freed (regardless of Alignment, instead a total count of freed Recruits), the Justice chooses a player and secretly looks at that player's Alignment Card - beware, however, that there are Power Cards that may affect the Justice's decision and the outcome! The Justice may be truthful or lie about that player's alignment.

At the end of a round, the Justice role moves to the player to the left, and it all starts over again.

Whichever faction gets the most Recruit Tokens on their side wins the game! Supports up to 15 players.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Fantasy, Mythology, Party Game
mechanics: Role Playing, Variable Player Powers, Voting

name: Konflikt '47: Japanese Starter Set
description:
June 1947. The Imperial Japanese Army is consolidating its position after almost 16 years of war, first with China, then in a brief struggle with the Soviet Union and later against the US and British Commonwealth. With major gains on the Asian mainland and still holding territory across the Pacific, the Japanese Army is under pressure but holding firm.

New Rift-tech weaponry is appearing in greater numbers and the Allies political uncertainty plays to Japan’s advantage. The fortitude and fanaticism of the Japanese soldier remains a potent force, but it’s the Rift-tech Scorpion light walker that terrifies its enemies, a stealthy machine with a powerful weapon load. As Walker technology advances, the humble tank may become obsolete, but in the meantime, the Rift-tech weaponry upgrades keep the proven Type 97-Kai Shinhoto Chi-Ha in the front line, its compression cannon capable of defeating infantry and Allied tanks alike.

This Konflikt '47 starter set provides the men and machines needed to finally push the Allies out of Asia and ensure the domination for the Emperor.

—desription from the publisher
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: The Cheap Chapel
description:
The Cheap Chapel is a fully cooperative role-playing board game for one to six players.

Build your unique character and make strategic decisions with your group to overcome a variety of monsters from dozens of scenarios.
Optimize your character’s attributes as you level up and work together with your group to fight battles of increasing difficulty.

See your character grow after each fight by learning new skills and increasing attributes. Choose to specialize and grow more powerful in certain attributes, or expand your versatility with a greater variety of skills.

Designed by a role-player for role-players,this board game offers steadily-building character development and a variety of attributes including: strength, dexterity, constitution, intelligence, wisdom and charisma.

Likewise, the available classes --Paladin, Mage, Priest, Thief and Ranger-- include 20 skills as well as 6 companions who can be hired for each of the quests.

The fighting system is direct, so that skills can be used to their full potential.
The standard attack is carried out with an attack roll and compared to the monster's defense.
In contrast, many skills have nothing to do with throwing dice, but require the party to come up with a plan.

Each story contains a storybook with over 25 scenarios, 20 monsters and battle slides for some scenarios. The variety of these monsters guarantees for a constant difficulty level.
We recommend playing 5 scenarios, which will take about 1 hour per player, and then taking a break until your next game night.

Every game in The Cheap Chapel is different. Apart from different stories, decisions in one game can influence the course of the next game, not including the incredible number of possibilities to customize your character.

Choose your character, roll starting attributes, put on your gear and go on an adventure.

The world of The Cheap Chapel awaits you.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Role Playing, Storytelling

name: Bushido: Taliriktug
description:
Taliriktug is as strong and rugged as the mountains he calls home. With his ancestral axe, crafted to last generations, none can resist his wide and arcing blows, felling opponents unable to the block his furious onslaught.

Blister contains one model, one 30mm base and one full colour profile card.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Nuniq
description:
An amazing hunter and tracker, Nuniq knows the mountains she calls home better than any other. Enemies to the tribes must tread carefully if they don’t want to lose men to the hidden traps and snares, obvious to the tribes people but undetectable to outsiders. Her eyes miss nothing, whether spotting prey, animal or human.
— description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Hill Tribe Warrior
description:
The many tribes of the mountain have been chased and persecuted for as long as the stories tell. Hounded into the mountains and left to scratch a meagre existence from the barren earth. This has made them a strong, resilient and resourceful people. Little is known about how or why the Tengu reached out to the tribes but the alliance has proved valuable to both sides. All the people of hill tribes are able warriors as they must be to survive in the harsh cold, when the need arises these people of snow and ice are fearsome combatants.
— description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Qimmiq
description:
The quiet and peaceful guardians of the mountains, Qimmiq is a healer, teacher and father to his people. Like all holy men amongst the hill tribes he lives on the outskirts of his village where he can be closest to the wild and listen to the spirits. He is knows the wild as if it were an extention of his own body, as such he knows the ancient uses for all the flora found in the hills, and is able to call on the spirits on the wild to aid him in times of conflict. Calling the roots of trees to bind invaders, or asking favours of the wind to buffet or blow as need requires.
— description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Kanut
description:
Kanut, the leader of the hilltribes, is the father to all his people, a true hero, patient teacher and a stoic guardian. He is a great warrior, his acts and courage on the bloody field of battle dispelling doubt and instilling a fever in his warriors. Kanut is a resolute and effective, if direct, fighter. Skilled with the great axe delivering brutal blows to his enemies, those that run receive the sharp and stinging bite of one of his throwing axes, their edges as keen as any samurai sword. A veteran of many battles, wounded many times but seeming unwilling to die at the hands of his enemies.
— description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Maniitok
description:
Like all of the warriors of the tribes, Maniitok is brave and honest. A keen farmer, pious and simple. The people of the hills are a simple uncompromising breed, as hard as the mountain and unyielding in the defence of their kin. A life in the hills is hard though and daily struggle against the land has carved Maniitok into the warrior that protects his people so fiercely, strong as a mountain ox, cutting down his enemies with wide arcing swings of his axe.
— description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Giant Eagle
description:
The Koroko tell stories to the young hatchlings about the circle of life and of how all is connected, sharing the eternal truth that nothing truly dies but is born again as something else. They say that the great giant eagles that patrol the Ro-Kan, these feathered sentinels ever watchful for the slightest threat, are the reincarnation of great Tengu warriors now watching over the mountain in a different form. Their talons sharp as the strongest steel, appearing from nowhere and disappearing just as fast. No enemy can tell from where these feathered angels will strike next.
— description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Convocation of Eagles
description:
The eagles are the eyes and ears of the Tengu, creating a potent early warning system should the enemy be foolish enough to climb into the snowy peaks of the Rokan. With beaks as sharp as steel and attacking with practised co-ordination, gouging and clawing down on the intruders, striking at weaknesses in the armour and exposed flesh.
— description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Tale e quale Show
description:
The board game based on the Italian TV show "Tale e quale Show".

Players roll the die and move their pawn on the board. According to the square they land, they have to do one the following challenges:

they sing a song: the other players try to guess the title and the singer.
they say a song and its singer: the other players try to guess the released year.
they draw a singer on a white board: the other players try to guess the singer.
they sing a song with the voice of another singer: the other players try to guess the title and the singer.


If someone guesses, he moves forward, if nobody guesses, the current player moves back.
The first player who arrives to the final square wins.

You can play also in team.

—user summary
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia
mechanics: Line Drawing, Roll / Spin and Move, Singing, Team-Based Game

name: Circul
description: The players start at the 4 corners of the game board. Movement is determined by a die. On some spaces events or traffic signs benefit or hinder the players. The first player to reach his starting point after traveling around the game board wins the game.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Lingo Twist
description: In the language party game Lingo Twist, you will struggle to make yourself understood, and whether you have your fingers in your mouth or your tongue stretched out far, you want to speak as clearly as possible. Good luck!

name: Don't Blow It
description:
The word building family game that’s sure to bring endless fun & laughter to game time. Build words to score points. The more words, the more points you get or so you think. It’s not just about out spelling or out wording your opponents but
developing a game plan. Don’t Blow It will frustrate you and it will challenge you, because play an OOPS UP! card at the
wrong time and just when you think you have it in the bag. OOPS you’ve blown it. Words & letters can be flipped, swiped,
swopped and even added to your hand right under your nose,which just adds to the fun. It’s the game for everyone including
Grandad because all that counts is your ability to make words and have awesome fun doing so. Hey, it will even help improve
your maths skills.

name: Trova il percorso
description:
The game is a simple way to introduce children to the world of route planning, helping them develop their logic and spatial intelligence skills, with 46 challenges.
For each challenge, you need to work out the right route for getting your playing piece to its destination.
Each scene has different coloured paths, interrupted by circular spaces.
Look at the objectives on the game card, then take the number of bars indicated on the card to complete your route.
Look at the different possible routes in the scene, then place the bars in the correct order on the white spaces on the game card.
Move your piece in the same way you have placed the bars on the game card to see if you have plotted your route correctly.

When you are more familiar with the game, you can challenge your friends to see who can complete the game card first.
Playing side-by-side, each player takes 3 coloured bars. Take the CITY or PLANET scene of your choice, together with the appropriate playing piece and game cards. Place the scene and the playing piece in the centre of the table and put the game cards in a pile. Pick a game card from the pack, then place it in front of you. The players must try to solve the game card at the same time. To plot your course, place the bars closest to you directly onto the board (instead of on the card). When a player thinks they have found the right solution they must say “STOP”. If you have placed the bars on the board correctly you keep the card. If not, the other player gets to keep the card. Continue the game by choosing another game card. The winner is the first person to get 3 cards.

name: Master Challenge 5: BBC Quizzes
description: Expansion cartridge and question book for the original Master Challenge. Another 1001 questions, centred around the BBC quiz shows, A Question of Sport, Mastermind and Ask the Family.
categories: Electronic, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Trivia

name: Casa Banana
description:
In the jungle, the animals are on the loose! The Monkey King invites his animal friends from around the world. Will the new tree house carry this number of guests after all? The more animals ascend to the tree house, the more wobbly it becomes. Strategy is therefore asked - How do you get most of the animals on the tree house without collapsing it or the animals falling down?
—description from the publisher

name: Lygari!
description:
Featuring all original artwork inspired by Art Nouveau, Lygari! is a fun bluffing game for 3-6 players, where each player is one of the Einherjar in Valhalla boasting about their conquests!

In Lygari!, there are 13 different monsters from Norse myth, and players take turns boasting about what creatures they have defeated in their previous life before coming to Valhalla. Cards are played face down, while players claim them to be one of the monsters in the game. It's up to other players to determine if each play is a bluff. Play continues until either one player has played all their cards, or the draw pile is exhausted.

During their turn, players have a choice of making a boast, calling the previous player a Lygari, or just drinking mead. When making a boast, a player plays any number of cards from their hand, face down, and claims them to be one of the 13 monsters in the game. If the next player calls their bluff, the cards are revealed. If they matched the previous player's claim, the calling player must take all cards played so far into their hand, otherwise, the lying player takes all cards played into their hand. A player may instead opt to "pass" by drinking mead and drawing a card from the stock. When the mead runs out (all cards are drawn), whoever has the fewest cards left in their hand is the winner!

Lygari! is the second in a series of games from Green Fairy Studios LLC in a shared setting of Mystique, where beings from ancient myth return to our modern day world. Lygari! highlights just some of the fantasical beings from Yggdrasil, the Nine Worlds of Norse myth!

—description from the publisher

name: どーぶつ・すとらぐる (Dobutsu Struggle)
description:
User summary
どーぶつ・すとらぐる (Dobutsu Struggle) is a Japanese dice game of 'animal struggle'.

Players each place one hunter coin on an animal card that has been drawn from the stack.

After all players have finished placing their hunter coins, calculate how many hunter coins there are in comparison to the number rolled from the dice to decide what animal card will go to which player.

After all animal cards have been claimed, the player with the most animal cards wins the game.

Publisher's summary
プレイヤーは、山札からめくられた動物カードに自分が持つ狩人コインを１枚ずつ置いていきます。
全員が狩人コインを置き終わったら、狩人コインの枚数＋サイコロの出目を比べ合い、その動物カードが誰のものになるかを決めていきます。
全ての動物カードのとりあいが終わった時に、動物カードの総合計点数の多い人の勝ちです。

name: 満足したいねずみたち (Manzoku shitai nezumitachi)
description:
User summary
満足したいねずみたち (Manzoku shitai nezumitachi) is a Japanese dice game when you try to 'satisfy the mice'.

The mice want to eat a lot of cheese to become happy. You need to make your mouse happy by visiting the garbage pile or finding cheese in the storehouse. But beware, if a cat comes along and your mouse must run away causing the mouse’s happiness to go down instantly.

Take care to train your mouse to escape.

Publisher's summary
ねずみたちはチーズをたくさん食べてもっとハッピーになりたいと思っています。あなたはゴミ捨て場を漁ったり新しいチーズ倉庫を見つけたりして、自分のねずみの満足度を上げていかなければなりません。
でも気をつけて。
猫がやってきた時に逃げそこなうと、それまでに得た満足がガクンと減ってしまいます。逃足のトレーニングも欠かさずに……。

name: アマゾンの度胸だめし (Amazon no dokyou dameshi)
description:
User summary
アマゾンの度胸だめし (Amazon no dokyou dameshi) is a Japanese card game of the 'Amazonian Test of Courage'.

The Amazon natives are playing a game where players traverse deep into the river to collect the fish. The player who collects the most fish wins.

However, the deeper into the river you go, the higher the risk of encountering an alligator. If a player does meet an alligator, the player drops all their fish and is disqualified.

The goal of the game is to mind out for the alligator while displaying your courage.

Publisher's summary
アマゾンの住民たちが、出来るだけ川の奥まで行って、たくさんの魚を持ち帰った者が勝つという遊びをしています。しかし、奥に行くほどワニに出会う可能性が高くなり、
ワニに出会ったら魚を全部落として失格になってしまいます。
ワニに会わないように気をつけつつ度胸を示すのがゲームの目的です。
mechanics: Push Your Luck, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Festival
description:
Each summer Queen Idriana travels to the the greatest festival in all the land. The Festival is the best opportunity to show your abilities to organize street performers into a festive force that can ignite the senses and imaginations of any audience throughout the realm. Can you capture the attention of the Queen and become the Busker Baron or Baroness?

As a Busker Lord or Lady you must choose from a collection of royal street performers and outperform the other Busker Lords and Ladies who are simultaneously selecting their own performers. The Queen wants to see who can best manage their troop. After drafting your performers, your goal is to keep the most performers in your hand for the final encore. Your best chance is to convince the Festival's watching crowd and the other royal street performers that your troop is the best. If you have the most performers in your hand at the end of the game, you win Queen Indriana’s royal contract and become the Busker Baron or the Busker Baroness for the next summer's Festival!

name: Bouncing Bots
description:
Bouncing Bots is the board game where players compete to get the best score by bouncing their bots on the highest valued numbers on the target boards. Score the most points to win!

—description from the publisher

name: Rochi
description: Rochi is a gambling game for 2-8 players, played with a Tarot-style deck with six suits of different sizes. It's a new deck design and a whole new way to think about how gambling games should work. There is no betting, very little bluffing, and six different pots!
publishers: King of the Castle Games Company

name: Kombiniermeister
description:
This is a tile placement game depicting a highly detailed map of Ostereich/Germany. Players need to correctly place the tiles in a puzzle like fashion. The first player to place all their map tiles is the winner.

—user summary

name: Transitions
description:
A strategic boardgame by TLM to introduce people and employees to their company concepts. You are the boss of a company. Your goal is to fill the companies grid with the indicated number of employees. Therefore, you can recruit them on the board, or make them evolve inside your company's grid. Throughout the game, the itransitions cards will reveal surprises due to economical and political evolutions the same way that such events occur in real life companies. Some are good events and you will be able to capitalise on the economic situation or interestting labor market events. Some are bad, for example, due to a recession or bad social management on your part. The game ends when a player fills his grid.

—user summary

name: Treasure & Paradise
description:
"Hsiao-Le, are you willing to seek treasure with me in the Paradise?"

Counting on the happy memories during childhood, Hsiao-Le promised to seek treasure in the Paradise. You also follow Hsiao-Le to this Paradise. It turns out that Grandma left a will, “As long as the treasure buried in the amusement park could be found, the finder could gain the inheritance of Paradise. Can you find out the treasures left here ahead of others?” before she passed away.

How to play:
Draw other player's hand card to collect the clue. Collect 4 clue to exchange the treasure. The player who own most treasure will win this game.

name: Croisiere 1950
description:
A colorful space exploration board game produced in post-war France. The object of the game is to travel through the solar system landing on the planets and moon and collecting valuable ore or precious stones. The winner is the player with the most valuable riches upon returning to earth.

The game requires players to choose a spaceship that looks more like a plane and traverse the solar system by the move of a single die along a path of small white stars. The journey takes them on a path to the Moon, Venus, Saturn, Mars and Jupiter before returning to Earth.

Whats interesting about the game is that 3 of the planets (Venus, Jupiter and Mars) rotate slowly during play by turning a disk and players have to align their ship towards the next path to move onto another planet.

On arrival on the moon and planets players acquire cards with valuable ore and gemstones. The value of each card is determined by who arrives there first.

The other interesting feature is a fast moving comet that orbits the players course by the throw of 2 dice. If a player collides with the comet a penalty such as loss of riches or even elimination from the game occurs.

After collecting the precious cargo from the planets and returning to Earth players are awarded bonus cards in order of arrival. The player with the largest value is deemed the winner.

—user summary

name: Bushido: Temo
description:
Temo fled first from the brutal enslavement of the Ito then from the worker camps of the Silvermoon. A resourceful seaman who holds and practises with great honour the knowledge of the jungle plants passed down through generations. It is these exotic combinations that he uses to dose his distinct blowpipe, the effects of the those darted vary from panic to rage dependant on the dart used.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Ran Fujiwaro
description:
A warrior sister of the Fujiwaro, Ran has betrayed her sisters to join with Mari Jung for reasons unknown. A blur on the battlefield, her sai finding cracks in armour and hide alike to cripple foes with a whirlwind of keenly placed attacks.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Sho
description:
From the Jwar to the Golden Sands across the Barren Sea, no more able a deckhand can be found. His body a net of tight knotted muscle, his mind a map of the sea.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Taru
description:
A brave and able seaman, he uses his net as a barrier to defend against missiles directed at him and also to divert their force against the attacker. Nimble and quick footed Taru is a great soldier for the Jung.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Mari Jung
description:
Queen of Waves, Lady of the Sea, the Third Storm are all and yet just a few of her names. Her eyes as deep as the ocean, her temper as terrible as a storm, as beautiful and inspiring to her crew as she is fear and reviled by her enemies. Her mere presence in the heat of battle staying her shipmates nerves, her tongue a weapon with which to strike at the honor of her opponents. For their captain her men would gladly make the ultimate sacrifice.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Lua, Buto Pirate
description:
It seems that the temptation of riches and sake are not the only things that can lead the Buto to leave their tribe. Lua a fine specimen of the Buto people has long since left the island of his birth, driven to satisfy a deep and lasting wanderlust the Jung are his new people. Much like many of those who crew the Jung ships he adds somethings few others can offer. His great axe felling foes or masts alike. He still has a few tricks up his sleeve learnt from his youth in the crowded streets of Jima to surprise though.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Kohanin
description:
A life on the waves makes you hard, bodies muscled and lean, the sway of the ocean becomes as natural as sitting under a tree. This is the life of Kohanin, their lives before swearing loyalty to the captain forgotten. Their crimes washed away as debris from a beach at high tide. More comfortable on deck than land, they are capable sailors and fighters, turning their weapons of labour into deadly instruments of battle in an instant.
—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Claims of Gold
description:
The race is on! Ole prospector Gus has kicked the bucket—God rest his soul. His last will and testament states that the deed to his gold-rich land goes to the first miner to claim 30 ounces from the dirt. Payment is due in seven days.

Claims of Gold plays over seven rounds with mechanics that combine worker placement and press your luck. Each turn, players place miner meeples out on the board to take different actions like visiting the workshop, mining the land, or cleaning out dirt to find gold. Taking an action first gives the best benefit, so players are met with challenging decisions on how to efficiently collect gold while trying to foil the efforts of other miners.

Press-your-luck comes into play as players clean out buckets of dirt from their operation to find gold. Bedrock is more rich with gold than regular Dirt, but watch out—it also contains more rocks. If a player reveals two rocks when cleaning out, then a piece of equipment they have acquired from the shop breaks.

Will you be the miner that claims it all?

name: Heroes of History: Iron Phalanx vs. Dragonboat Raiders
description:
In Heroes of History, you are the general and Gods and Kings are awaiting your orders. Give Thor Mjolnir and hammer away at King Leonidas and his Spartan Warriors making a last stand for Greeece. Or, turn the tables with Odysseus wielding Artemis's Bow and feed Viking kings to the Minotaur. Make the right moves, and be remembered for all time. Make the wrong moves, and be lost to the ages!

This is an expansion set for the original Heroes of History card game, featuring Midnight Riders (Revolutionary War) and Echoes of the Plains (Civil War). You do NOT need the first set to play the second set. They can be played together or separately.

2 players minimum; supports up to 4. The object is to reduce your opponent's State Points from 50 to 0. Draw cards from your deck, play Combatants like Thor, the Argonauts, Erik Bloodaxe, and Odysseus to the Trench and power them up with Weapon cards, including Artemis's Bow and Mjolnir. Play Supply cards to change the game situation. Zeus's Thunderbolt smites your opponent's entire War Zone, or use Danegeld to steal their State Points! Battlefields give bonuses to your side: will you battle in Valhalla or Troy?

This is a fully stand-alone game, but components can be combined with the original Heroes of History for a completely unique experience. Want Loki to shoot a Gatling gun? YOU can make it happen!

—description from the publisher
categories: Ancient, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval, Mythology
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Open Drafting, Player Elimination

name: Sea Battle
description:
A spinner driven war themed game where players move their ships down a track from the US Naval base to an enemy battleship and back.

For up to four players.

This game started as one game in a "Games of Adventure" 4 game set. The set included:

Air Race around the World
Jeep Patrol
Rocket race to Saturn
Sea Battle
mechanics: Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: War on the High Seas (2nd Edition)
description:
The game is set in a time that world trade is plagued by piracy, dangerous ocean voyages and fierce wars. Can you a small time merchant battle the stormy oceans and avoid the scourge of piracy trading goods for profit and becoming a Master Merchant, or will you build a superior fleet of ships and become to become a recognised Admiral of the Seas or perhaps you will find wealth in war and plunder your riches conquering ports around the world and become a Lord Governor.

The game is played over a number of rounds until one player scores one of the three victory conditions and is declared the winner.

In the standard game players are aiming to excel at one of three objectives. Master Merchant, Lord of Maritime or Lord Governor. Master Merchant requires a player to have 150g and dock at a port owned by their nationality. Admiral of the Seas requires a player to have 3 ship cards in his fleet and capture or buy a forth. Lord Governor requires a player to place his last nations port marker on the board.

For a more challenging and longer game the number of objectives a player needs to win can be raised to 2 or all 3.

Once a player has met an objective their turn immediately ends, however the round is not over and continues giving other player the opportunity to complete an objective. At the end of the round if more than one player has managed to complete all objectives needed to win, victory points are awarded (see below) to decide a winner, the highest scorer ultimately wins the game, if in the rare circumstances there is a draw, they can decide to accept a draw or both fleets can combat until one side loses a ship giving victory to the winner.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Pick-up and Deliver, Trading

name: Shadowfist: A Better Tomorrow
description:
Expansion set for the Shadowfist card game.

In the newly reopened Future juncture, explore a world centuries after the Chi Bombs dropped.

In a scene straight from Planet of the Apes, the Simian Nation is a land where sentient Apes and Monkeys rule. Human beings are subjugated or collaborators in this Banana Republic.

In another part of the world, human-kind has re-established itself and through their stewardship, the Earth's chi has started to heal.

Between these conflicting empires rests a wasteland filled with a blend of bandits, outcasts, and operatives. It is within the wastes that the new portals open allowing Portal Crawlers from each faction to gain a foothold as they try to build...

A Better Tomorrow

—description from the publisher

name: A Word or 2
description:
A word or 2 is a board game based on the T.V. game show of the same name. It aired in South Africa from 1998 - 2008. It was adapted from Des chiffres et des lettres.

The object of the game is to be the player with the highest number of points after nine rounds: six word games, two number games, and one conundrum.

Playing the game

The Word Game
Vowel and consonant cards are shuffled separately and placed face down in two piles. Taking turns, players 'call' either "consonant" or "vowel". A card from the corresponding pile is placed on the playing mat until all nine spaces have been filled. Players then attempt to form words using the letters before the timer runs out, with no letter being used more than once. The player with the longest word gets a point for each letter in the word, or 18 points if all the letters were used.

The Number Game
A randomiser is used to generate a number between 0 and 999. Players take turns calling for "high" or "low" value cards until Any or all of the selected number cards can be used to reach the target number, but numbers can only be used once. Permitted calculations are addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.
When the timer runs out, players announce their numbers. The player with the number closest to the target is awarded points as follows (provided the calculations were correct):
10 points for reaching the target, 7 points if within 5 (inclusive), 5 points if within 10 (inclusive), 0 if beyond 10.

The Conundrum round
A list of 275 jumbled up nine-letter words are provided in the rule sheet. The first person to guess the anagram scores 10 points.

Winning
The contestant with the most points at the end of all nine rounds is the winner.
categories: Math, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Number, Word Game

name: Fladder flats
description:
Everybody is enjoying a fun day at the beach but those pesky seagulls are about to ruin the day.

In Fladder flats you play the seagull, you spin a spinner and it shows you target color, you skweez the seagulls tail and try to hit the target sunbather with soapy poop. Every player has a 4 member family of a certain color. The last sunbather without poo determins the winner.

name: Pizza World
description:
Players are master pizza makers looking for the finest ingredients in a market. Each player is given shopping lists of ingredients to collect. With a limited number of ingredients in the market, getting the ingredients you need may not be easy.

Pizza World is a game about completing as many personal and shared shopping lists as possible, optional 'take that' elements and remembering where you last saw an ingredient - although they might not be where you thought.

Make friends, or not, as you compete for the ingredients you need.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management, Memory, Modular Board, Pick-up and Deliver, Set Collection

name: Plac
description: Players roll and move around a path on the board to be the first to reach the end.

name: Running Man: The Home Game
description:
A board game based on the 1987 Science Fiction movie. One player is the Runners. The other is the Stalkers.
The board is an 8x8 grid known as the Game Zone. There are 4 main locations located in the corners: Runner Entry, Stalker Entry, Satellite Uplink and Rebel Hideout. The centre 4 squares are known as the Intersection. In order to go from any corner location to any other corner location, you must first enter an intersection space.

There are 4 Runners: Ben Richards, William Laughlin, Harold Weiss and Amber Mendez. There are 5 Stalkers: Subzero, Buzzsaw, Dynamo, Fireball and Captain Freedom. Characters have 2, 3, 4 or 5 hits. When a character takes damage a damage counter is placed on it. If a character has more damage counters than hits, it is killed.

Runners and Stalkers start the game at differing stages:

At the start of the game the Richards, Laughlin, and Weiss counters are placed on the Runner entry square. Subzero starts on the Stalker entry point. Mendez enters the game on turn 4.
If Subzero is killed, both Dynamo and Buzzsaw immediately enter the game zone otherwise Dynamo and Buzzsaw enter on turn 6.
If both Dynamo and Buzzsaw are killed, Fireball immediately enters, otherwise Fireball enters on turn 10.
If Fireball is killed, Captain Freedom immediately enters play, otherwise Captain Freedom enters on turn 14.


Each player has a unique deck of cards comprising, Move, Attack, Defence and Special cards. Players take turns to draw three cards, place them in their hand and then play cards to move their own units and attack opposing units.

Move cards are used (discarded) to manoeuvre a player’s units around the board. A unit may make a max of 2 moves in a turn and must move the entire distance described by the move card or not at all.
Attack cards are used to make attacks against opposing units in the same space. A unit may make up to 2 attacks in a turn.
Defence cards are played to negate an attack.


The game ends when all Stalkers are killed or all Runners are either killed or escaped.

The Stalkers win if all of the Runners are killed.
The Runners get a minor victory if 1 or more of them make it to the Rebel Hideout.
The runners get a major victory if 1 or more of them makes it first to the Satellite Uplink and then the Hideout.


—user summary
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Preppers
description:
A card game for 2-4+ players in which each player represents a separate group of Preppers who are preparing for the end of the world. Players accumulate supplies and advantages in several different categories. While this goes on players eliminate different end of the world scenarios until only one remains. The remaining scenario will favour certain types of stockpile categories which will determine victory conditions.

There are 2 common decks:

Stockpile Deck: This deck contains 10 cards in each of 13 different stockpile categories: Weapons, Food, Animals, Vehicles, Plants, Knowledge, Medicine, Shelter, Trade, Water, Power, Cold and Equipment. Each category of cards has two cards each of values 3 to 7.
Scenario Deck: The scenario deck contains 20 cards giving a description of the stockpile categories advantageous in overcoming it (e.g. Zombie Apocalypse = Weapons x3, Vehicles x3)


To start flip over all the scenario cards face up and spread them over the centre of the table so that all of them are visible. The top 5 cards of the stockpile deck are also flipped.

There are 3 stages:

Prepping Stage: Players take turns with to flip over the top card of the stockpile deck and take 1 of the face-up stockpile cards and put it face-down in their stockpile. Players can look at their own stockpile cards but not their opponents. Move to Scenario Stage if there are no more face-up stockpile cards.
Scenario Stage: Players take turns to pick one of the face-up scenario cards and put it face-down in a discard pile. When there is only one scenario left, it becomes the End of the World Scenario (EOTWS) and play continues to the scoring stage.
Scoring Stage: The EOTWS will list categories that receive a bonus card value multiplier. For example: if it is the Zombie Apocalypse, all your Weapons cards and Vehicle cards are worth 3 times as much. For every category you have zero cards in, get -5 points. Your final score is equal to the total point value of all your stockpile cards.


The player with the highest score at the end of the game wins.

name: Big Horse Chess
description:
According to The Classified Encyclopedia of Chess Variants (§33.4, p305), Big Horse Chess shares little in common with orthodox chess except that it's played on an 8x8 board with pieces that hop like chess knights.

A player scores a point whenever any four of their eight pieces form a square of any size. Pieces that are landed upon are removed from play. The game ends when one player is down to three pieces. Highest score wins.

name: Building Babel
description:
It's a Thursday afternoon on the Plain of Shinar, and once again there is nothing to do. (History hasn't been invented yet much less bowling!) It looks like another wasted day. But then one of your buddies has a bright idea! "Let's build a tower all the way up to heaven!" he says. "Sure, I've got nothing better to do" you reply. And so the legend begins . . .

Building Babel is a card game for 3-6 players in which, working together, they try to successfully build the fabled Tower of Babel. In so doing players will also be trying to get more recognition for their efforts than the others do. Throughout the process God will be trying to stop them?

All that is required is 1 deck of playing cards and a handful of markers/tokens for each player. The cards are considered to be of two types – “Brick” cards (2 to J) which are used to construct the Tower, and “Act of God” cards (Q, K, A) which disrupt the construction process.

The deck is shuffled and a hand of cards dealt to each player (hand size is determined by the number of players). The rest of the cards form a draw pile.

Players take it in turns to play as follows:

The active player plays a valid "Brick" Card on the Tower. These must be placed in order. The base of the tower is a row of four 2s. Next up will be the 3s and so on until the top row is filled with the Jacks. There must always be at least two more cards on any uncompleted level below the one being played to. If a player completes a row in the tower, they place one of their tokens beside it. This will show who put the most effort into the project, come the end of the game!
If they cannot play a "Brick" card the active player must play an “Act of God” card (if they have one). The effect of the cards are as follows:
ACES: The next player misses their turn.
QUEEN: The order of game play is reversed (e.g. from left to right.)
KING: The last “Brick” Card played is taken off the tower and is shuffled into the draw pile. Additionally when the first King card is played all game related talking between players must stop due to confusion of the languages. When the fourth King card is played the game is over!

When the player has played their card (Brick or Act of God) they pick up the top card of the draw pile, their turn is over and play passes to the next player.
If they have no “Brick” or “Act of God" card to play the player must pass their turn. If the player was forced to pass their turn they cannot draw a card. On the turn after a player has passed, they may choose to shuffle up to half of their cards (round down) into the draw pile and replace them with an equal number then drawn from the top of the deck. That player's turn is then over.


Play continues until the tower is completed or the fourth King appears at which point God stops the project. In the event that tower is finished all players win, but the player with the most tokens beside the Tower is the big winner! However, if the fourth King card is played before this happens then everyone loses but the player with the most tokens beside the tower is the biggest loser for have put so much effort into a failed project.

name: Heroes & Commanders
description:
A World War II tactical game based on the mechanics of Colonial Space Wars.

The first prototype recreates small battles between Germans and Americans in the western front of Europe. It uses a hexagonal board with round tiles for units, while cards are used for controlling health, ammo and fuel supplies during the game.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Tile Placement

name: Honoris Beer
description:
HONORIS BEER (ENGLISH RULEBOOK)

COMPONENTS:

- 40 characters of beer cards.

- 1 yellow opaque dice with 20 sides.

- 4 wood player tokens.

- 7 title tokens of "Honoris Beer".

- 1 initial player token.

- 20 beer glasses resources.

- 10 beer barrel resources.

INTRODUCTION:

Honoris Beer is a fun game of chance and resources, with some strategy, where players will have to try to win challenges of greater stamina by drinking beer before other opponents or challengers and thus be able to win the honorary title "HONORIS BEER", or great brewer.


OBJECTIVE OF THE GAME:

Be the first to get 2 honorary tokens "Honoris Beer". For this you will have to be lucky in the rolls of the die and choose well in each play who is difficult to obtain and possession of resources so that he does not get these title cards.

PREPARATION OF THE DEPARTURE:

1. Each player chooses a color (purple, orange, yellow or brown) and places his card in his table area.

2. The deck of the 40 character cards is shuffled and placed face down in the center of the table.

3. Also next to the deck will be the resources of beer glasses and the resources of barrels, as well as the yellow die of twenty faces with numbering from 1 to 20 and the title chips "Honoris Beer".


HONORIS BEER (REGLAMENTO ESPAÑOL)

COMPONENTES:

- 40 cartas de personajes cerveceros.

- 1 dado opaco amarillo de 20 caras.

- 4 fichas de madera de jugador.

- 7 fichas de título “Honoris Beer”.

- 1 ficha de jugador inicial.

- 20 figuritas de recurso de vaso de cerveza.

- 10 figuritas de recurso de barril de cerveza.

INTRODUCCIÓN:

Honoris Beer es un divertido juego de azar y de recursos, con algo de estrategia, donde los jugadores tendrán que intentar ganar retos de mayor aguante bebiendo cerveza ante otros contrincantes o retadores y poder así ganar el título honorífico “HONORIS BEER”, el o la gran cervecero/a.


OBJETIVO DEL JUEGO:
