name: Gobbit: Phénix Expansion
description:
Text on Card in french: "Lorsque le Phénix apparait, tout le monde sans exception peut taper sur le cimetière. Le joueur le plus rapide empoche les cartes du cimetière. Le joueur qui a posé le phénix relance ensuite."

In english: "When the Phoenix appears, everyone without exception can hit the graveyard. The fastest player gets all the cards from the graveyard. The player who laid the phoenix then continues.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Animals, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Party Game
publishers: Morapiaf, Morning, OldChap Editions, Païlle Editions, Phalanx Games Polska

name: Stars and Crosses: World War 2 Company-Level Combat Rules
description:
STARS & CROSSES: Wargame rules for company-level battles on the Western Front in World War 2 in 6mm scale. Incredibly simple and flexible rule system.

Easy to learn, with modular expert rules you can use to customize your game play. Includes a PDF with printable counters and terrain hexes. Can be played as a hybrid board/miniatures game, thanks to unit bases that double as board game counters, with essential combat stats printed right on the unit base! Each player takes the role of a US Army or Wehrmacht platoon or company leader, with one or more platoons at his disposal, plus additional units purchased with a point-buy system.

Features include:

Hex-based movement (no rulers needed!)
Intuitive range and sighting rules
Command and initiative
Custom-equip your rifle squads with snipers, bazookas, panzerfausts, and more
Infantry close assault and armor overrun rules
Ground attacks by air units
Called artillery fire
Wounded, medics, and aid stations
Specialized ammo like white phosphorus, smoke, and proximity shells
Stats for dozens of infantry and vehicle units
categories: Book, Print & Play, Wargame, World War II

name: The Ancient Evil
description:
In The Ancient Evil up to 4 players will take on the role of investigators trying to thwart the plans of the evil cults,
controlled by a fifth. This fifth evil player or 'Games Master' will be in charge of driving the scenario, creating an atmosphere of mystery and suspense for investigators. The 'Games Master' will find everything they need to keep the investigators on edge; summoning cultists and monsters, as well as introducing plot twists, special events, and more. And the closer the investigators get the more powerful he will become.

During each scenario the investigators are free to proceed as they wish but every action they take in their attempts to solve the mystery generates 'menace' which in turn fuels the powers of the 'Game Master'.

Both investigators and enemies use a points system to perform different actions. Some actions, such as moving and attacking are limited in how many times they can be performed on a turn.
Actions are resolved using a D10 dice, rolled against the relevant skill, to determine success ranging from critical failure to a critical success. Critical results will be unique to the item or action being used/taken. Some enemies can even take and use items and equipment against the investigators.

Facing off against the Ancient Evil the investigators are in constant danger of falling to insanity. Exposure to otherworldly creatures, eldritch magic and unnatural events all threaten to drain their precious sanity. Such mental trauma can result in
episodes of temporary insanity or phobias which impact on an investigators ability to perform actions. Investigators pushed to the brink may even become completely insane. But this does not eliminate the investigator who, after flipping their character sheets to reveal an insane version, will continue to play.

The game comes with a scenario book containing numerous missions that can be played alone or linked as a campaign. But it doesn't end there. With the many tiles, enemies and other components you will have the tools to create your own scenarios. We are also committed to supporting the game and keeping to alive by, amongst other things, providing even more scenarios via our website which will be free to download.

—description from the designers
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Boy Scouts
description:
Boy Scouts is an Australian patriotic game first registered in 1911 by the National Game Company. Subsequent later versions appeared until around the 1930s.

The game is a simple roll and move mechnism along a path starting at the Australian red ensign flag and progressing to a final camp destination 90 moves away. The later version has the flag at the end.

Along the journey players can benefit or be penalized by landing on certain numbers, such as miss a turn, extra throw, advance or be sent back.

The player to reach camp first is declared the winner.

—user summary
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Box Quiz: Fodbold
description:
One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme 'Football'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about football. It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

name: Box Quiz: Jorden Rundt
description:

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about "Around the World". It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

name: Zippity Do!
description: 12 picture cards are spread on the table. One-by-one players take turns singing a song with one of the images. Remaining players try to be the first to identify what picture card is the subject of the song. Spot the song-Slap the card!

name: Imagine It!
description:
This is an educational game system created by McGraw-Hill. It is a workshop designed for small groups of children in Grade 2 who need extra help with reading comprehension skills. There is a set of six game boards (Let's Go Skiing, At the Ranch, Under the Sea, etc.) with lavishly illustrated pathways.

Players move along the pathway by drawing cards and responding correctly. The first player to reach the Finish space is declared the winner but all of the pathways contain bonus spaces to let slower players gain extra moves.

name: Mad Science!
description:
Players take the role of mad scientists, trying to outdo each other with inventions while avoiding catastrophic explosions in their labs.

Game play is straight forward press-your-luck with dice. Eight dice, two each of four colors, are rolled and grouped according to the faces shown. Scoring dice can be rerolled to add further score, but non-scoring dice pile up and count against you.

The goal of the game is to have the highest score at the end of a round where someone passes the game threshold - 200 points makes for about a 15 minute game once you're comfortable with scoring.

name: Honma-seibatu
description:
This is a self-published expansion kit for Sengoku Gunyuden series.
"Honma-seibatu" (Honma dominated) covers the historical and hypothetical battles on the small north island of Sado.

Five scenarios are included in this kit.



Note: Honma was a minor clan subjected by Uesugui (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honma_clan)

name: Eestimaa Puhas Vesi
description:
Eestimaa Puhas Vesi (Estonias Clean Water) is a game of 2-6 players where players travel through Estonia trying to find clear water among other resources. After finding the Clean Water -piece player must return to the capital of Estonia, Tallinn.

—user summary

name: Offend The World
description:
The fast paced game of languages and offence.

There are 10 languages each with 8 swear words over four different levels of offence (Extreme, Offensive, Rude, Mild) The object of the game is to get rid of all of your cards by playing cards of the same language or same level of offence. When you play a language card you must say the word or you pick up two!

There are a number of special cards added to the mix which allow you to screw over other players and can get you out of difficult situations as they can be played on any card.

For an added twist there is always a RULE in play. This can be anything from picking up additional cards from saying the words in an accent to ending the game quicker. You can play a RULE card at ANY time to wreak havoc amongst your oppenents.

There is also a 'make your own' set for adding those extra special words!

How many can you offend?

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Tinmates
description:
Battle for the Yard to gain Power and become the Prison Boss in this strategic area control game by Dranda Games

Tinmates is a strategic area control game that was created by Simon Milburn, of Dranda Games, for the 2017 Mint Tin Design Contest.

Players take turns to choose one of 4 actions - Deal to gain currency - Train to heal or upgrade - Bribe to gain advantageous cards - Fight to challenge the Yard or deal damage from the yard.

Players win by reaching the power goal (which varies depending on the player count). Players gain power by moving into the yard or by being in the Yard at the beginning of their turn.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Tal'Vos
description:
Tal'Vos is a deck building/card building game for 2-4 players.

Each player takes on the role of Admiral for their noble houses Airship and battles it out with their opponents til only one is left standing and is crowned emperor.

The game features strategic, fast passed back and forth action seen in many CCGs, as well as deck building and card building mechanics where instead of adding new cards to their deck, players instead upgrade their cards by sleeving in clear transparent upgrades over the cards they already have.

Each turn, players set their speed and select an opponent to attack and play cards back and forth into either offense or defense pools. Then they compare statistics and if the attacker manages to meet or beat the defenders agility, they deal damage! After the combat round, players purchase clear upgrade cards to sleeve into the cards they just played and then put everything in their discard. After 2 turns, players shuffle their discard piles, creating a new deck with cards now modified by what they purchased.

—description from the publisher

name: Steady Job Game
description:
Steady Job is especially designed for students of junior-senior high school age who have learning problems. Occupational research shows that persons do not lose their jobs because of lack of skills and knowledge but because of poor attitudes and a lack of understanding of the responsibilities involved in employment.

Steady Job is designed to reinforce the positive attitudes and behaviors essential to employability.

The object of the game is to be the first person to get a steady job.

—description from the publisher

The Steady Job Game is a roll and move game played with a d6 and pawns on a liner advancement line from the Employment Office (start) square to the Steady Job Square (finish).

Landing on a red - square causes the player to draw a - card and follow the (negative) instructions. Landing on a green + square causes the player to draw a green + card and follow the positive (instructions). The negative cards usually send a player back spaces due to negative actions (overslept, missed the bus, poor manners, failed to finish work). The positive cards reward players with advancing spaces for positive actions (on time to work, took a bath, cleaned work area, remembered to use safety equipment).

The game seeks to reinforce positive work habits and demonstrate the consequences of negative work habits.

The winner is the first player to advance to the Steady Job square at the end of the line.

—user summary

name: Box Quiz: Nordisk Mad
description:
One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme 'Nordic Food'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about Nordic food. It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

name: Pipe Fabrication Engineering & Design Game
description:
This game is designed to bring families and friends together have fun while learning basic, engineering, pipe fitting, fabrication and design skills, that are very useful in the construction, oil Gas industry.

It is an excellent and easy way to learn print reading, for:

Pipefitting and fabrication,
Piping engineering and design,
Planning and estimating,
Piping welding inspection and Quality Control, and many other construction crafts,

The game comes in a deck of 54 playing cards, and two sets of 6 Isometrics and P&IDs cards each set, plus an instruction manual.

It is a fun and easy to learn game, it can be played by 1 to 6 people of any gender form ages +8.

To play the game, you will use the different cards and build your piping spool as per isometric (ISO) drawings.

You will be simulating the main activities of a pipe fabricator/fitter, field engineer, planners, piping inspector, designer, etc. Starting from reading the prints, identify y select your materials to make the installation/fit (i.e. choose the right material "cards" then place it in the right location and orientation) as per isometrics and P&IDs (piping blueprints).

—description from the publisher

name: Box Quiz: VM
description:
One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme 'FIFA World Cup'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about the Fifa World Cup. It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

name: Prismal
description:
Prismal is a cooperative card game for 2 to 6 players, from 10 years old, of about 15 minutes. PRISMAL is the first game from the anthropomorphic universe we are developing:"Kingdoms of Isempar".

The goal of the game is to decrypt the cards face down in the middle of the table. Team spirit and deductions will be required to decrypt these cards using the information provided by players as they play.

Pick randomly one card of each colour and place them face down in the middle of the table. These six cards are called "encrypted" cards.

Shuffle the rest of the selected cards and deal them all to the players.

Important: Players cannot communicate with each other about the cards in their hands. A player can only see the colour of other players' cards by looking at their backs.

During their turn, a player must perform one of the following two actions:

Place a card: The player takes a card from his hand and places it face up in front of the "encrypted" card of his choice, without covering the one (s) already placed. This card can be placed in front of an "encrypted" card of a different colour.
The player takes a card from their hand and puts it face down in front of them. Players may at any time consult the backs of cards that have been discarded from the game.


The game ends when the players have no more cards in their hands or when all players have successively discarded a card. Then they flip the "encrypted" cards.
The number of cards placed in front of each "encrypted" card must correspond exactly to its value. Players then estimate their success rate based on the number of cards they have decrypted.

—description from the publisher

name: The Game of America Campaign
description:
Goal of the game: You are a Political Party trying to control the 3 Branches of the Government. First control the States (Legislature). Next control the Supreme Court (Judicial). Then control the Presidency (Executive).

Roll and move to collect (purchase) States which increase the number of votes you receive towards the 280 required to win the game. When you control all the States of a Territory, you can start to add Support which will increase the income level for any State in that Territory.

Control the Supreme Court by appointing 5 of the 9 Supreme Court Justices. Appointment is scaled with the first requiring 50 votes and $500K, the 2nd 100 votes, 3rd 150 votes, 4th 200 votes and the 5th and final 250 or more votes. $500k must be paid in each case. Justices can be removed if your vote total drops below the required amount.

Controlling the Presidency requires 280 votes, 5 Justices and pay Five Million dollars to the bank. This is how you win the game.

name: The Glory of Rome
description:
Technically The Glory of Rome is the title of a "Series of Historical-Political-Military Conflict-Simulations about the Ancient World" (to quote the cover), and this is volume one, The Complete Approach to the Wars between the CARTHAGE and ROME of Scipio Africanus and Hannibal, but since no other volumes were published the series title is being used for the game.

The game is strategic, with a fairly small map covering the Western Mediterranean. There are 65 turns covering the entire period of the Punic Wars; players are not necessarily fighting the entire time as wars need to be declared and peace can be brokered by agreement. In between wars players can move troops around, get reinforcements, hire mercenaries, etc.

Land units are represented by a small set of metal miniatures (included with the game); army strengths are presumably recorded on paper although this is not made very clear. Naval units are represented either by paper counters cut from a possibly-included sheet or by borrowed counters. Historical leaders with special abilities enter and leave the game on a schedule.

Combat uses a fairly standard CRT but with die roll adjustments provided by players simultaneously choosing maneuvers which are cross-referenced on a separate table.

In addition to the leaders chrome is provided in the form of special rules for various locations, e.g. Sardinia has a chance of revolting starting on turn 16 unless it has a sufficiently large garrison.

Much about the game is unclear since Taurus Games' rules were written in a barely coherent stream-of-consciousness style.

—user summary

name: Weltmeister gegen Europameister
description: World Champion Counter Europe Champion: Each player has 1 pawn (boxer) which he moves about the board. Movement is determined by a die. The World Champion begins casting, and then dicing is alternately done. The pips mark the steps that the boxers coming from their respective ring corners, take on the marked way towards each other to come to blows. If the attacker lands on the space occupied by his opponent, it means that he landed him an effective blow and scores a point. The fight lasts 3 rounds or til one boxer is knocked out. Winner of a round will be who has first scored 5 hits.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation

name: Ponies
description:
Ponies is a horse racing game with dice. Seven dice are included with the game, 6 with letters and 1 normal die. Players start with an equal amount of money (in 1, 5, 10, 20 and 50 unit demoninations) and all start with a 5 unit in the stake fund.

Each players take turns at one roll of all seven dice. The following word combinations are possible:

WIN - Player takes all units in stake. This then starts a new game.
PLACE - Player collects 1/2 of the units in the stake.
SHOW - Player collects 1/3 of the units in the stake.
LEAD - Player collects 10 times the number of units indicated by nunber on normal die from the stake.
PACE or RACE - Player collects 5 times the number of units indicated by number on the normal die from the stake.
REAR - Player neither collects or donates.
If none of the above words appear on role, player then donates number of units indicated on the normal die to the stake.

Player can never collect more money than is in the stake. When there is no more money in the stake, all players donate five unites apiece to the stake.

Game continues until someone gets WIN.

Alternate game play: Only play with rules for WIN, PLACE or SHOW.

—user summary

name: Gandouchi
description:
The origins of the word がんどうち, pronounced Gandouchi, are not entirely certain but one popular theory is that the word is composed from another word meaning "to steal". Gandouchi is a traditional event that takes place during the Doll Festival particularly in the prefecture of Gifu. Children visit nearby houses and ask to view that home's doll display. After viewing the dolls, they receive snacks and sweets from the residents of the home — comparable to the tradition of Trick-or-treating on Halloween in some Western countries.

In Gandouchi, you want to arrange hina doll cards in your hand the best way possible. All the cards start spread out face down on the table. On a turn, you reveal two cards, then add one of them to your hand or exchange a card in hand for one of these cards. Any exchanged card and the card not taken are turned face down again, so pay attention to these cards and watch what others pick up!

At game's end, players reveal their hands, scoring the most points for having a wide range of colors and types of cards.

name: Last Earth: Pangaea Ultima
description:
Scientists predicted that in a quarter of a billion years from now, Earth’s landmass would merge into a single contiguous continent, the Pangaea Ultima. The effect would be gradual, they thought, and people would have millions of years to prepare.

They couldn’t be more deadly wrong.

In 2029, a massive explosion on the Sun’s surface, forced Earth’s continents to move violently against each other and by 2031 the Pangaea Ultima scenario had become a gruesome reality. About 99,7% of the world’s population is dead, cities have been razed to the ground and all infrastructure is lost.

But still, hope is not lost. Out of the ruins of the old world, the few survivors emerge strong and determined to rebuild what was undone. Among them, you and your team of survivors will try to re-establish civilization in the brutal and hostile world that is now called the Last Earth.

Last Earth is a post-apocalyptic tile placement, resource management exploration game for 2-5 players packed with enough action and strategic choices to keep you on the edge for game after game.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Push Your Luck

name: The Employment Game
description:
In this roll-to-move game, players are competing to get the best possible jobs. The first player to get a combination of jobs that pays $3,000 per month, without exceeding 200 working hours, is the winner.

Game play: On a player's turn they roll the dice and move the appropriate number of spots around the board. The player then picks up the job card corresponding to the spot they landed on, and place the card in front of them. The player then records the amount of hours worked, and earns the income from the job. It is then the next player's turn. This repeats until one player has accumulated enough jobs to earn $3,000 per month, without exceeding 200 working hours.

If a player gets a new job card that would put them over 200 hours worked, they need to either discard the card, or replace one of their other job cards with the new card.

On their turn, after rolling their dice but before moving, a player can try to gamble to try and steal someone else's job. If the player decides to gamble, they re-roll the dice and attempt to get the same result. For example, if the die roll of the their first roll was 8, then they would try to re-roll the dice to get 8 again. If they are successful, they can take any job card from any other player. If they are not successful, then they must pay a penalty fee to the "Employment Pot".

The rules suggest that any penalty paid to the "Employment Pot" should be paid with real money, and the winner of the game gets to keep any money in the "Employment Pot."

—user summary

name: 青春スパイラル (Youthful Spiral)
description:
User summary
青春スパイラル (Seishun Spiral) (Youthful Spiral) is a Daifugo-type game, where each player plays a card, and the first one to get rid of their cards wins. But the twist is, when you pass, you have a right to exchange your cards. So you may "build up" your hand, in play.

The game is played over three rounds, but the 1st and 2nd rounds are only a run-up match. The grand winner is the player who won the 3rd match. Keep that in mind, and aim to strengthen your hand before the showdown!

Daifugo is a classic Japanese card game with a climbing mechanic, where players clear their hand by playing higher value cards. But the weakest player is able to improve their position between rounds.

Publisher's summary
手札を順に出していき、最初に手札が無くなったプレイヤーが勝ちという大富豪タイプのゲームですが、パスする際に手札を交換する権利が得られます。これを利用して、ゲーム中にどんどん手札を整えることができます。
ゲームは全体で三度行われ、1回戦・2回戦は前哨戦にあたります。最後の3回戦に勝てば勝ちなので、それまでに手札を鍛え上げましょう！

name: Final War: Carnage Expansion Set
description:
The Carnage Expansion Set introduces the explosive power of the melee-based Warlords; the righteous Knight, the crafty Dwarf and the ferocious Orc. With dominating new abilities and punishing powers, you’ll need to bring your A game to emerge victorious over these Warlords!

This set contains:

3 Warlord Cards
50 Card Knight Player Deck
50 Card Dwarf Player Deck
50 Card Orc Player Deck
Rule & Ability Revision Guide
“End of Round” Action Markers
Shield Wall Markers
Quick Play Guide
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy

name: Strawberry Shortcake: Berries to Market Game
description: This is a color matching race to the finish board game. Spin the color dial and move your character to the color that was selected. Landing on the Lucky Bug will send you to the next color space on the board matching your piece. The Berry Bird will send you back to the color matching your piece. Be the first to the finish line to win!

name: CardTharsis
description:
CardTharsis is a fast-paced game where you use "little hands" to "drain the swamp" and laugh out loud while, as a group, you and your friends Make yourselves feel Great Again. CardTharsis uses humor to cultivate the inner strength we will need to survive. Laugh. Stay strong. Resist. Play.

You will be presented with possible real life scenarios based on three very human categories: Social, Political and Sexual. You must respond by playing cards from your "swamp" in your little hand. The best response collects the cards. The player with the most cards wins. In your "little hand" also known as the "swamp" will be some truly despicable waste: Actual Quotes from the President.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game, Political
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Monsters and Kids
description:
“A dark pretentious strategy card game for people who love kids and monsters, just the same.”

Monsters and Kids is a 2-4 player card game for everyone who loves the bizarre, weird, darkness and more bizarre. (Because you can never have enough of bizarre.)

If you are not afraid of monsters, U.F.O.s or anything supernatural, the kids could really use your help. Save them from disasters and look out for enemies while constantly making sure you have enough cards to survive another turn.

So, in conclusion, Monsters and Kids is a turn by turn strategic card game created by two architects. The strategies range from developing cute illustrations, attractive intro videos, nursery rhymes, dark themes, self-referential humor to deadly aggressive attacks for pulling in maximum people.

—description from the designer

name: Legacy of Twilight
description: Currently being changed.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Trading

name: Halls of Judgment
description:
Be the best God of Judgment.
Get points four ways: Use your power to bid for followers or to activate them as heralds. At the end of the game, get points for fairness and for hidden goals.

—description from the publisher

name: Taloc Mayan
description:
In ancient Mesoamerica explorers from many places founded isolated civilizations... until they discovered others who happened to be there before them. Violent clashes ensued as they vied for control of sacred pyramids, temples, sinkhole cenotes, and jungle shrines. You can experience this with the Taloc: Mayan adventure boardgame as you try to construct the Mayan temple before your competitors take over your people, your powers, and your resources.

Don't forget to take into account the Mayan calendar whose clock is ticking as you play, changing the parameters of the game as you try to build to the top.

Available in flat 2D and the ultimate 3D tabletop versions, this game is sure to add excitement to your gaming table.

With precisely sculpted 28mm heroic miniatures, a custom dice tower, water fog machine effects, LED lighting options, soundtracks, finely detailed modular terrain, custom game dice and accessories, you are sure to be able to reuse the compatible game components on your RPG game table after the board gameplay fades.

Build and conquer in historical Yucatan with Taloc Mayan: the board game.

—description from the publisher
categories: Abstract Strategy, Adventure, Ancient, City Building, Civilization, Dice, Economic, Miniatures, Mythology, Territory Building
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board, Tile Placement, Turn Order: Time Track, Worker Placement

name: Newsroom
description:
Newsroom is a worker placement game where you get to manage your own international media outlet. The aim of the game is to publish your newspaper editions earlier than other players thus gaining the trust of your audience and of the advertisers and boosting your global presence as an International media outlet.

In the beginning of the round, news come out in different countries around the world in different fields (politics, economy, sports, culture). Each story is associated to countries with the roll of dice. Players have in their disposal a Press team and send its members to cover some of the stories, by interviewing people and getting their news copy back in the paper.
Each edition is divided in 4 blocks (newspaper columns) and has to cover at least 10 content points which derive from the news pieces that journalists bring back or, later in the game, from advertisements. Once the edition content is complete, the paper goes to the editors while journalists are free to get some more news stories from around the world.

After the editors have checked your story, the copy moves on to printing and is published. Its time to collect money, to pay your Press team and to hire better journalists, or more editors or printers to get your next edition even faster. Remember, the competition in the media is fierce and if you lose time the other media outlets will get your story out and it will then be worth nothing to you or your audience.

Based in the queuing theory, Newsroom is an easy to learn but hard to master worker placement- economic management game where speed and effectiveness determine the winner. Much like in the real media world!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Take That, Worker Placement

name: Roads and Rails, Rivers and Trails
description: Play your cards to build a shared network of roads, rails, rivers, and trails. Block your opponents while scoring paths for yourself -- but don't forget about any of your own paths, or you'll be caught short at the end!

name: Owen's Chase
description:
Owen's Chase is an asymmetrical 2-player deduction game set in the 19th century Nantucket. Whales are trying to safely travel north to the feeding grounds to feast on rich krill while being pursued by a sharp lookout in the crow's nest of a whaling ship. On each expedition, use your senses to track down a whale in the vast ocean. But be careful of dangerous weather, unexpected repairs, or even a nasty tail fluke that can bring your chase quickly to an end.

One player plays as the Whale and the other as the Lookout. The Whale player puts the cards face down in a 4 x 4 grid, and the Lookout chooses cards. Based on the card chosen when revealed, various actions occur that can have the Lookout win, the Whale win, or other results. Play continues until the Whale is found or or the Shipyard is found, or until the expedition ends. Cards include the Whale, a tail attack, crow's nest, open ocean, shipyard, and storm.

—user summary

name: Prime Number Five
description:
Prime Number Five is very easy mathmatic memory game.
Contain 30 cards.
All cards has frontside number and backside number.
Each card, frontside and backside has a some relation.

Backside numbers are 2, 3, 5, 7, and 11. (5 types number x 6 cards)
Frontside numbers are 4, 6, 9, 10, 14, 15, 21, 22, 25, 33, 35, 49, 55, 77, and 121. (15 types number x 2 cards)

If frontside number is 14, then the card's backside is 2 or 7.
Because 14=2x7
If backside number is 3, then the card's frontside is 6, 9, 15, 21, or 33.

Shuffle all cards, and spread them on table.
In your turn, reveal one card and another.
If the two cards's frontside numbers are same, you get it.
Get, or not get, next player's turn.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Math, Memory, Number

name: Reise durch die Heimat
description:
The game consists of a board based on a railway map of Switzerland, and around 100 cardboard tokens labeled with the names of each station.

The object is to be the first player to complete a pre-agreed journey across the map by rolling a die and moving. A six gets another turn but if a second six is rolled then the player must move backwards. Mountain and local lines can only be traversed when the correct number is thrown.

The rules sheet (bilingual German/French) give 10 different variants for how the players' routes may be chosen: in some the tokens are placed on the map and collected, in others the tokens are used to draw a station at random.

Publisher: Papa Schubi № 2822.

name: Top Deer
description:
Top Deer is a race game in which 2-4 players try and breed and race the best reindeer for Santa's sleigh team.

The chief stablemaster at Santa's North Pole lair has announced his upcoming retirement, and Santa is holding a contest to decide who to promote. Whoever can win the most races - or most-accurately pick the fastest reindeer most consistently - will get the top job, but there are a number of less-than-nice-list tactics your opponents might employ to bump your career off the track!

Each reindeer is represented by a hand of five regular French-deck playing cards. In each race player stack these cards in a pre-determined order and turn them over to move their reindeer around the track; after each race players have a chance to selectively breed the best traits from their current reindeer into the next generation of racers.

Top Deer is a single-sheet game that doesn't need any construction and just requires a few tokens per player and a couple of decks of cards, intended to be included in a Christmas card.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Fuel & Duel
description:
This is a light weight racing game for the light hearted. Racing around the track trying to get first over the finishing line as you are pumping up the steam in your engine and knocking out the others out of the way. But be aware that you will lose if you run out of fuel.

A kids and family racing game introducing resource management for younger players. Fuel the car engine to move, the more you feed the engine the faster it could go, but as hotter it gets.

Manage your resources and roll to move.

Bild your own racing tracks with the modular boards, customise your vehicles, manage the resources, nock the other cars out of track or try to break them and win the game.

Slogan: Racing for glory, win with luck and planing.

Theme: Car race

How to win: First to move over the finishing line of the final lap is the winner of the game.
mechanics: Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Pusher Kings
description:
Pusher Kings is a funny, two-player card game that has you struggling to maintain control of the drug market in your town! This game is not a deck builder, so both players will be playing from a pre-set deck. Each player gets a hand of seven cards (with at least one "pusher" card in their hand) before the game starts. You must flip cards to use them, only using specific cards for your turn.

There are a few different card types; Pushers, Henchmen, and Actions. Pushers sell the drugs and can be used once per turn. Once you flip the card over in order to use them you gain money that can only be spent during that turn. Once the turn is over, the money disappears. Pushers cannot attack, defend, or take damage and only one can be used per turn.

Henchman have different costs, abilities, and attributes. They are used to gain power in the town and can be attacked. Henchman also cost a fair amount of money each, so you will need to be able to pay them to use them in your turn. The first turn you draw a henchman, you have to have them flipped, so they cannot be played right away.

Action cards are not flipped but instead discarded. There are only two of each action card in the deck, so you need to play them wisely. Each action is immediate and costs resources to play. These can be used to harm player’s henchmen or the player themselves.

Each player has 10 health points (the player themselves who holds the cards) so once they have been harmed enough to reach zero health points, the game is over.

Pusher Kings has some really awesome artwork drawn on the cards! This card game does not have deck building aspects, so it is an easy game to pick up and play with your friends.

—description from the designer

name: House Rules
description:
House Rules is a print and play party game where you make the rules!Take turns racing around the board, drawing cards with rules on them and collecting Star Tokens. One turn you might get a Board Rule that advances you three spaces. On your next you might get a Player Rule telling you to:


Win a 10 second round of Charades or return to your last space
Tweet to your secret crush or lose a Star Token
Sketch a player in under 30 seconds AND get their approval
Break into teams of two, have one player pick a secret word and get the other to answer it - the first team to guess their word wins Star Tokens


Everything you need to play is included in the download. Just print and play!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Hand Management, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Freight Wars
description:
Freight Wars is a 2-3 player game where you can procedurally generate your game tiles before you print them, giving you a completely unique game set. You are a Victorian industrialist who is looking to build a transportation network. You can do this by placing roads, rivers, or railways to connect towns to other places, as well as block off the routes of your opponents.

First, you must choose which mode of transportation each player should use. One should use roads, one rivers, the other should use trains. Then, you must shuffle the cards and hand them out to various players. Each player should get a town card, as well as two other cards dealt to them.

Players must place tiles so that the modes of transportation connect to the tiles already placed on the table. These tiles will need to match up for every mode of transportation to be placed, then the player will be able to draw another tile from the deck, so they always have three cards. Players can also skip a turn by discarding all of their tiles to draw a new hand.

After all of the tiles are placed, players must count up how many connections they have between towns. There are different points depending on how well the transport links are between different places. This can be seen in more detail in the rules of the game.
—description from the designer

This print-and-play game has an unusual distribution method - players download a Windows executable program which generates random tiles for printing. Once printed, the tiles are used for traditional tabletop play. Because the tiles are programmatically generated with randomization, no two sets will be exactly the same.

—user summary

name: Pocket Skirmish
description:
Pocket Skirmish is a fast-paced tactical card game for 2 players, in which you assume control over 3 units on a randomly generated map. With tactics and luck, you achieve victory by defeating all of your opponent's units!

—description from the publisher

name: Auto Rennen
description:
The players have to drive their racing cars from start to finish. Movement is determined by a standard die (1-6) and a color die. The result of the color die decides which car is to be moved. So each player rolls for all players in the game. On illustrated spaces, events hinder or benefit the player. The first player to reach space 76 wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Ruck Zuck
description:
The players have to move their token from start to finish. The token have holes in their center, which are used to move the token with a stick (lance). Movement is determined by 40 small cards with letters on them. The cards are used to form the words "Ruck" and "Zuck". The players start with 3 cards, lying open in front of them. Every turn the player draws a card. As soon as he can form one of the two words the player has to move his token accordingly. "Ruck" means forward and "Zuck" means backward. The number of spaces is equal to the number of cards used to form the word (2-4). If a player moves his token onto a green space, he may move forward to the next green space. A red space means the player has to move backward to the last red space.
The first player to reach the finish wins the game.

name: Kagami
description: Kagami is a one to four player solo or cooperative abstract game in which players attempt to mirror two sides of an eight by eight board or four quadrants for a more challenging experience and more players. The game is played without verbal communication. Players score based on the type and number of stones perfectly matched on the board.

name: Wine Collector
description:
Wine Collector is a visually dynamic tile-laying game in which you must try and satisfy the whims and wants of a selection of fussy Wine Collectors by finding the relevant wine in your cellar (represented by bottle/label parts), and putting together the relevant wine bottle from your collection of tiles...

Limits on available Grape varieties, Flavours, and Nuances will ensure it's not an easy task. Do you push-your-luck and hold out for 'the whole caboodle', or cut your losses and deliver a sub-standard product...? It's your call, but when the last Wine Collector has left the building, it's game over!

Each round, players take it in turns to either draw a card from one of three decks (either a new one from the top, or the last previously discarded tile) or can choose to satisfy a Wine Collector's demands and 'claim' the relevant Income from that Collector. Collectors will pay well if all their demands are satisfied, or not-so-much if you can only meet some of their expectations...

There are three tile decks:

Grapes are double-sided tiles with a particular grape or wine variety on each side. These are placed in front of players when they're drawn, but each player may only have a maximum of four grapes/varieties in front of them at any one time, but may choose to draw additional Grape tiles and discard down if necessary to ensure they do not exceed this limit. Grape cards will need to be given up for each Wine Collector claimed.

Flavours are tiles that have two representative flavours on them, and they can be utilised one way or the other by rotating the tile through 180 degrees. These are kept in a player's hand until used to claim a Wine Collector.

Finally, Nuances are tiles that have three descriptors on them, and can be used to satisfy Collector demands either in part or whole, depending on how they are used and which descriptors are covered by other tiles when making a claim. These tiles are also kept in a player's hand until used.

A player's hand size is limited to just six tiles/cards in total (excl. Grapes/Varieties which are kept on the table in front of them), and you must juggle these as best you can to make a call on what tiles are worth holding onto, and which ones can be safely discarded...

—description from the publisher
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Party Game, Puzzle, Word Game
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Pick-up and Deliver, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Tile Placement, Trick-taking

name: Happiness Board Game
description:
Based on the latest scientific research from Positive Psychology, the Happiness Board Game teaches players how to raise their happiness levels. Players take turns rolling dice and moving around the game board. Game board is made up of three kinds of spaces: positive circumstances and attitudes, negative circumstances and attitudes, and bonuses.

When players land on a positive space they take a card from the corresponding deck and read it out loud. Cards present positive situations were points are rewarded for being in a positive circumstance or having a positive attitude. Those points are then multiplied by their corresponding weight (10% or 40% respectively) that the situation has on one’s happiness level. Players than move their score tracker the appropriate number of spaces in the scoring area.

The same happens when players land on a negative space, except the points are negative and suggestions are given on what players can do to raise their happiness levels in negative situations.

Some of the cards provide points of discussion such as, “You begin volunteering at the local animal shelter. Scientific studies have found that volunteering increases our level of happiness. Right now have every player name some volunteering work that he or she would like to do.”

Play ends with the first player to reach 100 points.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Digital Safety Game
description:
Created by the Tallinn University Digital Safety Lab The idea of the game is to learn more about digital safety. The goal is to answer as many questions as possible and win after accumulating a required number of cards. The game is designed so the inquirer has to formulate a question and evaluate whether the answer is correct or not. Discussions and real life examples why this knowledge is important are encouraged.

At his/her turn, the player (inquirer) chooses and asks a question on the card from the next player (respondent). The inquirer evaluates whether the answer is correct or incorrect.
In case of CORRECT answer the respondent keeps the card and places it in front of him/her, face up.
In case of INCORRECT answer, the inquirer keeps the card and places it in front of him/her, face up.
Player who first collects 3 cards from one category (same color) shouts out "I'm Safe!" and wins the game!

—user summary
categories: Card Game, Educational, Print & Play, Trivia

name: Cults of Dagon
description:
Cults of Dagon is a print and play game of set collection and insanity for 2 to 4 players. The game is a work of fan fiction based on H. P. Lovecraft's story Dagon. The game is distributed for free, and anyone who is interested in playing it is allowed to make a copy for themselves and their friends.

In Cults of Dagon players control groups groups of 5 cultists traveling around the world to seek the knowledge and tools to summon the sea god Dagon. The tricky part is that too much knowledge may lead them to insanity, reducing their effectiveness for the rest of the game.

Each turn 6 cards are drawn from a deck of artifact cards. Each card represents a type of artifact (book, map, dagger, etc) and has a numerical value between 1 and 6. Players alternate placing their cultists on the cards. They cannot place cultists where they already have a presence, and must outbid by at least one the player with majority on an occupied card.

Once all cultists have been assigned, each card goes to the player with majority. The cards are arranged in sets (books with books, etc), and if the numerical value of a set reaches or exceeds the Insanity Value for that game, a cultist of that player goes insane and is removed from the game. The set that went bust is turned face down.

The game continues until the deck runs out of cards or a player loses 3 cultists. Players score the value of their face up cards. Each face down set is worth the Insanity Value of the game, regardless of card values.
Highest score wins the game.

The game contains two mini expansions: Dark Visions, and Devious Plots.

—description from the publisher

description:

—user summary
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Space Conquest
description:
Object of this game is to conquer as many constellations (groups of stars) as you can. You conquer a constellation when you get your colored discs on more than have the number of stars in the constellation.

Play takes place on a 34" x 22" mat with images of the constellations. Players roll dice to move their pieces around the track on the outside. You either stop on spaces with color\star combinations that allow you to put a marker on a star or stars in a constellation or you land on spaces that allow you to take a card and follow the instructions on the card.

Two other variations of game play include The Game of Polaris (The North Star) in which players start in a different constellation and move towards Polaris. Final variations include a Fast Game Variation which allows you to just conquer stars based on dice throw instead of moving around the track on the game mat.

—user summary

name: Escape
description:
The gameboard is divided into 10x10 squares, representing a castle and surrounded by a moat. Walls between some squares create a Pacman-style maze. Two players, red and blue, race to move their tokens around the maze from the eight start squares of their color to the "ESCAPE" symbol at the drawbridge.

UK Registered Design № 839,010.

name: Leap Frog Globe Game
description:
This is an educational geography game for children that features an inflatable globe. There are three levels of play.

Game One is a simple picture matching activity with race element. Players attempt to match the picture on a card (like a Kangaroo) with a location on the globe (like Australia) as a timer is running. First player to the finish space wins.

Game Two is a race across the board as players attempt to match pictures and locations to a continent card (Asia, Africa, etc.) that was randomly assigned at the beginning of the session.

Game Three adds word cards and requires additional reading skills. This is also a race but it includes a card taking mechanic based on a word search between player's hands.

Designed for 2, 3, or 4 players age 3 or older.

Includes the inflatable globe, a globe stand, tokens, cards, timer, instruction booklet, and board.

name: Pokémon TCG: The Town on No Map Expansion
description:
The Town on No Map - 地図にない町 is a Japanese-language expansion - one of two expansions roughly corresponding to the contemporaneous English-language expansion Aquapolis.

The expansion includes 92 cards.

—user summary
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game

description:
User summary

categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Världsregeringen: Valfläsk
description: This expansion replaces the six original cards that are used during the "Ärendefasen" with new versions that give more strategic options for the players. The expansion also makes it possible for up six players.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Political
mechanics: Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Role Playing, Worker Placement

name: Artillerie vor!
description:
Each player has 13 infantry companies, 2 light batteries and one heavy battery. At the beginning of the game, the pieces are set up on the red, blue and yellow marked spaces. Each turn the players move 2 of their pieces 1 space in any direction. The infantry has a firing range of 1 space, the light batteries of 2 space and the heavy batteries of 2 and 3 spaces. A piece is destroyed if it is in the firing range of 3 enemy pieces. If a piece is at one of the two fortified spaces, it has to be in the firing range of 4 enemy pieces. If a player has less than 4 pieces left, he has lost the game.

—user summary

name: Autobörse
description:
The players move their pawns around the board and buy and sell used and new cars. On some spaces the players win or lose money. After a prearranged time the player with the most money and cars wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Kaedama: A Ramen Story
description:
In Kaedama, you and a partner are new restaurant owners looking to spread the universal joy of ramen. You must manage customers, assemble bowls of ramen, and make enough money to someday buy the restaurant of your dreams.

In this 2 player co-operative game, one player is in charge of the 'Back of House' responsible for prepping and cooking food as well as washing dishes and plating. The other player controls the 'Front of House' by seating customers, upselling drinks & appetizers, and entertaining the guests. Each round, players will roll action dice to determine what actions they can take. However, in order to take an action, it must be paired with a limited pool of speed dice. You'll need to communicate and strategize on how best to use manage your time.

Be quick about it! No one likes a cold bowl of soup!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Worker Placement

name: Interpoly/Kuddelmuddel
description:
Interpoly (2 player)
One player has 16 red pawns (policemen), the other player has 4 yellow pawns (gangsters). Movement is determined by a die. Red may share the die result between two or more pawns. The police tries to enclose the gangsters and the gangsters try to escape to the 4 home spaces in the corners of the game board. On the roll of a 6 red may roll again, yellow may take 1 red pawn off the board. 1 captured policeman counts 1 point, 1 enclosed gangster counts 2 points. After the game, the players switch their roles and after 2 games the player with the most points wins.

Kuddelmuddel (2 or more player)
4 red pawns are placed in the center of the game board, the rest are placed near the board. The destination spaces are marked with the letters A-F. Each player is assigned to one destination space. Movement is determined by a die. Each player may move any pawn. If he gets one on his destination space he keeps that pawn and places a new one in the center space.
The player who gets the most pawns to his destination space wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Darkmace
description:
Darkmace is a 2-4 players miniatures board game about dark ages' wars. You will control one of four armies aiming to conquer the most territory in the battle field. The types of combat units are infantry, archer, cavalry and catapult each having different moving, attacking and defending abilities. You must position them strategically across the battlefield to best coordinate your attacks and to enlarge your land.

Darkmace is played over 13 turns, with each turn consisting of move units, recruit units, construct buildings and manage gold steps. At the end of the last turn, the player that controls the most provinces is declared as the winner.

Darkmace combines miniature gaming and area control styles on one board. You must best position your units individually on hex spaces while taking the control of the provinces as a whole.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Grid Movement, Open Drafting

name: Last Blood
description:
Last Blood is a turn based competitive or cooperative thriller where players explore, fight and run from monsters. The game features exciting events and a very unique computer based art style.

The game is largely based on exploration and encounters with monsters. A very simplistic combat and movement system allows fast play but with complex choices.

Players lose health from combat, starvation and poison. The last player alive wins.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Modular Board, Player Elimination

name: Eight Cards
description:
Eight Cards is a game where 2-4 explorers (players) go on an expedition for 7 days (turns) to try and earn the most reputation (points) and become the most legendary explorer (the winner).

Gameplay is simple to learn and play, but always changing and near impossible to predict. It works like this:

All players have 8 cards. These 8 cards are the same 8 cards as everybody else has in their hands. Each turn the players select a card and once everyone has selected their card, the cards are revealed at the same time and compared. Depending on the number of people who played the card, the outcome changes. Based on the number of players with the same card, positive outcomes can become negative, the target of the card may change and even special actions must be performed.

As the head of your expedition, your role is to figure out when others will play each card, bluff about when you're going to play your cards, and deduct when it's safest to play your cards based on what's been played already.

It's a game of reason, strategy and sometimes just plain luck to figure out how to build the best reputation and win the game.

—description from the publisher
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Exploration, Travel
mechanics: Hand Management, Secret Unit Deployment, Take That

name: Rabbit Trails: The Play on Words Game
description:
What is Rabbit Trails? Rabbit Trails is card game for all ages (especially students!) involving play with word association.

How do you play it? Play starts with each player being dealt 7 cards. Then the top card of the remaining deck is flipped over. Each player takes turns laying a card this is easily associated with the card showing. For example: The card flipped at the start of the game is, "Rabbit". Player 1 plays, "Carrot" (because rabbits eat carrots). Player 2 plays, "Chef" (because chefs can cook carrots). Player 3 plays, "Astronaut" (because both chef and astronaut are professions). And player 4 plays, "Grape". Wait! Grape?? Grape clearly doesn't match with "Astronaut". The other players hear out Player 4's reasoning and vote on whether or not to allow the card to stay in play. They vote for the card to be removed. Player 4 has to draw a new card as a penalty and play continues. The winner is the first person to get rid of all their cards. If a player cannot play (and does not want to try and fool the others by playing a less than perfect card), the player can draw and, if the card will work, play it right away.

But that's not all! There are also action cards featuring various ways to foil the plans of the other players and get you closer to winning the game.

What are the benefits of Rabbit Trails? Benefit #1, Rabbit Trails is an awesome game. Seriously! I have been designing this game over the past couple of years and have been getting bogged down with requests to make this game available from friends, family, and even people who see us playing it while out around town. After refining the cards and getting the rules nailed down, this game is finally ready for prime time! But that isn't all... Benefit #2, is related to education. It's not often that fun and education go together, but Rabbit Trails bridges that gap. Because the aim of the game is to get players to find connections between words, it makes students use higher order thinking, like analysis and evaluation to be successful, which are at the top of Bloom's taxonomy.Benefit #3 [Bonus], Rabbit Trails is great to test your English language skills if you are currently learning English or use English as a second language. It makes English language learners think critically about words and their multiple meanings!

—description from the publisher

name: Pokémon TCG: Starter Pack Expansion
description:
User summary

Starter Pack - スターターパッ is a Japanese-language expansion roughly corresponding to the contemporaneous English-language expansion Generations.

The expansion includes 72 cards.

Unlike regular expansions, Generations booster packs could not be purchased individually from booster boxes. Instead, they were only available in special 20th Anniversary-related items of merchandise, which included Mythical Pokémon Collections and Red & Blue Collections. Each Mythical Pokémon Collection comes packaged with 2 Generations packs, in addition to a special Full Art promotional card and collector's pin featuring 1 of the 11 Mythical Pokémon available as part of the 20th Anniversary distributions during 2016.

The Japanese Starter Pack emulates the original both in terms of design and the random nature of the cards included. While the cards contained in each deck can vary, they are grouped based on evolutionary family and type. The deck can be broken down into two sections, which are packaged separately. The first section will always contain one of two Mega Pokémon, either M Venusaur-EX or M Charizard-EX, in addition to a fixed selection of Pokémon and Energy cards relative to its type, plus multiples of Trainer cards for a total of 27 cards. The second section contains 3 different groups of Pokémon containing an evolutionary family of 1 type, plus 1 other Pokémon of the same type, matching Energy cards, and a selection of single Trainer cards for a total of 33 cards. None of the cards available as part of the pack have rarity symbols. A special Blastoise version of the Starter Pack (Japanese: スターターパック カメックスver.) was later made available, initially exclusive to venues hosting the Kamex Mega Battle in Japan during May 2016, followed by a more general release from the Pokémon Center Online store in June 2016. This version substitutes the Grass or Fire-type cards available in the first section of the regular version with Water-type cards. These cards appear in the core Generations set, but are classed as secret cards in the Starter Pack. The Starter Pack also comes with an exclusive Chansey coin.

-- user summary obtained from: https://leonhartopedia.fandom.com/wiki/Generations_(TCG)
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game

name: Trollz: Magic of the 5 Game
description:
Welcome to the Trollz World! Join the Best Friends for Life as they scoot all around Trollzopolis collecting Gem tokens. But watch out for Snarf--Simon's half dog, half ogre sidekick--or he'll slow down your quest to defeat Simon!

To get around, players roll a die. Pimple Spell spaces and Snarf spaces can limit players' movement but can be gotten around with Obsidian tokens and Obsidian Spell Phone tokens, which can reroll dice or use the spell phone instead of rolling. Other spaces can call every player to a specific space. The Spell Phone included with the game decides what happens when it's landed on or rolled via a text message that appears on the screen.

The objective is to be the first player to collect all 5 Gem tokens and defeat Simon in the final showdown.

Based on the Trollz toyline and cartoon by DiC Entertainment.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Battle of the Numbers
description:
At the beginning of the game, each opponent rolls the general/captain and places him in the captain’s area(Three circles). Then place the tie breaker die(clear with a small blue die inside it) in the tiebreaker area(5 circles) To start out each player rolls 2 of their dice and places them in the first row. Then the player can choose to either keep his/her row and try his/her luck or they can lower a die’s number by one and roll another die. The objective is to have a higher sum for each row than your opponent. The max capacity for each row is five die. At the end of the turn both players add up the die and the larger number is subtracted from the lower number. Next the Difference is taken away from the losing army. If a tie is to occur then the clear die with a blue die in it is rolled by each player and the sum of the two die is added to each player’s side based on the roll. Keep doing this until there is no tie. If you have a one in your row at the end of a turn change the one to a six before you add up. If you end up calculating before changing the one to a six the one stays a one for the remainder of the game. If you lose then you can roll the 20 sided die and re roll the captain. Place the same number of added die to your side of the military and try to beat your opponent.

Things to remember:

If you roll a one with your general, it stays a one
Lower each die one at a time
The game stops after you completely lose all of your die and roll the failure die


—description from the designer

name: Baby
description:
Baby is cooperative deduction micro game for two to three players in which one player facilitates the recurring and semi-random needs of the infant whilst the other one (or two) player(s) take on the role of the parents, attempting to decipher and resolve the cause of their child's cries.

The game consists of three micro decks of five cards each. One deck represents a happy baby, another a sad baby, and the middle a neutral baby. A baby status token moves between the decks, indicating the current climate of the infant and also defining from which deck the next card should be drawn. Cards are only seen by the player playing the role of the child, and upon them are depicted up to two different needs of the five in the game: hungry, poopie, sleepy, restless and crying wolf (ie. nothing's really wrong). Depending on the card the player will then place face-down tokens showing the baby is upset but not visibly indicating what the cause is. These needs can be resolved with different parent tokens, such as feeding, diapers, carrying, music and playing. While the need tokens don't come in multiples and therefore can't "double up" on the same time the parents only have a limited number of each of their tokens so they must use them wisely. After each step of the game (child expressing and then parents attempting to solve it) the baby status is always move to indicate the new state of the child. If a card should be drawn from an empty deck, the game has ended and the players all win if the status of the baby is happy.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Deduction, Humor, Math, Memory

name: Best Allies: Rules for Gaming 18th Century Battles
description:
The 18th century in Europe saw a massive development in weapons and tactics. The musket was refined into a flintlock, smoothbore with a socket bayonet. Although accuracy was low, which limited effective fire to very short ranges, volume of fire improved considerably and units were capable of firing three and sometimes four rounds a minute. The infantryman was now capable of combining the roles of musketeer and pikeman in one. And to maximise firepower, formations became wider. The aim was to move a formation to within range of the enemy and then overwhelm them with firepower. Only rarely was a bayonet charge needed.

—description from the rulebook

Units of 3 bases represent an infantry battalion or cavalry squadron. Suggested basing sizes are given for 6, 15, and 25/28mm figures.

Players take turns activating one brigade at a time. Each brigade commander is rated as Poor, Average, or Excellent, which allows the commander to activate 1-3 groups of brigade units. After all brigades have activated, combat occurs.

The game includes army lists for various 18th century wars: Great Norther War, American Indian Wars, War of Spanish Succession, Wars Against the Turks, Jacobite Risings, Seven Years War, American War of Independence, and the French Revolutionary Wars.
categories: Age of Reason, American Indian Wars, American Revolutionary War, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Turbo Words
description:
Turbo Words is a fast paced word game for 2-4 players.

Players act simultaneously to fill individual playing boards with randomly selected lettered game tiles with the aim of creating as many words as possible.

Other game tiles force players to directly interact with each other adding to the intensity and enjoyment of the game.

The timer can also be started by any player... ensuring that the action is never allowed to slow down!

—description from the publisher

name: Winnetou 2
description:
Game 1: Prärie-Kampf (2 players or 2 teams)
Each player or team starts with 8 pawns on the red and blue outher spaces of their camp area. The goal is to get 4 pawns into the 4 camp area spaces in the corners of the enemy camp. Movement is determined by rolling a die. If a pawn gets on a space with an enemy pawn, the later gets captured. If a pawn reaches a destination space, one friendly captured pawn gets free.

Game 2: Verfolgungsjagd (Pachisi, 2-4 players)
categories: American West, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based
mechanics: Grid Movement, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Jewels: Natale
description:
Promo Card Natale for Jewels

In turn order every player look at the 3 top cards from the resource deck, he chooses one and put the other 2 at the end of the deck.

name: Criminal Masterminds
description:
Have you ever wanted to pull off the grand heists that you see in the movies? Well, here is your chance. Lead a crew to gather items required for the final heist. Partner up with fellow masterminds if you think you can trust them. Complete the final heist and win the loot…and the game!

Criminal Masterminds is a dice rolling game in which two to four players assume the roles of criminal masterminds attempting to pull off grand heists.

The Masterminds need to build a worthy crew who can assist them in acquiring the gear and vehicles required to pull of the final heist. They may team up with other masterminds and their crews to complete jobs or to attempt the final heist. But they always need to keep a close eye out to ensure that they can trust their fellow masterminds.

—description from the publisher

name: SpacePOP Galactic Glam Game
description:
Get ready to turn up the music with the princesses of SpacePOP! Play as Athena, Hera, Rhea, Luna, or Juno as you race around the planets of the Pentangle, collecting all of the items to complete your ensemble before making your way back to the Space Bus.

Players pick one of the five princesses and must land on certain spaces to collect the four pieces of their outfits and single Space Pet. The first player to collect all five pieces and make it back to the Space Bus wins. Activity spaces require players to dance or sing to progress. Landing on Empress Geela's space sends you to her Dungeon of Doom and you must roll a specific number to get free.

This fashionably fun game features unique game play that will get everybody up and grooving, as well as glitter dice and transparent character cards.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Singing

name: Angry Birds: Green Bird Add-On, 3-Pack
description:
It's an Angry Birds Expansion Pack and only playable with Mattel Angry Birds board games.

You can continue the fun of building, launching and destroying with this Angry Birds Add-On pack! It comes with three figures and six special power cards to add new specific functions for each bird, increase difficulty and enhance gameplay.

This set includes these figures: Green Bird, Blue Bird, and Construction Hat Pig.

The Angry Birds game will be set up as usual, except that the new power cards are shuffled in a different pile.
Every player draws a power card at the start of the turn. Every power card is different. Some of them adds a bonus pig to the castle, some other just swaps the first bird to a new one, but even special attacks can be executed.
With Green bird you can shoot again from the place it landed, with Blue bird you can shoot 3 times, etc.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Expansion for Base-game, Video Game Theme

name: Wrasslefest XXVI
description:
WRASSLEFEST XXVI is a wild party game where players get a theme and ten minutes to come up with a pro wrestling persona. The audience then decides who's got the coolest Intro, the best Smack Talk, and the wildest Signature Move. It can be played with just 3 people, though of course you can have as many as you want for total mayhem!

The game comes with rules for standard play, as well as Bonus Modes like Tag Team Tournaments and Legacy Mode.

-description from the designer

name: Starseer
description:
Starseer is a short, quiet, co-operative card game for 2 players.

Conduct the ritual, listen to the stars.

—description from the designer

Play requires 2 players but can accommodate more. The game does not specify age ranges or play times, but the process is fairly abstract (not for very young children).

The game takes place over three turns. During each turn, one player assumes the role of "Eye" and all other players assume the role of "Hand(s)". The "Eye" draws a "Constellation" card which becomes the object of the cooperative game; the "Constellation" is not shown to the "Hand(s)".

Using various hand gestures and playing various "Star" cards, the "Eye" attempts to guide the "Hand(s)" into correctly guessing which "Constellation" card is in play. The game does not allow verbal or written communication. Play is entirely cooperative, if abstract, and proceeds until the "Hand(s)" correctly guess the "Constellation", whereupon play passes to the next player who assumes the role of "Eye". All players win the game after three "Constellations" have been successfully resolved.

—user summary
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Print & Play, Puzzle

name: Battle In: The Dungeon
description:
Memorize your spellbook or strap on your longsword - it's time to Battle In: The Dungeon!

Grab up to three friends (or play solo!), pick a hero and jump into the fray. Enter a room, battle monsters of all types - skeletons, goblins and bears, oh my! (and dozens more) - and leverage your hero's skills to survive. Loot your foes and move on to the next room. If you can make it through seven rooms you're pretty good; if you can make it through ten rooms you can call yourself an epic hero, worthy of bards tales from here until the end of time. But be warned - sometimes the best laid plans fall apart once you set foot in the dungeon.

The mechanics of the game are easy. Flip over a room card which gives you bonuses/penalties/adjustments. Deal out monster cards (the same number as the number of heroes who entered the dungeon). Order them by their Initiative score. Then fight.

Fighting is dead simple - if you can do basic math you can play. Take your hero's attack value, roll a 20-sided die (included) and add them together. Subtract the monster's defense value and if what's left is more than 10 it's a hit. Subtract your hero's damage from the monster's hit points (represented by cubes) then move to the next hero or monster in line. Once you get to the end you start again until either all the heroes or all the monsters are defeated.

But don't let that fool you - this isn't a "beat level 1 monsters, then move to level 2" kind of dungeon. Sure, you might find a lowly kobold in the first room, but you might also find a brown bear. Or a zombie. Or a dragon. Because let's face it - knowing what you're going to find is just plain boring. And there's nothing boring when when there's a Battle In: The Dungeon.

name: Zodiac Attack
description:
Author's description

Two-player arcade dogfighting for your table! Every turn your bullets move in the direction they're fired. Zip around the map, fire your bullets and be the last animal standing.

User summary

The game is played on a large grid play surface with boundary edges. Players alternate turns. During a player's turn they move their token and may fire a projectile (each projectile is fired in one of eight directions). After each player moves and fires, all projectiles move one square in the direction of their invariable travel. Projectiles that move into an occupied square "hit" the object in the square and become expended. Player tokens that are thus hit incur damage. Note that projectiles do not "belong" to one player or another, and it is possible for players to "shoot themselves".

The goal of the game is to remain alive longer than your opponent. The first player destroyed loses; the other player wins.

Anything that "moves off" the right side of the play surface reappears on the left side of the play surface; anything that "moves off" the top of the play surface reappears on the bottom of the play surface, etc., in a mode common to many old video arcade games. Thus, as turns progress the grid becomes increasingly encumbered with projectiles (insuring that impacts occur increasingly frequently).
categories: Fighting, Print & Play, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Action Queue, Grid Movement, Player Elimination

name: Stalingrad
description:
The pivotal battle for the Soviets in WW2. After this battle the Germans would never again go on the offensive on the eastern front. Now you take the generals seat and try to do better than the historical outcome.

—description from the back of the box

Stalingrad is a low priced 2 player strategy board game covering the epic battle between the German and Societ forces in and around the city of Stalingrad during WWII.

On June 22, 1941, Germany and the Axis powers invaded the Soviet Union, quickly advancing deep into Soviet territory. The fighting in 41 culminated in a fierce Soviet counter attack on the outskirts of Moscow, which saved the city. Entering 42 Hitler and his commanders shifted the offensive south towards Stalingrad, breaking through the Soviet lines and threatening to cut off the oil rich Caucuses from the main soviet industrial areas. Stalingrad was the lynch pin to the defense of the Soviet south and the place Stalin had demanded the Russian people make a stand at all costs. The result was the bloodiest battle of WWII.

In Stalingrad the game begins with the German drive on Stalingrad itself. Both players begin the game getting a fixed assortment of troop reinforcements, which later shifts to troop purchases as decided by the players. The battle consists of fighting up to and around Stalingrad and includes the northern Caucasus region, plus fighting inside the city itself on the more detailed city map.

-description from GoB website

Part of the Compact Game Series
SKU GUI8030
Boxed, 4.5" x 5.75" x 1.5" game box

Difficulty Level: Easy

The box contains:
1 10"x15" full color map
1 11"x17" full color map in 2 pieces
1 D10 die
Rules
136 full color die cut units

name: Resort Buggy
description:
One beautiful resort, two to four players all with different agendas but all sharing the love of the ‘Resort Buggy’ ride.
A game of chance, strategy and competition where each player has different criteria to win. Be a resort guest, resort manager, conservationist or developer and take the ‘Resort Buggy’ ride to fun.
Will the resort be saved, become a large tourist development or will it become a world heritage site? You determine!
OBJECT OF THE GAME:
