Race to fulfil the ‘To Win’ requirements for your team. The first player to do so wins the game.
Blue Player- The Resort Guest (RG) team wants to have an amazing holiday and check off all the bucket list of activities during the holiday stay.
Yellow Player- The Resort Manager (RM) team wants to retain the resort as a successful operation by receiving favourable internet blogs, sighting endangered species to attract tourists and ensuring villas are cleaned. (For the 2 and 3 player game variations – Resort Manager also striving to acquire businesses in the resort).
Green Player - The Conservationist (CV) team wants to sight endangered species, lodge a conservation order and obtain sufficient petitions.
Red Player - The Developer (DV) team wants to acquire businesses in the resort, conceal any endangered species sighted, lodge a development application, pay required legal fees and create a blog on the proposed development.

GAME THEME - Resort

GAME MECHANICS - move to relevant areas on board via dice roll, card selection

TO WIN CRITERIA (in detail)
Resort Guest:
- For a 2 player game – stay for a minimum of 2 weeks
- For a 3 & 4 player game – stay for a minimum of 1 week
- Go on a Resort Activity
- Go out for dinner at the Savoury Swan Restaurant
- Have a day spa treatment at Heaven’s Day Spa
- Make a purchase at Gratitude’s Gift Shop
- Make a blog at the Internet Kiosk rating the resort
amenities/laundry
- Sight 1 endangered species twice
- Go on Conservation Eco Walk
- Go on Conservation Canoe
- Go on Conservation Night Adventure Tour
Resort Manager:
- Be at the top of the Resort Manager Counter Path
- Sight 2 endangered species twice
- Place 8 Villa Clean counters on villas. Can only clean
a villa once
- For 2 & 3 player game only – acquire at least 2
businesses (Day Spa, Restaurant, Gift Shop)
Conservationist:
- Sight 3 endangered species twice
- Place 8 Petition counters on villas. Only 1 petition
counter per villa. (additional petitions are to be
collected based on Resort Manager Counter position.
Additional online petitions are obtained via the
Internet Kiosk or by favourable Resort Daily cards.)
- Lodge a Conservation Order in the Internet Kiosk. Fee
10RD$
Developer:
- Be at the top of the Developer Counter Path
- Acquire at least 2 businesses (Day Spa, Restaurant, Gift
Shop)
- Lodge Development Application in Internet Kiosk. Fee
6RD$
- Pay any legal fees as determined by Resort Manager
Counter position
- Make a blog on proposed development at the Internet
Kiosk
categories: Animals, Deduction, Dice, Educational, Environmental, Puzzle
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Fahrt frei zum Grand Prix
description: There is no game board. The racetrack is variable and has to be assembled from several track segments. The movement of the race cars is determined by two dice. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the players. The first plyer to reach the finish line or completes an agreed upon number of laps wins the game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Project ·G·A·M·E·
description:
This game was developed for and given out to participants of the geocaching mega event "Project ·G·A·M·E·" in Bremen(Germany), on May 31st 2009.

The board is printed on DIN A3 photo paper. The rules are similar to "Snakes & Ladders" with some minor twists.

No dice is used. Instead, participants of the event recieved a "geocoin", which also could be used as a dice, with a spinning pointer.
Blue Symbols on the map allow the player to move forward.
Red Symbols on the map send the player backwards.
Green symbols allow the player to decide if s/he wants to go forward or backward.
A cog symbol lets you spin the counter/roll the dice a second time.
A magnet symbol lets you move another players pawn to your position.
Dice symbols lets you press your luck. You shall name a number between 1 and 9 and spin the counter. Depending on the result, you either move forward twice the called number, go back twice the called number or move forward even three-times your selected number.

name: The "Sir Ross Smith" aeroplane race game
description: Roll-and-move race board game based on the air race from England to Australia organised by the Australian government in 1919, and won by Sir Ross and Sir Keith Smith in a converted Vickers Vimy bomber. The board features a map of the world, with a path of spaces form England to Australia, and the usual penalties and bonuses en route.

name: Adorable Monsters: The Super Freaking Awesome Expansion Pack
description:
It's here. The card game expansion you didn't ask for, but are getting anyway. Introducing...

Adorable Monsters, the Super Freaking Awesome 10 Card Expansion Pack!!!

Dum, da da da, dum, da da dummmmm!!!

10 ALL-NEW characters—each with a different power to affect game play in unique ways!

name: Jewels: Cortigiana
description:
New promo card for Jewels.

Every player place one token on the Cortigiana card. Then the owner can sell jewels at the given price.

name: Vero o Falso? Junior
description:
A fun game for the whole family full of unusual anecdotes. Are you ready to play? An exciting challenge awaits you!

The game proceed with a series of questions and challenges on the general culture, sports, arts, comics, movie etc.

The player that will answer the most correct questions will win the game.

name: Achtung Flieger kommen!
description: The pilots start at the red or blue circled spaces in the middle, the planes on the circled spaces (1st and 3rd line) on the left and right side of the game board. The goal of the game is to occupy the enemy airport with the pilot in the middle, surrounded by the planes. Movement is determined by the number die in any direction. If the color die shows the color of the active player, he gets another turn (up to 3 turns in a row). On the roll of a 6 a plane or the pilot has to be moved from ist starting position, if possible. If a figure lands on a space with an enemy figure, the enemy is sent back to a starting space, now including the 2nd line. The figures can't move into their own airport.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Bitcoin the Card Game
description:
MADE IN USA!

78 Cards: Poker size 2.5"X 3.5"

300gsm Linen

Custom Tuck Box

Shrink Wrapped box and cards inside.

If you have ever played the game "PIT," and you have ANY interest whatsoever in cryptocurrency, you will LOVE this game! It is an adaptation of the well known game "Pit," but instead of commodities like wheat, soybeans, corn... it uses the HOTTEST cryptos on the market! Each card has must know facts about the coin itself and the game comes loaded with must know facts before investing. Cryptocurrency is the biggest game changer since the invention of the internet, YET fewer than 1 in 4000 people even own a bitcoin! Whether you are a serious investor or just want to have a fun time, this is the game for you! Get ahead of the curve and have a blast! Become familiar with crypto while playing the funnest game in your closet!

Bitcoin the Card Game is fun for ages 7+ and for 3-8 Players. Multiple decks can be used for larger groups! 78 cards per deck; 8 suits (coins) of 9 identical cards, a hacker card, a miner card, an instruction card, 2 must know bitcoin facts cards, and a future of bitcoin card. Only the coins and the hacker and miner cards are used in game play.

OBJECT:

Be the first crypto trader to score a total of 5000 points. As soon as the dealer yells, "BITCOIN," you become a crypto coin trader trying to "own the marker" of one of the following 8 coins: Bitcoin, Ethereal, Litecoin, Monero, Bitcoin Cash, NEM, Dash, or Coinye West. You "own" that particular coin when you have in your hand all 9 cards of the same coin.

SET UP

1. Select a dealer

2. Prepare a score sheet

3. Use one complete 9 card suit per each player in the game plus the hacker and miner cards. Leave all other cards out of the game.

4. The dealer shuffles the deck and deals out all the cards in play face down. Each player should have 9 and the players with the miner and hacker cards should have 10.

5. Pick up the cards and arrange them by suit. Don't let anyone else see them. Decide which coin you want to own. Hint: pick the coin you have the most of in your hand.

6. When everyone has sorted their cards the dealer says, "Bitcoin" and the trading begins.

PLAY

As soon as the dealer said, "bitcoin!" everyone starts trading. To trade, select 1-4 cards from your hand of the same suit that you do not want to own and say, "one! one!" or "two! two!" depending on how many cards you want to trade. You may trade with any opponent who is calling out the same number. Sometimes a particular opponent will want to trade fewer cards than you do. In this case you can lower your bid and trade the smaller number. you CANNOT look at the cards you are trading for until the trade is complete, NOT can you reveal which cards you are trading. It is a race to see who can collect all 9 the quickest. The first player to call out the coin they have once they own the coin wins the number of points associated with that particular coin. No one else wins any points that round.

WILD CARDS

If someone goes out and you hold the miner and/or hacker cards you lose 200 points per wild card in your hand. If you have 8 cards of a singer coin and the miner card, you may lay down all 9 (8 coins plus the miner card) and shout out "DOUBLE BITCOIN, DOUBLE MONERO! etc..) In his case you win double the points on the card. If you have the hacker card in your hand you may not lay down your cards until you have gotten rid of it. You jay trade both cards together or separately or with another coin but you CANNOT trade more than 4 cards at a time.

COINYE WEST

This coin is worth much less than the other coins but if someone collects all 9 everyone else loses points. Double Coinye means everyone also loses double as well!

WINNING

The game is played several times until a player has a total of 5000 points.

name: ウサギのロストレガシー：聖杯探索 (Usagi no Lost Legacy: Holy Grail)
description:
User summary
ウサギのロストレガシー：聖杯探索 (Usagi no Lost Legacy : Holy Grail) is a card game where Rabbit Knights explore ruins in search of the Lost Legacy: Holy Grail. This game uses the Lost Legacy license.

"It is year 244 of the Rabbit Era on the Island of Britain.
King Uuthur has sent the Rabbit Knights of the Round Table on a quest to find the legendary Holy Grail." (From Chapter 1)

A secret scenario book is revealed as players fulfill the necessary requirements to discover the unknown. As the story moves forward, more rules are added. If the players are able to reveal all of the scenario books, they successfully clear the game. Because the secret scenarios will be disclosed to each player in a different order, you are able to complete a story that is all your own.

There are ten chapters to play through, each taking a few minutes to complete. So a whole game would be under an hour.

Designer's summary
兎歴244年、ブリテン島にて。ウーサー王は円卓の兎達に、伝説の「聖杯」の探索を命じた。（第1章より）

ウサギの騎士たちが遺跡で冒険し、「失われた遺産：聖杯」を探すカードゲームです。 ロストレガシーライセンスを使用しています。
プレイ中に開示条件を満たすことで秘密のシナリオブックが開示され、物語が進むとともにルールが追加されていきます。
すべてのシナリオブックを開示できればゲームクリア。開示する順番はプレイヤーごとに違うため、あなただけの物語が完成します。
categories: Adventure, Animals, Card Game, Fantasy, Medieval

name: The Life You Can Lead
description:
The Life You Can Lead is an effective altruism game with a reincarnation theme and interesting trivia questions and funny action cards. The players start out as humans with incomes randomly chosen from the real-world distribution, although less fortunate players may also reincarnate as chickens and dung beetles. The players collaboratively try to achieve normative good (donating to charities and answering trivia so as to get 1000 human QALYs (quality-adjusted life-years), 10,000 animal QALYs, and 10 x-risk points (x-risk points help prevent human extinction.)) Additionally, players have private moralities that give them alternative ways to win the game, such as moral relativist, sadist, preference utilitarian, nihilist etc.

—description from the designer

name: Reclaim Earth: ReArmed
description:
Reclaim Earth - ReArmed is a medium weight mission based combat game utilizing aged military technology in a future post apocalyptic setting.

Players will use scout vehicles to explore the board and discover military components that will allow the building of warplanes, warships and tanks from the WWII era.

Players will deploy their rediscovered military force to battle opponent unit and structure targets on a large 38 zone game board. Playtime ranges from 60 to 90 minutes.

Reclaim Earth - ReArmed will be the first of a series of games under the Reclaim Earth family and setting.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Dice, Exploration, Modern Warfare, Science Fiction, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Action Queue, Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Rock-Paper-Scissors

name: Pizza PAPA-OPOLY
description:
This is special anniversary version of Monopoly with a Papa John's Pizza theme. Properties include locations like "Asiago Alley" and the traditional Chance Cards are replaced with "Better Pizza" cards. The play money features a photograph of the owner.

The contents are similar to Monopoly with houses, tokens, dice, etc.

name: X-O
description:
X-O is played on a board showing 129 yellow/orange/red squares where numbers between 1 and 25 can be read.

Each player rolls 3 dice to obtain a number or numbers similar to the one(s) on the square where the player wishes to place one or several of his tokens. For example, a player rolls 3/4/6 : a) he may place 3 tokens on squares "3", "4" and "6" ; b) he may place 2 tokens on square "12" (=3x4) and "6" ; c) he may place 1 token on square "18" (=3x4+6). All operations may be used.

When a player places 5 of his tokens in a straight line orthogonally or diagonally, he scores points according to the colour of the squares they are located on : 1 point on a yellow square, 2 points on an orange square, 3 points on a red square.

The game ends when a player runs out of tokens. Each unplayed token is worth 1 point for each player. The player with the maximum score wins.

—user summary

A winner of the 1987 Concours International de Créateurs de Jeux de Société.

name: Shogi: 4 Players
description:
This is a web-published DIY 4 player version of shogi, a game also called Japanese chess.Each player sets up pieces as usual on the 4 back-rows of a shogi-ban (shogi board). In the center are 3 sets of a row of 9 spaces, one each to be shared between each possible pair of players. That shared row acts as a fifth row of a board shared by a given pair of players; only those two given players may nter or cross through the space. As usual orientation of a piece marks ownership. All standard rules of shogi apply.

For a 3 player version, one player's partial board is simply eliminated.

Gameplay is clockwise. To use Western terminology, a player whose "king" is checkmated at the start of their turn-- whether by a single player-s pieces or by a combination of players' pieces-- is eliminated. The "king" is removed from the board" and thereafter that player's turn is skipped. The last remaining player wins.

name: Death's Door
description:
In the future, explorers around the world discover secret staircases within ancient pyramids. At the bottom of the hundred thousand dusty steps are three doors. Anyone who opens a door is never heard from again. Whispered rumors speak of lost treasure, primeval technology, and nightmarish creatures. Powerfully driven adventurers arrive to bravely knock on DEATH’S DOOR.

Each player in DEATH’S DOOR has their own unique ways of gaining points centered around themes like exploring, killing, or looting. You win by completing the objectives described on your Story card and preventing other players from completing theirs. You must combine strategy, tactics, and diplomacy as you place and open dungeons, discover dangers, and gather powerful treasure.

Players start in different parts of the dungeon, and place tiles with a hex grid to create the board. You choose whether to join forces or fight solo. Lairs, with more monsters and a lair boss, are challenging and require multiple party members working together. The Final Boss is very difficult to defeat. The game ends when the Final Boss dies (everyone wins), or when there is one player left alive (highest score wins).

A simple yet dynamic attribute system defines the ability of players and monsters to engage the world. They describe how everyone attacks, defends, and acts. Taken together, they represent the health of the character. As you get bonuses to these attributes, you become more powerful. As you take damage, you become weaker. If all three attributes drop to one, the character is dead.

With only a dozen pages of rules and about two hours of play time, DEATH'S DOOR is designed to deliver RPG depth and lasting replayability that can be still learned and completed in one sitting.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Player Elimination

name: La Planche
description:
La Planche is an abstract press your luck game for 1 to 4 players.
The board is divided in six zones, numbered from 1 to 6.
Each turn, a player roll a six-sided die and put one of his 6 tokens on the corresponding zone of the board, then he choses to continue rolling or to give the die to the player on his left. If the rolled die shows a number corresponding to a zone that already contains a token, the player who rolled the die takes all the tokens that are on the board, except those on zone 1 (tokens in zone 1 are blocked).
The first player who get rid of all his tokens wins the game.

name: Farm Alarm
description: It’s a silly sequencing memory game! Kids learn animal sounds as they repeat them in order of the cards: Cow says Moo, Chicken says Bawk. Remembering who said what last and repeating the sequence of sounds is just half the fun! Three wild cards (parrot, fish, and seal) add to the auditory fun as kids are asked to repeat certain sounds, make silly faces, or clap! Make the wrong noise or action and break the sequence (horse says, "Meow"?!), and the other players can grab the soft pig "squeal" on you! Builds brain power and auditory memory. Farm Alarm Game Silly sequencing memory game Encourages memory skills, communication, sequencing, auditory development Repeat the animal sounds in order Three wild cards (parrot, fish, and seal) mean repeat, make funny faces, or clap Make a wrong noise and other players can "squeal" on you! Pig oinks when squeezed! Includes: 42 cards, soft rubber pig, barn storage box 2 or more players
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Humor, Memory, Party Game

name: War of Warships
description:
War of Warships - is a free card game by Evgeniy Zhuravlevich (Zodi) for 2-6 players. This is a game about warships, all characteristics and photos of ships are real.

Players draw cards and check them to see, which ship won this battle.

I made this game for myself (I wanted a game with warships ^^), and now I'm giving this game to all, who want to play. Just print the files and have fun! ;)

—description from the designer (English)


War of Warships - бесплатная игра Евгения Журавлевича (Зоди) для 2-6 игроков. Это игра о боевых кораблях, все характеристики и фотографии кораблей настоящие.

Игроки тянут карты и сравнивают их, чтоб определить, какой корабль победил в этом сражении.

Я сделал эту игру для себя (я хотел игру с боевыми кораблями ^^), и сейчас предоставляю любому желающему возможность сыграть. Просто распечатайте файлы и развлекайтесь! ;)

—description from the designer (Russian)
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Print & Play

name: Rough Riders!: America's Little Wars of Empire
description:
Rough Riders! is a war game which depicts the battles of San Juan Heights and El Caney, in Cuba, and actions in the Philippines, between the eager, but nearly clueless, Army of the United States, and the highly experienced and far better equipped Armies of Spain, as well as the resultant insurgency of the Moro’s that came with acquisition of the Philippines.

Each Player represents a Commander who controls a number of Battalions, and it is his task to defeat the enemy through maneuver and firepower. Even though an Army may have many Battalions, and far outnumber their enemy, if the soldiers are new to war, discipline, and command, those advantages can quickly evaporate. To achieve victory with such an army, a Commander, by his personal example and with the help of his junior officers, must struggle to keep his confused and isolated men fighting and moving on their objective, or see them fail and die to no purpose.

Completely original, card driven, and exceptionally fast and "clean," no other set of rules on this subject has caught the essential problems of command and control as experienced by all forces engaged.

A special rules section for battles in Mindanao against the Moros are included which allow not only for hidden movement, but random generation of terrain as U.S. Forces advance across country mastered by inhabitants whose fanaticism became legendary.

The 74 page, 8.5" x 11" rules book comes with full color covers, 8 pages of color maps and flags to help identify units in play, as well as the complete Action Deck of cards paper printed in b&w, ready to cut out and use, as well as useful Game Markers which eliminate the need for written records.

Scaled at 1:10 and intended for 15mm or 25/28mm figures.

name: Defense Three Kingdoms: Two-Player Expansion
description:
防衛三国志　2人用 拡張 is a set of additional rules for two people of the game "Defense Three Kingdoms" sold in 2016.

New Card contents
5 character cards, 5 base cards, 5 enemy cards

name: Nukery
description:
The button pushing game of "limited" nuclear conflict for megalomaniacs, optimists and the ecologically retarded from 8-108.
—description from the box

Nukery is a political commentary game from the Cold War era that abstractly depicts the rush to assemble enough nuclear weapons to annihilate all other players. Four fictional "blocs" represent the players' home countries. Players move around regions within their country, collecting "nuke/no nuke" cards as they go. When they are satisfied with their arsenal they may attack, trading the nuke cards to draw Strike cards that may obliterate enemy territories or the attacking player's own territories.

name: Leg dein Leben!
description:
Lay your Life! is a tile laying game for big and small conniseurs of the art of living. In a group or with a partner, here you spin yarns of a life.

Aim of the game is to lay down all your cards, by telling a good story. You'll create the convoluted biographies. After birth, your first steps, primary school you devide to live in the wild together with your friends to make plans to save the earth. It's about juggling with words and inventing stories.

It's the house-game of the Spielkartenfabrik Stralsund, invented here, developt, made and you also can buy it here in our workshop. So if you love telling stories, and want to think outside the box, you'll find with this hand-made deck of cards a completely new board game.

(Translated from the companie's website)

name: Valor & Steel & Flesh
description:
The Valor & Steel & Flesh battle rules allow you to blend the amazing steam and Victorian scientific romance with the soldiers and weapons of historical colonial era warfare and - with a dash of heroics and whimsy - get that curiously delightful blend known as Victorian Science Fiction gaming.

Valor & Steel & Flesh features the wonders of steam technology (colossi, landships, elctro-cannon, Etc.) and the awesome might of otherworldly marvels (flying ships, heat rays, alien creatures, etc.).

While based on the renowned Brother Against Brother system (originally designed by Ivor Janci) from H.G. Walls, Valor & Steel & Flesh does not use a strict historical, or even alternately historical, approach, leaning rather heavily towards the heroic approach so favored by Hollywood in its “historical” productions.

name: Roll Poker
description:
A pocket dice version of poker this game consists of 5 six-sided dice. There are 4 Aces, 4 Kings, 4 Queens, 4 Jacks, 4 10s, 4 9s, 2 Jokers and an extra set of hearts in Ace, King, Queen, and Jack. Total "cards" is 30.

In Roll Poker any number can play. To start, each person puts 10 chips in the kitty. The starting player and everyone following contributes one chip to the kitty. Payoff on each scoring roll is as follows:
Pay Off
Any two pairs - Free Throw
2 Aces and any pair - 2-1
Any 3 of a kind 2-1
3 Aces 6-1
Straight 8-1
Any full house 10-1
Any 4 of a kind 12-1
4 Aces 20-1
Any 5 of a kind 20-1
5 Aces 30-1
Royal Flush 40-1

Any chips remaining at end of game are distributed evenly.

There are also 3 other variations called Royal Flush, Sudden Death, and Total Poker

name: Draft City
description:
Draft City is a drafting and tableau-building game for 3 to 5 players which focuses on combining card abilities to score prestige.

During the game, players have five rounds (or four rounds in a five-player game) to harvest resources, issue commands, store goods and acquire buildings, contracts and workers from a deck of one hundred unique cards featuring different abilities. Each card can be used in several different ways, and there are many strategies to discover. Every card relates to one of five resources, and each resource has two separate themes represented by card abilities. Focusing exclusively on one resource provides the ability to play powerful buildings, while gathering multiple types of resource provides the ability to play a much greater variety of cards and combine their abilities in unexpected ways.

Do you have what it takes to become the new mayor?

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: タンポポ (Dandelion)
description: In タンポポ (Dandelion), you are a lone dandelion growing on a solitary island surrounded by the sea. You must blossom from a seed until you're ready to spread seeds of your own, trying to wrest control of the weather from other players so that you can blow on the wind and reach the promised land — and victory — before anyone else.
publishers: ひとりじゃ、生きられない。(I Cannot Live By Myself)

name: Into The Sea
description:
The amazing creatures that live in the ocean deep are valuable. You know if you can catch them, wealthy marine life enthusiasts will pay major moolah to add them to their collections. Yet, you aren’t the only diver after these beasts of the big blue. Fortunately, you have a gift. The skill to charm and command smaller fish. It is with this talent in mind that you will go... Into the Sea.

How To Play
Separate the cards in to two decks– one light blue, and one dark blue. Deal 2 light blue cards to each player. The player to the dealer's left has first turn.

During a turn, each player shall draw up to 3 cards (the hand limit) from the light blue deck, and play 1 card on the playing surface to create lines of the same colour fish (red, blue, yellow and green). Only 1 line for each colour is permitted at a time, and is shared by all players. When a card is played that increases a line of fish to 5 or more, a "school" is created– attracting a big sea creature. The player who placed the last card to create a school shall draw a card from the dark blue deck, briefly add it to that school for all to see, and finally collect the school, plus the big sea screature, to score the total of the number of points shown on each card.

Shrimp and Butterfly Fish are wild cards. They may join any colour line of fish. However, Butterfly Fish also let a player place a second card during his or her turn. Play continues clockwise.

The player to have scored the most points, once all sea creatures have been captured, wins!

name: Pizza Parlour
description:
A 'snap' style card game with a pizza flavour! A variant on the classic card game snap published by the early learning centre.

Each player takes their turn drawing a card from the top of there deck. When two matching cards are played, the player who shouts 'double topping' and slaps the pile collects the cards, when two matching cards are played separated by a single different card the player who slaps the pile and shouts 'pizza' takes the cards.

The game also contains 6 'take away' card, by shouting 'take away' as soon as this card is played a player gets to collect the cards. It also contains 7 'pizza eater' cards - the player who turns over one of these cards becomes the pizza eater and can take all the cards in the centre pile unless they can be stopped, the next player takes three turns in succession - if they manage to get a 'double topping', 'pizza' or 'take away' the normal rules to claim the pile come back into play.

The winner is the player who takes all the cards.

name: Das Staffelspiel
description: The cards are placed in the middle of the table. The players roll a die and take cards accordingly to the result of their roll. If no card of the rolled number is in the middle of the table, the player steals a corresponding card from another player. The players try to collect 4-card-sets ("Staffeln") as specified in the game rules. For each completed set, the Player gets a specified amout of game tokens from the other players. A Set of one only color or number is called "Hauptstaffelreihe". After the Points für a "Hauptstallelreihe" are awarded, the cards are taken out of the game and can't be stolen by other players. When there are no more cards in the middle of the table, the game ends and the player with the most game tokens is the winner.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Der dunkle Punkt
description: This game claims to be the funniest game in the world. Two players try to move 4 pawns from the base of the board beyond the dark spot between the snake heads. pawns that actually get on the dark spot have to begin anew. Movement is determined b a die. If the roll of the die shows a result that allows a pawn to get on the dark spot, it has to be used for this pawn. The small black dots (crossroads) can be occupied by any number of pawns of the same color. If a pawn gets on a crossroad, that is occupid by one or more pawns of the other color, the other pawns have to go back to the next crossroads behind them. If a pawn has the opportunity to reach a crossroads, it has to do that. The first player to get all 4 pawns off the game board beyond the dark spot wins the game.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Zoid Battle
description: Zoid Battle (actually, Zoid Battle 2) is a set of rules I wrote when the Zoids anime became popular in the US. I wrote them mainly to play Zoid-themed games at local game conventions. The rules are written for hex-based combat (approx. 50m per hex), and not actually intended for use with your full-sized Zoids toys or models - but you can certailny have them with you at the table to act as your mascots!
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Get The Picture
description:
Got it! Spot it! Grab it!

Unleash your creativity... In under a minute you must describe the picture card in your hand for everybody to guess. Mime, Pose or use 3 Words to get them all thinking. Comparing your description to a host of possible cards on the table, it's a frantic race to first spot and then to grab the right picture.

name: Crazy Celebrity
description:
A wildly uproarious storytelling game that’s sure to be
a hit at any party. You and your friends will spin tales that
take such bizarre and unexpected turns that you’ll be
rolling on the floor with laughter!

name: Crazy Professor
description:
A wildly uproarious storytelling game that’s sure to be
a hit at any party. You and your friends will spin tales that
take such bizarre and unexpected turns that you’ll be
rolling on the floor with laughter!

name: One Direction The Game
description:
Will you be the first to complete your game card and make it backstage? One Direction: The Game is a themed game for 2-4 players in which you answer questions, take challenges or complete actions in order to collect tokens. Each token represents an item of One Direction memorabilia. The object of the game is to be the first player to fill your game card with autographs, collectables and concert items. Only the winner receives the backstage VIP pass necessary to complete their game card.

Players take it in turns to pick up cards that bring them closer to collecting tokens. Do You Know? cards require the player to answer a question about One Direction to receive a token. Action Cards for example may cause the player to miss a turn or trade tokens with another player. Will You Dare? cards are family-friendly challenges such as "Do the chicken dance for 20 seconds" or "Sing happy birthday in a way that would get Harry's attention".

name: Treecolo
description:
Memorise and find the hidden fruits and vegetables corresponding to spring, summer, autumn and winter. Be the smartest to complete your season first, but watch out for the wind and the lumberjack !

A game which allows children to practice their memory and observation skills.

name: Resilience
description:
Overview and Theme: In Resilience, you will lead your armies to capture lands for your chosen banner, trade resources with your neighbors, negotiate terms with your allies and your enemies, build mighty strongholds and battle those who stand in your way! You will choose the actions for each of your armies that will in turn, change the shape of the land and the outcome of the game.

Goal: The game of Resilience is played with 2 to 4 players, each attempting to be the first to build a level 4 stronghold and become the winner of the game. The levels of a stronghold are as follows: 1-Keep 2-Wall 3-Moat 4-Victory

The Game Board: The game is played on square land tiles that are laid down between the player's war camps. The land tiles are one of three types, Desert, Plains or Forest, each having a different land value associated with them. The more land value a player controls, the higher they can build their stronghold to win the game.

Some of the land tiles have mountains that limit where a player's commander can move to and may be rotated by the players to alter the game board, benefiting or hindering a player's strategy.

Game-Play: Each player has 3 commanders that they use to move around the game board and interact with the land tiles. On each player's turn, they may use each commander once to claim land tiles, use special abilities or battle opponent commanders.

Battle: Each commander has an army that is made up of 1 to 3 army cards. Army cards may be; Infantry, Archer, Cavalry or a Diplomat. In a Rock-Paper-Scissor fashion each player reveals cards, one at a time, from the commander army to battle: Infantry beats Cavalry, Cavalry beats Archer, Archer beats Infantry. The diplomat serves as the wild-card; when used in battle, both players are forced to roll a 6-sided die to determine the victor of that particular fight.

Trading: Players may trade away land tiles they control to other willing players, and in return, they re-collect army cards that have been discarded or resurrect fallen commanders.

Fun fact: No player can truly be eliminated. Even if a player looses all of their commanders and land tiles, they can always accept trade from other players, bringing them back into the game.
categories: Exploration, Medieval, Negotiation, Puzzle, Territory Building, Wargame
mechanics: Area Movement, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Hexagon Grid, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Take That, Tile Placement, Trading, Variable Player Powers

name: Pirates Chase Game
description:
Pirates Chase Game is a simple spin-and-move game for 2 players. One player plays the part of the Pirates (who controls 3 ships) and the other player is the Cargo Ship Captain (who controls 1 ship). The object of the game is for the Pirate player to land exactly on the same space as the Cargo Ship with on of his ships, thus winning the game for the pirates. If the Cargo Ship is able to make it once around the board without being sunk, then the Cargo Ship Captain player wins the game.

—user summary

name: Star Command: The Board Game
description:
The object of the game is to secure the bases of the star with your missiles and defense shields. A base is secured when you land your missile on a base and when you play your defensive shield on the spot in front of it. The game is won when a player secures three bases.

Essentially, Star Command: The Board Game is a roll-and-move game where each player is trying to move to the bases before the other player. A couple of rules allow players to attempt knocking out their opponents' missiles and secured bases as well.

—user summary

name: Swordpoint: Chariot Armies
description:
Army list book containing 34 armies with additional variants, covering the period from 3000 BC to 700 BC. Army lists include:

Sumerian and Akkadian
Old and Middle Kingdom Egyptian
Elam
Minoan & Early Mycenaean
Libyan
Nubian
Harappan Indian
Arab Nomad
Early Assyrian
Early Babylonian
Shang Chinese
Early Eastern Tribes
Old Hittite Kingdom
Hyksos
European Bronze Age
Mitanni
Syrian and Canaanite
Aryan Indian
New Kingdom Egyptian
Hittite Empire
Middle Assyrian
Sea Peoples
Trojan War
Philistine
Dark Age Greece
Israelite
Zhou Chinese
Libyan Egyptian
Cimmerian and Scythian
Urartian
Kushite Egyptian
Later Babylonian
Neo-Assyrian
Saite Egyptian
categories: Ancient, Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Evrwyn: The Blight of Tarvana
description:
Evrwyn is a high fantasy role-playing tabletop card game that takes you on an epic journey to find Tarvana and end her blight. Traverse the Valencian Empire, scouring through forgotten dungeons, busy settlements, and treacherous terrain. Choose between many unique races, classes, and professions to navigate this volatile realm. Evrwyn’s gameplay combines storytelling, group strategy, unforeseen opportunities, character customization, and survival. Because of Evrwyn’s many random features, each gaming experience will be unique. Encounter a plethora of travel and dungeon events that test even the most seasoned players. Taking chances, pursuing riches, and rolling the dice can lead to powerful discoveries or your ultimate demise. Evrwyn will test your group’s strengths and expose its weaknesses. Your allies may not always have your best interest in mind.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Events, Open Drafting, Push Your Luck, Role Playing, Storytelling, Team-Based Game, Trading

name: Blobbiemundo: Mazo Rojo
description:
The Red Deck contains shapes of higher Attack values in average.
Each Introductory Sructure contains 50 Cards (1 Refractive), 15 Vitality Counters, 1 Environment Counter, 1 Playmat, and 1 Rulebook.

name: Blobbiemundo: Mazo Anaranjado
description:
The Orange Deck contains shapes of higher Speed values in average.
Each Introductory Sructure contains 50 Cards (1 Refractive), 15 Vitality Counters, 1 Environment Counter, 1 Playmat, and 1 Rulebook.

name: Blobbiemundo: Mazo Amarillo
description:
The Yellow Deck contains shapes of higher Confusion values in average.
Each Introductory Sructure contains 50 Cards (1 Refractive), 15 Vitality Counters, 1 Environment Counter, 1 Playmat, and 1 Rulebook.

name: Blobbiemundo: Mazo Verde
description:
The Green Deck contains shapes of higher Defense values in average.
Each Introductory Structure contains 50 Cards (1 Refractive), 15 Vitality Counters, 1 Environment Counter, 1 Playmat, and 1 Rulebook.

name: Blobbiemundo: Mazo Azul
description:
The Blue Deck contains shapes of higher Perception values in average.
Each Introductory Sructure contains 50 Cards (1 Refractive), 15 Vitality Counters, 1 Environment Counter, 1 Playmat, and 1 Rulebook.

name: Blobbiemundo: Mazo Índigo
description:
The Indigo Deck contains shapes of higher Camouflage values in average.
Each Introductory Sructure contains 50 Cards (1 Refractive), 15 Vitality Counters, 1 Environment Counter, 1 Playmat, and 1 Rulebook.

name: Blobbiemundo: Mazo Violeta
description:
The Violet Deck contains shapes of higher Weaponry values in average.
Each Introductory Sructure contains 50 Cards (1 Refractive), 15 Vitality Counters, 1 Environment Counter, 1 Playmat, and 1 Rulebook.

name: North & South
description:
North & South brings you to the future, to a place where two armies troop together at each other's border, ready to enter into the inevitable confrontation.
As the commanding officer of the northern troops, you try to determine the positions and the strength of the enemy elite troops by means of some daring moves.
The opponent from the South tries to do the same and the consequences soon make themselves felt. Skirmishes in the air and on land quickly lead to true trials of strength in which now the North and then the South is winning.
Luck only plays a minor part and the better strategist will win increasingly more battles. Only recklessness or a surprise counteroffensive can still stop him from winning the war.

—user summary

name: The U.S. Army Game
description:
This is a WWI trick-taking card game. The 53-card deck is divided into four suits by service: Infantry (blue), Cavalry (yellow), Artillery (red) and Engineers (green). Each card has a detailed illustration of an individual of each rank in dress uniform, and a colored border that includes the value of the card, branch of service, symbol of service, rank and rank symbol.

Each suit is numbered from 1 to 12 in ascending order of rank: Private (1), Corporal, Sergeant, 2nd Lieutenant, 1st Lieutenant, Captain, Major, Lieutenant Colonel, Colonel, Brigadier General, Major General, and General (12).

In addition, there are four black (unsuited) cards illustrating military technology: Machine-Gun (5), Armored Motor-car (10), Air-Ship (15) and Tank (20), as well as a President and Commander-in-Chief card.

name: L'Histoire Romaine
description:
This is one of a series of four card games published in the 1700s in France known collectively as the "Cartes Historiques". While the box is not dated, Hargrave's History dates the deck to 1760.

L'Histoire Romaine has a deck of 48 cards, numbered with Roman numerals, plus a card with rules of the game. The cards are printed on thick stock from wood blocks, with square corners and blank backs. At the top of each card is the name of an historical character and a circled portrait. Below the portrait, and taking up most of the card, is a biography of the individual. The box shows E. Jouy as the author of the biographies.

The game seems to have been educational in nature, with the player drawing a card announcing its name, and the other player(s) having to come up with one or more relevant facts from the biography. Correct answers win the card, with the winner being the player who collects the most cards.

name: The Dewey Game
description:
This is a word game similar to Anagrams, but with the specific objective of forming the last names of 14 admirals who served in the U.S. Navy during or prior to the Spanish-American War. The game is named after Admiral of the Navy George Dewey, and seems to have been published to cash in on the glory of then Commodore Dewey's victory over the Spanish fleet at Manila Bay.

The names run in value from Admiral Albert S. Barker (10 points) to Admiral Dewey (100 points). The game contains 77 plain square letter tiles, one for each of the letters in the names on the list of admirals.

Players initially draw a hand of 10 tiles, and attempt to form, in whole or in part, names from the list. On each turn, a player draws a tile from the face-down stack, and if possible adds it to one of his names in progress. Instead of drawing from the stack, a player may steal a face-up tile from another player needed for one of his own names, provided that his own partial name is closer to completion than his opponent's. Letters may not be stolen from completed names. Completing a name grants an additional tile draw.

When the draw pile runs out, players may continue to steal, and the game ends when no further plays are possible. The winner is the player who completes the highest point-value worth of names.
publishers: The Dewey Game and Novelty Co.

name: Le diable du pont de Valentré
description:
Le diable du pont de Valentré (literally "The devil from Valentré's bridge") is a card game for 2 to 6 players inspired by a French tale and a comic book drawn by the game author. Each player plays the architect in charge of building Valentré's bridge, but as the legend says, the devil comes at night to steal stones from the bridge.

This is a classic card game where at his turn, each player draws a card and then can either get the resources necessary to build the bridge (so-called "key" cards), protect his keys ("shield" cards), attack an opponent ("claws" cards), build his bridge or discard.

The game ends after the first player builds the bridge.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Fantasy, Medieval
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Pattern Building, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Set Collection

name: Taï-Hou
description:
A game related to Chinese Chess and Dou Shou Qi, played on an 11×12 board. Each player has eleven pieces numbered "1 Nightingale" through "10 Arrow", plus "Lotus Flower".

According to Cazaux and Knowlton's book "A World of Chess" (2017), this game was discovered on an online auction site in France in 2016.

name: Dong Wu Qi
description:
A game produced in the 1950s, comparable to but significantly different from the game with the same name Dong Wu Qi that's more widely known today. The name just means "Animal Chess" or "Animals Game".

It's a chess-style game played on a 9x13 board, with each player having 16 different animal pieces. The animals are grouped into four different categories with four different movement rules (domestic animals, wild animals, insects and birds): within each group, weaker animals may not capture stronger animals. Each player's Lion piece, the most powerful of the wild animals, is confined to the mountain area at the end of the board, and the object of the game is to capture the opponent's Lion.

This game is described in Cazaux and Knowlton "A World of Chess" (2017) as having been discovered in an online auction in China.

name: Shattered Nations
description:
Shattered Nations is a strategic game where you pit an army of your own design against an opponent’s army. Choose your actions and moves carefully, even one misstep can change the tide of battle and turn victory into defeat.

The goal of the game is to destroy all of your opponents commanders before they destroy yours.

Players will build an “Army” based off an agreed upon point army point value, deploy their army onto the battlefield, and attempt to destroy their enemy’s commanders.

The battlefield is a simple yet devastating beast. Broken down into three separate zones, each zone provides a specific function to a player.

Command Line – The command line is the key to victory. This is where the army commanders start the game. Only commanders and heroes can be here.

Deployment Line – The Deployment line is how you get new troops onto the battlefield. You play cards from your hand into this location.

Front Line – The Front Line is where the action happens. Units must be on the front-line to attack the enemy.

To move your soldiers around and attack you will need to issue commands via action cards. Each turn players will only be able to perform three actions. There are 5 types of actions they can take. Each round players will pre-select their actions. This is critical because it locks you into those actions for that round. Not choosing wisely may result in you not being able to use all the actions allotted to you.

Attack Action: used for a unit in the Front-Line to attack the most forward unit in the opposing Command Line. Attacking with a unit “exhausts” the unit. (see combat section more details on attacking and killing units).

Deploy Action: used to move a unit from your hand to the deployment zone of an active Command Line. Deploying a unit “exhausts” the unit.

Advance Action: used to advance any unit forward in the same command line. Advancing a unit “exhausts” the unit.

Event Action: used to play an event card from your hand.

Ability Action: used to activate a unit’s ability. Using a unit’s ability “exhausts” the unit.

Combining these actions and clever use of the battlefield will assure you a victory. Be careful though, it is of paramount importance to interpret your opponent’s battlefield and predict what actions they will be using.

Assemble your army, deploy your troops, destroy your enemies commanders!
mechanics: Action Queue, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Byggare Bob: Ett jobb för Byggare Bob
description:
It´s an snake and ladder kind of boardgame.
The object of the game is to navigate one's game piece, according to die rolls, from the start (bottom square) to the finish (top square), helped or hindered by Bob the Builder. You can get a green light and go forward two steps. There is a square that tells you that you have forgotten your builderhelmet, so you have to go back three steps. There can be workers on the road that make you skip you turn. There are several ( I think 7) different types of squares that you can end up on, that makse you go forward och backwards. First up wins the game.

name: A Game of Legacy
description:
Kickstarter game designed by Bernie DeKoven and Tassos Stevens, exploring the nature of legacy and "evoking what it means to pass something on to someone else", created following de Koven's terminal cancer diagnosis in 2017.

The game arrives in a sealed box, with instructions not to open it until the players are ready to play. The game states that it requires a box of matches or a lighter, and a device with internet access.

name: Antsy!
description:
A Fast-paced fun game to get rid of "those ants in the pants."

Each player is assigned a pair of pants on the game board. They are also given 10 ants to put in their pants. The players then move around the board and are given activities which help get rid of the ants.

The first player to "get rid of" their ants wins the game. The game plays fast and children want to play Antsy time after time.

name: Mixed Signals: The Circuit Board Game
description:
Mixed Signals: The Circuit Board Game is a game in which two players compete for the domination of a circuit board.

The players play as low and high voltage (or zeroes and ones if you prefer) and take turns placing triangular circuit tiles on the board. This in an effort to cause favorable voltage transitions in the circuit.

The goal for each player is to place all of their voltage tokens on the board by getting a majority of the circuit to carry their voltage. This is not as easy as it might sound since your opponent can and will hijack your sections of the circuit!

The game starts out with only two input tiles, one carrying a low voltage and one carrying a high voltage. Throughout the game, you will find signal mixing tiles and even new input tiles that make the game increasingly challenging, complex and fun!
mechanics: Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Tile Placement

name: CompoundIt!
description:
CompoundIt! is a word game in which the “letters” are chemical elements and the “words” are compounds. The rules of the game strive to balance entertainment and playability, scientific accuracy, and educational value. The target audience includes students, science enthusiasts, nerds, and word game fans interested in learning an entirely new “language”. The style of play is familiar to those who have played other crossword-style board games, and the rules for compound formation come from chemistry itself.

Players make moves using a hand of ten tiles. Each tile is an element from the periodic table, although not every element is represented--only those found in relatively common compounds. A valid move creates a neutral compound with balanced charges. Compounds may be either binary (like carbon dioxide, methane, water, or ammonia) or involve polyatomic ions (sulfate, nitrate, hydroxide, etc.) Subsequent turns build new compounds using both new tiles and tiles already on the board. Players score points based on the point value of each tile (some elements are worth more than others), whether they are utilized in one direction or both horizontally and vertically, and whether they are played on special bonus squares. The game ends when one player runs out of tiles following the exhaustion of the general supply; at this time, the player with the most points wins.

name: SheepDice: The Adventure
description:
The sheep are restless… they want to go on an adventure!

SheepDice: The Adventure is a dice rolling game where the sheep are the dice. The flock of 21 sheep travel from one tile to the next until they make it back home… or not! Be a shepherd and help guide the sheep along, or be a wolf and catch them. The team with the most sheep wins!

The shepherd picks a sheep to roll, and based on the result, all matching sheep will move forward. The wolf rolls a group of sheep and catches one, but only if the wolf guesses a sheep type that ends up being alone. The tiles are double-sided and can be rearranged so you can have a different adventure every time.

Can be played in teams, cooperatively, or solo.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Simulation

name: 1 mal mußte: 3 mal kannste
description:
Each player gets 6 sticks. The goal is to get rid of all 6 sticks. Each turn the players have the choice to roll 1 to 3 times. The players place a stick on the space with the number they rolled.
If the space contains a stick, the player has to take this stick instead of getting rid of one.

An exception is space 6. Every time a 6 is rolled, the player places a stick on space 6 regardless of the number of sticks already there.

The first player who hasn't any sticks left wins the game.

name: Ein Tag mit Romika
description: The players have to get from space 1 to space 60. Movement is determined by a die. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the players. The first player to reach space 60 wins the game.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Urban Heat
description: Urban Heat is a simple, press-your-luck auto racing game for 1 to 6 players. Requiring one stop on each curve, players must choose between going a safe minimum speed of three spaces or add a D6 roll to the minimum and risk a wreck. The track is randomly generated and hidden in a draw pile, only revealed when the lead car advances from the known course. The player whose car first crosses the finish line wins.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Push Your Luck, Roll / Spin and Move, Tile Placement

name: BOSS: Das verruckte Romme
description:
This is a Rummy based game with several special features.

The game consists of 2 sets of cards valued 1 to 10 in each of four colours plus 24 "special" cards. The objective of the game is to get rid of all your cards by creating runs and/or sets ("sets" means either from now on) of at least 3 cards and playing them in front of other players so becoming penalty points that count against those players.

There are several sorts of Joker that may be used to make up the 3+ cards sets. "Double" and "Triple Jokers" double and triple the value of the sets they are in.

There are 8 "Pass the set" cards that enable a player to pass any one set in front of them on to another player with the exception of sets containing a "Super Joker".

There are 4 "Take it Back" cards that can be used to immediately counter the "Take it Back" cards.

A deal finishes when any one player succeeds in reducing their hand to zero cards. All players score and record the value of the cards in front of them and in their hand. A game consists of 5 deals, the winner being the player with least penalty points.

name: Can you hear me
description:
Read facial expression of characters, do they match with the story? Sometimes, it is not so easy to tell the delicate differences of emotions and sympathy.

“Can you hear me?” is an emotional training game that is developed to exercise social coping skills by empathizing with other people’s feelings.

Facial expression is an important element of reading emotions, and it is also a clue of mutual interaction that establishes the relationships with other people. Therefore, this game is designed to train general emotional system according to situations through storytelling, and to enhance the ability to build a social relation network.

It provides a training process to read emotions from character’s (four members of a family) facial expressions that fit the theme

[Winning the game]
The player who collects most of the tokens by reading emotions well wins the game. Each player should listen well to other players’ situation explanation, then look for the appropriate facial expression on the Emotion tiles that fits the story and place a token on that tile. It is not about one’s own feelings, but listening to other people's emotions and sympathizing and finding their faces on Emotion tiles accurately is what determines the victory.

name: Danny Dux Space Race
description:
Danny Dux has a fleet of spaceships in orbit around Mercury and wants to race them to Pluto.
The game is a simple spin and move. With players traversing the solar system landing on each planet. They must spin a particular number to escape its velocity to proceed towards the next planet. A number of hazards can be encountered along the way, resulting in a lost turn or returning to a previous planet. First to arrive at Pluto by exact spin is the winner.

Produced as a promotional game by the Dux Stationary products,Tickle industries, Australia in 1958.

name: Environmental Rescue Game
description: Environmental themed roll-and-move game. Collect points as you move along the board, highest total at the end wins.

name: Ta-Ku
description:
Ta(ble) Ku(bb) is a table version of the outdoor game Kubb also known as Viking Chess. Ta-Ku is played with dice and small wooden blocks.

Whilst in the traditional Kubb you score by knocking down the wooden blocks of your opponent and finally the "king", in Ta-Ku you throw, roll or flip dice at small wooden blocks. You win the game by counting the values of the dice which successfully knocked down an opponent's block AND stayed within the borders of the field.

The game is played over three matches, the team or player with the highest score in the end wins.

—description from the designer

name: Die Mond Rakete
description:
A simple roll and move game where players travel race from the earth to the moon.
Players choose their course by the roll of the dice, with 1 and 2 travelling along a black path, 5 and 6 along a red path and 3 and 4 along a yellow path. Along the way various challenges are encountered such as faulty air supply in the rocket or not enough acceleration to leave earth and penalties are applied.
Players pass through the constellations on route to the moon and landing on certain numbers assists or hinders the players progress.
Landing on the moon is accomplished by throwing a 6 on the dice. First to land on the moon is the winner.
The game was published by the Fritz Homann A.G company of Germany who produced a few board games to promote their Fri-Ho-Di margarine brand.

name: Magorum
description:
Magorum is an exciting, fast-paced customizable fantasy card game where players take the roles of powerful Mages that do battle by casting incredible spells, perform enchantments, conjure up magical items, and even call forth powerful incantations. The big difference is that in Magorum the player doesn’t control any units such as monsters or robots or fighters. Instead, YOU are the center of the battle and you use YOUR power to perform amazing feats of magic and destruction in order to defeat the opponent. The only permanent cards on the field are the magical items that empower the player. In this fast-paced magical warfare, players have to use wit and strategy to overpower their opponent.

The main box set consists of 200 different cards which are divided into 5 different schools of magic: Ignogan (Fire), Aqualibrium (Water), Winderis (Air), Terrakov (Earth) and Gromnik (Electricity). Players can mix and match cards from different schools to create their ideal deck.

The players mix and match cards from each school to create a deck of 57 cards, and a side-deck of up to 7 cards. The players then take turns placing cards in the manapool and using the mana they've accumulated to cast spells and deal damage. Each point of damage equals 1 card discarded from the top of the opponent's deck.

The goal of the game is to deal enough damage to the opponent to discard all of the cards from their deck, thus winning the duel!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Hand Management, Player Elimination, Take That

name: Tossed Together
description:
Tossed Together is a fun, high energy, word guessing party game.

Players work together as a team to give a clue to their teammate for a word that is on a card they've drawn. The catch is, teammates can only say one word of the clue at a time!


The first guesser draws a card and holds it so the other players can see the card, but the card’s information is hidden from the guesser.
Starting with the player to the left of the guesser, the other players on this team give a clue to the guesser “One Word At A Time”
If the players giving the clue break any clue rules, the team loses one point and a new card is drawn.
When any clue giving player feels the clue is complete, they ring the bell. Once the bell is rung, the guesser makes one guess trying to correctly identify what’s written on the card.
The card is scored: A correct guess is worth one point. An incorrect guess is not worth any points.
The player to the left of the guesser becomes the new guesser and play continues.
When time runs out, continue the clue for the current card. After the guess is made, the round ends.


The team with the most points at the end of the game wins!

—description from the publisher

name: Thomas the Tank Engine Action Game
description: Move passengers from the waiting room to a station. Use your train to pick up your colour, then move to the next station. First player to pickup all their passengers win.

name: Flying Saucer Spelling Game
description:
The game consists of an outer circular board that has a rotating inner circle. The inner circle has some sci fi graphics and along its edges it has the alphabet and letter blends. Rotating the inner circle helps players makes words using the outer circular board.
The starting player turns the outer circle 5 combinations to randomly select a letter combination (i.e eep). the player then uses the inner circle of letters and blends to try and make as many words possible (i.e Keep or sheep). For each correct letter- sound combination players receive 5 points. Penalties of 10 points apply for any omitted words or incorrect words.
Players take turns until 5 sound combinations are completed. The player with the most points is the winner.
The game is really to help children learn to read and spell.

—user summary

name: Journey through Space Game
description: Simple roll and move game travelling from earth to an inhabited star. Spaces are marked 1 to 100 with specialized spaces to help in the journey and others to penalize the players. First to reach the inhabited star is the winner.

name: Bingo Dice
description:
There are 3 dice with 18 symbols and 3x3 bingo sheets.
Roll all dice and place the tokens on the matching symbols.
Who get all 9 symbols on his/her sheet is the winner.

name: CXG-027 Computer Naval Battle Game
description: This is an electronic battleship game. Object is for one player to destroy all opponent's ships.

name: EtheoryEm
description: EtheoryEm is a music theory and worker placement game in which players take control of musicians attempting to earn a seat in the prestigious Ethereum Orchestra. Each turn, players choose to perform one of several actions, such as Practice (placing, rolling and shifting notes on the chromatic scale), Audition (attempting to secure a chair in the orchestra by completing objective chords and scales using those notes), Tenure (solidifying their seat in the orchestra and improving their influence within it) and Performance (randomly determined action points where the musicians must perform masterpieces to prove their skill and keep their positions). As the orchestra is ultimately filled, players tally victory points to determine the winner based on the chords & scales successfully completed, their musician presence and location within the orchestra, as well as additional hidden objectives.

name: Snow Day: A Snowman-Building Card Game
description:
Players compete to be the first to build a snowman in this fun and thematic card game. Be the first to build all three pieces of your snowman and collect all 7 item cards to win!

—description from the publisher

name: Lu Jun Qi Zodiac Game
description:
This set sold as 陸軍棋‧十二生肖棋 is supplied with 50 paper army tokens for playing a variant of Lu Jun Qi, and 50 paper animal tokens for playing a game similar to Dou Shou Qi. The board is not the same as the usual board for either game: it's 7x10 with a central river, and with all four corners missing.

The army pieces are numbered in Chinese numerals, and each side has one each of 1, 2, two each of 3, 4, 5, 6, three each of 7, 8, 9, plus three mines, two rockets and one flag.

The animal pieces are numbered in Western numerals in Chinese Zodiac order, and each side has two each of Rat (1) through Pig (12), plus three bullets.

name: Purple People Eater
description:
The ELECTRICALLY frightening 'feely' monster game of skill. For 2-4 players, 6 years and upwards.

Purple People Eater - is asleep. Can you save the people from his horrible clutches? If you wake him up you will hear him growl as his eye lights up in anger. Caught in his clutches you will feel his tentacles quiver on your hand. Will you be able to rescue the people through his gaping jaw? Take care, because if you wake him he will get very angry!!

Inspired by the song of the same name, players attempt to remove people from the monster's clutches without setting off an alarm.

—description from the publisher

name: Build Up
description:
Build Up is a domino game played with two sets of double six dominos. Players take turns building stacks of dominos, scoring points at the end of each hand. The winner is the player with the most points after three hands.

—description from the designer

name: Junior-5er-Pasch
description:
Try your dice rolling luck in Junior-5er-Pasch, with the hope of either rolling as many of the same animals — or as many different animals — as possible. Whoever has the most Xs on their game sheet wins.

In more detail, on a turn you roll all of the dice, then you may reroll as many dice as you want up to two more times. After your third roll (or if you stop earlier), choose either one of the animals or the rainbow on your score sheet and cross it off. If you choose an animal, count how many animals of this type are on the dice, then X this many spaces on your score sheet; if you choose the rainbow, count how many different animals are on the dice, then X this many spaces. After seven rounds, the game ends.

name: Labyrinth
description: The players have to get one or two pawns from the black starting space through the maze to the yellow destination space. Movement is determined by a die. If the move of a meeple ends on a space with an arrow, the arrow determines the direction of movement for the next turn. Pawns are not allowed to turn around.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Battle of Wits: Poisoner's Dilemma
description:
Poisoner's Dilemma is a quick micro-game containing only four cards. The cards come in a custom printed sleeve that holds the whole game.
The game is inspired by the scene in "The Princess Bride" where Vizzini and Westley face off in a Battle of Wits.
Westley serves two goblets of wine for the two to drink. But one goblet is tainted with poison! Which one???
“It ends when you decide and we drink
and find out who is right and who is dead.” -Westley

The game consists of three cards: two wine cards and one poison card.

Entire Rules of Play

Each person starts with 3 life.
The first person to zero life is dead.

Choose one person to be the Dealer and the other to be the Player.

Round Description:
1. The Dealer chooses one card to remove from
the game for the round.
2. The Dealer serves one face-down card to the Player
and one to themselves.
3. The Player chooses whether to drink the from card in front of themselves or from the card in front of the Dealer.
The Dealer drinks from the other card.

a. If the poison card is in the game, whoever drinks it loses 1 life.
b. If the poison card is not in the game and the Player chooses their own card, no one loses a life.
c. If the poison card is not in the game and the Player chooses the card in front of the Dealer, it is a grave insult to the Dealer’s integrity, and the Dealer punches the Player. The Player loses a life.

Switch the role of Player and Dealer for the next round.

name: Revolt
description:
Revolt is a two-player space combat game set in the inner solar system; the map's outer edge is the orbit of Jupiter. One player represents a solar system government and the other player a rebellion against it.

Each side has a fleet of ships and a number of bases. Ship counters can represent any number of ships so each player knows where the other has forces but not how strong they are. The ships use vector movement; they can accelerate or decelerate a certain amount each turn and also change heading a certain amount (in 5-degree increments); their movement vectors are drawn on the board.

Combat is deterministic; the attacker's strength is divided by the distance between the attacker and defender to determine the number of strength points lost.

The sun's gravitational effects are taken into account for ship movement, but those of the planets are not. The planets and space stations move along their orbits during the game.

The objective of the government player is to eliminate all rebel ships and bases; the rebel player wins if they can avoid this for 30 turns.

The basic rules for the game were published in four issues of International Wargamer beginning with the December 1970 issue. The game was also available from the designers; this version included additional tournament rules and presumably also contained the map and counters, as they did not appear in the magazine.

name: 20 Clues: World Geography
description:
20 Question style cards based on world geography, including a window-board with the numbers 1-20, to keep track of guesses. Reader chooses a random card, reads the category ("I am a land region," for example), and players take turns choosing a number. Reader reads the clue corresponding to that number (in this example, clue number 13 is: "The name the Indians gave me means "'Ground Afire'"), and that player takes a single guess at the answer. If wrong, play progresses to next player (if multiple players). If correct, the player wins points equal to 20-the number of clues required to guess the answer. Play continues until one player or team reaches 50, or some other predetermined point total. Alternatively, a set number of cards or a time limit can be set, and highest points wins.

Target areas range from very obvious (Pacific Ocean) to slightly obscure (Denali National Park).

name: Infernal Contraption: Zombiphage Cannon Promo Card
description:
The back of the card specifically says "Infernal Contraption 2nd Edition"

Card text:
"Your opponent puts the top card of the scrap pile into his hand and puts two cards from his hand on top of his parts pile."

Was packaged inside Zombies Keep Out

name: Jewels: Minatore
description:
A new promo card for Jewels which was originally given out at Lucca Convention

Text:
Discard 2 cards and choose any gem card from the discard pile, adding it to your hand.
categories: Card Game, Economic, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy
mechanics: Action Points, Auction/Bidding, Set Collection, Trading

name: Arnold Takes Command: The Battle of Bemis Heights
description:
Arnold Takes Command is a new kind of card-driven wargame for two players, ages 12 to 99. Unlike most of its siblings, in this game movement plays an insignificant role. Additionally, prior experience with traditional wargames isn’t required. ATC isn’t a dice-rolling slugfest or a “take that” affair. Here, it’s all about the card play: what to play, when to play it, what to discard, what to track, etc.

The game has two distinct phases, just like the actual battle. Players use action cards of various types to attack, defend, gain initiative, maneuver, emulate morale, take cover, use “fog of war” to their advantage, and so forth. Single “duds” are discarded, but pairs have a useful purpose.

A preponderance of “split” action cards ensures a nice variance from game to game. Components include 70+ cards and two maps.

—description from the designer
categories: American Revolutionary War, Card Game, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Milestone Mayhem
description:
Will Your Project Suck or Succeed?

In the game, you are the project lead on a front-end web app development project for a well known enterprise software and services company. Your goal is to complete your milestone before your rival project lead completes theirs.

To complete a milestone you turn over a card and earn points towards your milestone. Seems simple right? Well, just like in real life, there’s a lot of mayhem laying in wait to throw your project into chaos.

name: Domino Zootiere
description:
Domino Zootiere is a cute arranging fun for 2-3 children ages 2 years and older. Who will get rid of all their domino cards first?

How to play:

Do you have a domino card with one of the two animals?

Yes? – Excellent! Then place the domino card so that the animals that are the same are next to each other.
No? – Too bad! You can't place a domino card; take one domino card from the stack and place it face-up in front of you. If the new domino card matches a picture on the table then you may immediately place it.

End of the game
If players can no longer place any cards and there are no more face-down cards, then the game is over. If a player successfully places all their domino cards, they win the game

name: Domino Baustelle
description:
Domino Baustelle is a cute arranging fun for 2-3 children ages 2 years and older. Who will get rid of all their domino cards first?

How to play:

Do you have a domino card with one of the two building site pictures?
Yes? – Excellent! Then place the domino card so that the pictures that are the same are next to each other.
No? – Too bad! You can't place a domino; take one domino card from the stack and place it face-up in front of you. If the new domino card matches a picture on the table then you may immediately place it.

End of the game
If players can no longer place any cards and there are no more face-down cards, then the game is over. If a player successfully places all of their domino cards, they win the game!

name: Memo Bauernhof
description:
Memo Bauernhof provides entertaining memory fun for 2-4 children from 2 years. Who can remember the positions of the barnyard pictures and collect the most pairs?

How to play:

Did you turn over two of the same picture? Excellent! You can take the pair and keep it.

Did you turn over two different pictures? Too bad, but it's OK! Once everyone else has has a chance to see the barnyard cards you can turn them back over again.

End of the game
Have all the pairs been collected? Then all children place their barnyard cards next to each other: The player with the longest row of cards wins the game.

name: Lotto Fahrzeuge
description:
Lotto Fahrzeuge is a fun matching game for 2-4 children from 2 years. Who will be the first to fill their own base card with the right vehicles?

How to play:

Children play in a clockwise direction, taking turns. The youngest child begins and turns over a vehicle card. Everyone compares this vehicle card with their own base card. The player who finds the vehicle on their base card can take the vehicle card and place it face-up on their base card.

End of the game
The first player to place all three vehicle cards on their own base card wins the game!

name: Lotto Feenland
description:
Lotto Feenland is a fun matching game for 2-4 children from 2 years. Who will be the first to fill their own base card with the matching fairyland friends?

How to play:

Children play in a clockwise direction, taking turns. The youngest child begins and turns over a fairy card. Everyone compares this fairy card with their own base card. The player who finds the fairy on their base card can take the fairy card and place it face-up on their base card.

End of the game
The first player to place all three fairy cards on their own base card wins the game!

name: King Cat
description:
You will gain control of 1 of 4 unique Cat Kingdoms seeking dominance of your the home. Control your stores of Catnip, Recruit Knight Cats, Fulfill Secret Royal Decrees, Raise your Kingdom's Instinct, Honor, and use your cat army to conquer Territory, Toys, and Food for command of Victory Points.

The Kingdom with the most victory points wins!

This game combines hand and resource management, set collection, and competitive and cooperative play.

Tremendous replay value and family fun appeal with colorful components and a cute theme parodying the lives of our furry cat friends.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Set Collection

name: Chomp-itz Crocodile Dinner
description: Each of the two or three players in Chomp-itz Crocodile Dinner straps an elongated crocodile snout to their face, then races to catch their four colored fish so that they can then snatch the gold fish to win the game!

name: Tactician: the Game of Battlefield Strategy
description:
Tactician is a two-player turn-based game of tactics and strategy in which the players are medieval generals. Each player commands an army of Archers, Pikemen, Mounted Archers, and Knights who fight to destroy the foe and win the day.

Players first choose which advanced tactics to use, if any, and then assemble the game board. Choose at least four of the fourteen square tiles and arrange them so all tiles are accessible and both players have an equal number of starting squares. For a challenge, use the Tactical Terrain side of the tiles.

Each player begins with between eight and twenty units of their choosing, deployed within the first three rows of their side of the board. Turn phases include Movement, Combat, and Resupply. Combat is resolved based on Unit Advantages, situational bonuses, and a roll of the dice. All phases are completed by a single player before their opponent may begin their turn.
