In order to win, one player must eliminate all enemy forces from the field or outnumber their opponent's troops by more than 3-to-1. Set-up and play average 60 minutes total.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board

name: Timun Mas and Green Giants
description:
Once upon a time, lived a green giant named Buto Ijo. He gave a cucumber seed to old woman. Later on, the seed growth into giant cucumber. When the cucumber was slice, a cute baby appeared. The baby was named Timun Mas. 8 years later, Green Giant was back to take Timun mas as his food.

You play as Timun Mas. Bringing 4 magical weapons, you have to beat down the Green Giant. What are the weapons? Cucumber seed, salt, terasi, and needle. Collect all this weapons and attack the Green Giant.

Each player plays as Timun mas. You are the winner if you are able to collect Greent Giant greater than others.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Modular Board

name: The Heritage of Batik
description:
Batik is known as heritage of Indonesia’s culture. Therefore, we should keep it since it’s very sublime. Throughout this board game, we can play together with our family or friends. This game uses an unique local theme without losing its essence or its philosophy.

Player should collect component cards in order to create a Batik tile. Every single Batik tile is placed next to other tile so that it’s connected and create a pattern. Every time player buy a tile or use a tile, s/he will get a victory point. Moreover, player also has a chance to switch variate spell cards. By using this cards, player can distract another player or even speed up the action to get highest point. Player with highest point will be the champion.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Pattern Building, Tile Placement

name: Heavy Gear Demo Game
description:
An Introduction to the Heavy Gear World
This introductory game contains a simplified version of the Heavy Gear rules that keeps all the flavor of the game, but is easier to learn and faster to play. It does not require the use of the rulebook or of ANY other regular Heavy Gear supplements. The Heavy Gear Game demo includes 8 cut-out Gear counters (4 Hunters, 4 Jägers), 1 color hex map and a condensed version of the Silhouette tactical rules. All you need are a few six-sided dice.

—description from the introduction

name: Moscow In Peril:  1941
description:
Russian tank brigade up to army level. 3 turns per month - Oct-Jan - for a total of 12 turns, enabling the Russian winter counteroffensive. 16 hexes Smolensk to Moscow - 15 miles per hex. Blitzkrieg/breakthrough attacks.

Roads as well as railroads mapped.

—description from the designer
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Push Your Luck, Simulation

name: Eyegamer
description:
Eyegamer — The Ultimate Board Game To Have Fun And Train Your Memory.

In Eyegamer, the goal of the game is simple. The player’s task is to collect as many pairs of cards as possible in the shortest period of time. Eyegamer is a re-implementation of the classic memory game, with a minimalist, black & white card design. The minimalist design of the cards is designed to make it harder for you to match cards.

At the start of the game, shuffle and place the entire 40 card deck in a 10x4 (4 rows of 10 cards each) layout. The cards should be placed so that the patterned side of the cards are face down, and the "Eyegamer" card backs facing up.

On your turn, simply pick any two cards and turn them over, showing the patterned sides. If they match, remove them from play. Each matched set should stay with the player/team that matched them. If the chosen cards do not match, flip them back so that the "Eyegamer" card backs are facing up. They remain in play.

At the end of the game, each matched set is worth 1 point. The player/team with the most points wins the game.

There are three modes of play included in the game:


Solo - a 1 player challenge
Challenge - a 2 player challenge
Team Deathmatch - Up to 8 players (team sizes of 2 and 4 per team) with team members alternating turns choosing cards.


You can also purchase multiple Eyegamer decks to create larger grids for the game, thus making the game more challenging.

name: Im Himmel empfängt man die Krone der Belehrung
description:
This is a very early German game, possibly 17th-18th century, and perhaps unique. The rules and the outcome from landing in various squares are certainly handwritten on the thick paper board. Differences in the shapes of the space numbers suggest calligraphy rather than printing, with irregularities in the shapes of the spaces pointing to a hand-drawn board as well.

Like many early board games, its theme is moral improvement. The game title translates as: "In Heaven you will receive the Crown of Instruction".

In play, it is a typical spin-and-move along a 100-space track that spirals inward, with penalties and bonuses affecting various spaces along the way.

name: Emprise
description:
Emprise is an fast paced action economy combat card game that also doubles as a 52/54 card deck. By deploying troops and commissioning officers, your mission is to reinforce your position while repressing the enemies'. You will be forced into tense situations, sabotage your allies, rescue enemies, and sacrifice your own troops to win the battle.

The objective is to earn victories by having enough reinforcements played at the end of your turn. However, each reinforcement can also be used for hand management, strategy denial, assaulting enemies' reinforcements, or controlling gameplay.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Card Game, Modern Warfare
mechanics: Action Points, Hand Management, Take That

name: Syphilitic Conquistadors
description:
Join the invading Spaniards in the search for ancient treasure, or help the Aztecs protect their hidden storehouse, all while staving off the devastatingly crippling disease the Spaniards brought with them.
This two player game pits players against each other on a small tiled map, where they must fight to take and keep control of Aztec gold.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Modular Board, Network and Route Building, Pick-up and Deliver, Take That, Variable Player Powers

name: Machines of War
description:
Machines of War is a military strategy game, using the elements of area-control and deck-building. As you build your machine (deck), you must strive to overpower your enemies, decimate their armies, take their lands, and conquer the city.

—description from the publisher
categories: City Building, Fighting, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Player Elimination

name: Tipsy Land
description:
The object of the game is to the first to get to the end of the path.

Each player rolls the die and advances one’s own pawn indicated. Along the way players take a drink or force others to take a drink depending on which space a player’s pawn lands. The rules say, “Recommended to be played with non alcoholic beverages” but included with the game are four shot glasses. The instructions are in English, Spanish, and French so the publisher is duplicitous in three languages. Also of note, the game board is made of glass.

name: Disney Presents Movie Classics VCR Board Game
description:
Remember Snow White, Pinocchio, and Cinderella? Their adventures enchanted you when you were a child. Now with the Disney Movie Classics VCR board game, your child meets the same delightful characters but in a whole new way! Actual footage from the Disney movies is combined with three fun matching games.

Just insert the tape into your VCR and the adventure begins! The tape tells the story while the games add extra fun and excitement!

—description from the back of the box
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Diskmagik
description:
Diskmagik is an advanced version of the game Diskmoon, based on the novels universe "Ge-Volver 1810" by author Marco Ricchini.
In this uchronic XIX century, different ancient races live in secret among humans, often holding important roles in many nations.
Some of these people have the power of the ancient two-faced god Janus, this grants them two different appareances in one body.

In Diskmagic, a pirate called Morgan the Obese wrote a ruleset to regularize the rough sport invented by his crew and called it the Diskmoon discipline.
He dictated that all the games would have been played at Skull Island and the item to retrieve would be an ancient preciuos coin, called Diskmoon.

In the Diskmoon game series, two players use a team of four miniatures of different races. The two teams start the game in two different sides of the game board, comprised of 17x17 squares that they will build using two-sided tiles, making a different game every time.
The purpose of the game is to find the Diskmagik token and bring it to the opponent starting side to score one point. The first player that scores two points wins the game. One team can also win the game if he kills all the opponent's Jollary characters.
The players activate one of their miniatures every turn. Each miniature has 10 action points to spend for movement, attack, passing the diskmagik and using special abilities.
Each character also has two different sides represented on the miniature and on the cards than represent the two forms that he can switch into during the game to change his abilities and statistics.
The game board has some obstacles like water and lava that can slow or kill some characters.

Diskmagik reimplements the game Diskmoon introducing "the swarm" mechanic.

name: Diskfightorient
description:
Diskfightorient is an advanced version of the game Diskmoon, based on the novels universe "Ge-Volver 1810" by author Marco Ricchini.
In this uchronic XIX century, different ancient races live in secret among humans, often holding important roles in many nations.
Some of these people have the power of the ancient two-faced god Janus, this grants them two different appareances in one body.

In Diskfightorient, a pirate called Morgan the Obese wrote a ruleset to regularize the rough sport invented by his crew and called it the Diskmoon discipline.
He dictated that all the games would have been played at Skull Island and the item to retrieve would be an ancient preciuos coin, called Diskmoon.

In the Diskmoon game series, two players use a team of four miniatures of different races. The two teams start the game in two different sides of the game board, comprised of 17x17 squares that they will build using two-sided tiles, making a different game every time.
The purpose of the game is to find the Diskmoon token and bring it to the opponent starting side to score one point. The first player that scores two points wins the game. One team can also win the game if he kills all the opponent's Jollary characters.
The players activate one of their miniatures every turn. Each miniature has 10 action points to spend for movement, attack, passing the diskmagik and using special abilities.
Some characters also has two different sides represented on the miniature and on the cards than represent the two forms that he can switch into during the game to change his abilities and statistics.
The game board has some obstacles like water and lava that can slow or kill some characters.

Diskmagik reimplements the game Diskmoon introducing "grenades" mechanic.

name: Lunker
description:
Fishing game where players attempt to catch the most bass as measured in total weight. Players move from area to areas on the board and cast lines in an attempt to reel in a fish. Dice rolls determine whether you caught anything (with some areas providing a higher probability of success) and the size of the bass that was caught. There are penalties for catching undersized fish or returning to the marina too late at the end of the game.

From the front of the box:


Designed by fishermen for fishermen... Ages 8 to 80. Three levels of play: BASIC * INTERMEDIATE * ADVANCED teach scientific fishing by simulating actual fishing experiences. YOUR fishing knowledge and skill determine YOUR catch. Perfect for family, club, or solitary play. 1-8 PLAYERS.

name: Major League Baseball Challenge Game
description:
The Major League Baseball Challenge game is personalized to each team in Major League baseball. The box covers are designed for each team as well as a playing board which duplicates the home teams ball park, all in full color. No dice involved, this is a card game with special "at bat" and "fielding" cards which control play and provide real life baseball action. The rules are simple and the game is fast with sudden reversals like a home run with two on in the bottom of the 9th inning, for a come from behind win. Good Luck and "Play Ball."

—description from the back of the box

name: チャイニーズ・レストラン (Chinese Restaurant)
description: のチャイニーズ・レストラン (Chinese Restaurant) is a cooperative game in which you order dishes served on a turntable in a Chinese restaurant. Take pieces of food from the plates and meld them for takeout orders.

name: Ohirune Nyanko Darake
description:
A balance game featuring cats in different poses.

Set up the wobbling tire on a table or floor and then take it in turns to place one of 10 cat figures onto it using the chopsticks provided. Make sure you balance carefully and don't let the cats come tumbling off!

The game is aimed at children but is challenging enough for adults to play, especially in lighthearted settings.

It comes with numerous play options and mini games and puzzles.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Party Game

name: American Dreams
description:
Objective
Throughout history collect Life, Liberty, & Pursuit of Happiness cards. Each of these cards has a value, the player with the most points is the winner of the game.

Deck Types
American Dream – These are the Timeline Cards that will be played each turn to progress through American History, each play of the game will be the length of fifty years. Life, Liberty, and Pursuit of Happiness Cards – These cards include special moments in your life that you have experienced during your time playing, collecting these cards are important to winning the game and finishing with enough points to obtain and maintain your American Dreams. Remember the player with the highest total from these cards is the winner of the game.

Setup & Starting
Separate and shuffle the four different deck types, deal each player five American Dream Cards and one from each of the following decks; Life, Liberty, & Pursuit of Happiness. The player will have all Life, Liberty, & Pursuit of Happiness Cards face up in front of them.

The first card played in the timeline will be played by the oldest player, they must play their earliest American Dreams Card i.e. 1909.

Each player will take turns playing timeline cards and collecting or discarding Life, Liberty, & Pursuit of Happiness Cards based off the actions the American Dreams Card has them take.

For your turn you please note that you may only play a card 1 to 3 years after the previous card played. For example: If a player lays down 1925 and you are the next player, you may play 1926, 1927, or 1928—if you do not have that card, your turn is skipped and discard an American Dreams Card of your choice.

History Behind the Game
Each play you will most likely lose or gain Life, Liberty, & Pursuit of Happiness cards each and every turn. The fluctuation mimics the point on the timeline when obtaining the American Dream was more difficult than in other years.

During Wartime players will find it most difficult to maintain their current point total, use your cards wisely during these time to ensure that you will have the most points when the Timeline reaches fifty years from the starting point. Winning And Losing The Game When fifty years has passed on the timeline, you may begin to tally the total from your Life, Liberty, & Pursuit of Happiness cards. The player with the highest total is the winner.

Alternate Rules
Century Play: Depending on which version of the game you will be playing with, this version of the game goes beyond fifty years, it will begin in 1901 and last the entirety of the American Dreams deck, all cards must be played.

When you play the card it must be the exact following year, if you do not have that card—draw another card. You will not discard in this scenario. All American Dreams cards will be played on the timeline.

Example Of Play
Player One sets down 1904 to start the game, which causes them to collect one Happiness card, concluding their turn. Player Two sets down 1907 to follow, causing them to collect one Liberty card, concluding their turn. Player Three sets down 1910 to follow, causing them to lose one Life card. On Player One's second turn at play, they choose to use one of their Life, Liberty, & Pursuit of Happiness cards that has an action—on this turn of play they have the option to trade a card with a fellow player. Player One chooses to take their 1 point value card and trade it for Player Two's 5 point value card. This action will help Player One going forward.

—description from the designer

name: Schnitzeljagd für kleine Detektive
description: Each of two teams (foxes and hunters) play on their own identical game boards. No team may see the board of the opposite team. Each hunter tries to cature the fox of the same color by getting on the same area as the fox. Movement is one area per turn. After each third move the players have to inform the opposite team of the name of the area he is standing on. There are 1 item of 12 areas and 2 items of 18 areas on each board. If a hunter gets on the same area as the fox of his color and claims the fox to be captured, the hunter has won, if the fox reaches the opposite edge of the game board, the fox has won. In both cases both are eliminated from the game. The last fox captured or escaped decides the winning team.
mechanics: Area Movement, Player Elimination, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Gob'z'Heroes: Smile Pack
description:
Additional figures and their profile cards for Gob'z'Heroes:

Devil'Pig is heavy, accurate and rough. When you activate devil pig, roll a die, on a result of 5 or 6, the commands are obeyed! Devil's pig physical abilities become 10 until the end of your turn.

Gob'Clown is lucky and starts with clown hammer. When gob'clown tickles a rival gob', place 2 tickles markers on the target. When gog'clown causes a rival gob' to become stunned, that gob' also receives a tickle marker.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting, Humor, Miniatures
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Hand Management

name: Contact
description:
Players each take turns moving one of their 3 coloured squares on a 4x4 grid. 8 of the 16 squares in this grid are 'scoring' squares and a player will score when they move one of their pieces into a scoring square. Players earn points for pieces that are attached to the edges of their scoring square, plus pieces in their colour that are in the same row or column as their starting piece. In addition, being in the same row or column as the 'dictator' piece (a square of a third colour) doubles their points for that turn. The dictator can also be moved at the cost of 3 points.

Players continue to play rounds until one player reaches a set number of points, with that player being the winner.

name: Hinaus in die Ferne!
description:
This is a simple roll-and-move game concerning a holliday trip. On the roll of a 6, the player has a second turn. On some spaces events benefit or hinder the players. The first player to reach space 150 wins the game.

The game was published about 1958 as an insert for the tv-magazine "Hör Zu".
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Würfeln Sie mit!
description:
This is a simple roll-and-move game. On the spaces that picture magazine covers, events benefit or hinder the players. If a player gets on a space that is already occupied, the other player has to get back on the next free blue space behind him. The first player to reach space 75 wins the game.

The game was published in December 1958 as an insert for the womans-magazine "Constanze".

—user summary
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Spacebabies N Robots
description:
Spacebabies N Robots is easy to play a board game with little strategy and lots of fun! The premise is simple, each player has four robots (pawns), carrying babies. Player has to get all his robots to the escape pod while facing scary alien creatures, death blocks, and opponent traps. The first player to get all his/ her robots to escape pod wins. The players will be equipped with certain weapons and power-ups which can be used strategically. Maximum of four people can play this game. BE CAREFUL! The fate of the space babies depends on a roll of dice!

Overview
-This game has three different maps with distinct look and feel.
Some rules will vary according to maps.
-This game can be played by 2,3, or 4 players.
-The main objective is to get all the robots (pawns) to the escape pod (middle area) for their evacuation before other players.
-Players can choose to play solo or form teams based on their preferences.
-Each player will get 4 robots (pawns), 6 cards and custom tiles (2 or 3 depending on the map).
-The custom tiles will be used as traps for opponents.
-Certain custom tiles can be used for own advantage.
-The player can kill other opponents and get killed by other opponents.

Rules
-To start the game, a player will have to roll either 1 or 6.
Every roll of six will grant a bonus roll.
-The player can move any pawn in the active play area on a dice roll.
-For a single dice roll, you can move only one pawn. If you get a bonus roll, you can use that role for another pawn.
-If your pawn reaches a block (a tile in the active play area), and if opponent's pawn is there, player’s pawn will kill it and take its place.
-Player will get a bonus roll for a kill.
-The player can use cards to his/her advantage. (Refer to card info and rules)
-The player can use custom tiles as a trap as well as for own advantage. (Refer custom tiles).
-A pawn reaching the destination area/ escape pod will give grant one bonus roll to the player.
-While stuck in a trap, if the player has no cards or doesn’t want to use cards, the player can try and roll 1 or 3 to get out of it. If the player fails, the pawn will die. Also, if a player rolls 6, failing to roll 1 or 3, the player can use the bonus which he/ she got from a roll of 6 to try and roll 1 or 3. If the player fails again, he can use the bonus on any other pawns in the active play area.

name: Cupcake Mania
description:
Cupcake Mania is a family card game for 2 to 5 players, where each player takes the role of a crazy bakery chef during a hard day at work.
Each player, during their turn, must get the pastries that come out of the ovens, placing their tokens on them, according to the turn order.
With these pastries, they must prepare as many client orders as possible, under the watchful eye of the bakery owner.
The player with most order points at the end of the game will be declared the winner.

name: Jack 'n Andy: A Game for Men
description:
This is a mature/adult game. The game states it is for adult men. During the game, players will perform sexual acts on the other players.

At the beginning of the game each player chooses their winning condition from the following list:
"I am playing this game to:
1) Receive Pleasure...
a) 25%
b) 50%
c) 100%

2) Give Pleasure...
a) 25%
b) 50%
c) 100%"
This choice is kept secret from the other players.

Players roll dice to move around the board and follow the instructions on the location where their pawn ends their movement.

Players can get "Penalty Cards" which force them to give "affection" to the other players.

As players move around the board, they are collect puzzle pieces. Players attempt to complete two complete images, each of a naked man.

Completing the two puzzles allows players to move to the inside track on the board where they can collect "Hole Cards."

The winner is the first person to get a "Hole Card" that matches the combination he has chosen at the beginning of the game.

name: The Metro Mosaic Game
description: Metro-Mosaic is a game of logic played with different colored markers on a grid divided into 4 territories. Each player fills his territory leaving the fewest number of open cells. During play each player devises a plan of development, a plan of defense, and a plan to disrupt his opponents plans. Finished game of the model of the "Broad Acres" community.

name: Shataro
description:
Described in passing in Edward Falkener's book 'Games Ancient And Oriental and how to play them' (1892, page 163), thus:
"an Indian game of cards, ... in which after every deal, the winners take at chance [ie randomly, unseen] as many cards from the hand of the loser as they have won tricks, and give back to him in return as many of the worst cards they have in their own hands; and thus at every deal he is worse off, till he is happily out of the game."

The above mechanism appears to be in use in at least one variant of Indian games with Ganjifa cards, so I would imagine this game to be played with those cards rather than 'western' ones.

name: Crown of Aragón: Philip Leader Promo Card
description:
First released in 2017 at PAX Unplugged.

This promotional leader card is available by meeting Crown of Aragón designer Phil Amylon in person.

Leader cards add variable player powers to Crown of Aragón.

Philip's leader side allows you to start the game with 2 influence in the area of your choice. When you play his event side you gain 4 influence in any area where you have no influence.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Variable Player Powers

name: Crown of Aragón: Randall Leader Promo Card
description:
First released in 2017 at PAX Unplugged.

This promotional leader card is available by meeting Crown of Aragón developer Randy Nadeau in person.

Leader cards add variable player powers to Crown of Aragón.

Randall's leader side allows you to abandon cards you have in play to return cards from the discard pile to your hand, or you can give up his ability to play his event side, which lets play two additional cards that share a type.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Variable Player Powers

name: Velocity-9
description:
We’re running out of fuel. Only one planet in the galaxy has Glimmer, a newly discovered fuel source, and your faction needs to control it. But so does everyone else, so you’re about to enter the race to end all races. Fly faster than you’ve ever flown, outrun your rivals, do whatever it takes to get to that planet first. Because if you win Velocity-9, you win the galaxy.

As one of six factions in Velocity-9, you will roll a D6 and play various racing cards in order to speed up your ship, slow your opponents down, and block effects they play against you. You will also contend with various cosmic events that can either help or hinder you, such as wormholes and solar winds. In addition, each faction has two unique advantages and one unique liability, which can turn the tide of the race.

Your goal is to progress down the board, reach the planet Velocity-9, and circle the planet with your ship. Do this before your rivals, and you will deploy your shield around the planet, claiming control of its fuel for your faction.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Take That, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers

name: Ghost Raiders: The Shadow Hills Hotel
description:
In Ghost Raiders, each player is a Ghost Raider in a haunted hotel in the dystopian future in a race to become the Head Ghost Raider.

Players try to collect canisters filled with ghosts to be the first player to have collected three canisters. Players draw scenario cards that will aid or inhibit their progress while trying to collect ghosts.

There are two types of cards, Ghost Cards and Haunt (scenario) Cards. Each turn, players go through a scenario and then try to collect as many ghosts into their canisters as they can, but they have to consider that ghost types do not always match, so they will have to empty out canisters quite often to make room for new ghost types. This can cause heartbreak, but it can also put a player in the lead if they play their cards right.

Players' hands represent the radars used as the Ghost Raiders, therefore they can't rearrange the order of cards in their hands.

Players take their turns by doing the following:
1. Draw a Haunt card.
2. Draw or Discard Ghost cards.
3. Play a Ghost card.
4. Re-scan the room (Draw a Ghost card face-up, draw another Ghost card face-down).
5. Exchange Ghost cards.
6. End your turn.
mechanics: Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Set Collection, Trading

name: Zero Order
description: Zero Order aka "0o" is a flat-packed 3D printed abstract strategy board game. Played with 18 hexagonal pieces that are Units on one side and Tiles on the other. 12 of the pieces become tiles for your map while the remaining 6 become the units with which you battle with. Players take turns trying to take enemy units off the map using the unique actions and combos available to them. First one to completely incapacitate or eliminate the enemy, wins.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Modular Board, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Playground
description:
Players roll marbles down plastic slides trying to have them land in holes in the sand box in the middle of the board. You score one point for each marble that is in a hole in the sand box and three points if the white marble if it is in your opponent's half of the sand box.

Points are tracked on a path around the playground and the winner is the first to make it to the end of the path.

name: Blood and Treasure
description:
Blood and Treasure is a dungeon crawling simulation for 1 or more players using a standard 52 card deck of cards (jokers optional). The goal of the game is to kill/capture as many monsters as possible while collecting and keeping as much treasure as you can. The dungeon is also filled with spike traps and locked doors that must be passed in order to complete the dungeon successfully.

Game-play/Card Designations:
[Drawn cards]

When face cards (king, queen, jack) are drawn they become "monsters" and the next numbered card drawn becomes both the hit-point value and the treasure of the monster (for the player to keep if the monster is defeated). Monsters can either be defeated using swords and shields or the player can defend/take a hit with shields and health points.
When clubs are drawn they become doors and must be unlocked with keys or smashed with swords.
When spades are drawn they become spike traps and must be disarmed or traversed.


[Played cards]

Spades are used as swords to defeat a monster or smash doors.
Clubs are used as shields to defend from a monster attack or safely traverse a spike trap.
Diamonds are used as keys to unlock doors or disarm traps. Diamonds also count as treasure when tallying points at the end of the game.
Hearts are used as health points to take a hit from a monster or to take damage while getting through a spike trap.


The game can be played until the deck has been depleted (dungeon run), until all face cards have been collected (monster hunt), or until the entire deck has been collected (hero's quest).

When counting up points at the end of the game, face cards are worth 5 points each and diamonds are worth the number on the card. (Aces are counted as 1 point.)

—description from the designer

name: Ridiculous Angler
description:
Become an angler with quick hands,get the biggest catch!

“Ridiculous Angler” is a game for brain train, memory and quick reaction.

"Ridiculous Angler" casts a fishing rod and catches only fun.
The fun is not just about the catch in a fishnet, it is about competing with those anglers next to you! Become a ridiculous angler and try fishing.

[Game play and winning]
In the beginning of the game, memorize the types of fish that you will need to catch in your net. During the game players on their turn draw goal cards and catch fish cards from “the sea“. In this game you will need quick hands and fast reaction to compete with other anglers. You will deal with many types of fish. In the end of the game, when all goal cards are finished, you will decide which types of fish to keep in your net, the rest – will be released. Every fish you caught, will bring (or not bring!) you points. The player who scores the most is the winner.

name: Great Man Cards
description: Great Man cards (上大人牌) are character cards, like "chess cards" or their ilk whose characters come from the Confucian classic copybook "On the Great Man" (上大人). The cards come in a variety of formats with as few as 24 types of cards and as many as 27. They are used primarily to play vaguely Rummy-like games and stem almost exclusively from Hubei province.

name: Dice Odyssey
description:
SUMMARY
All but one of the players will take on the role of a hero (who are part of the same guild) that is participating in a great competition known as “The Dungeon Games”. These events, created by the world’s greatest magicians, are pulse-pounding, unpredictable and timed. Each player will need to make use of every round they have available to them, either trying to complete the main objective or grabbing “Arcane Keys” that are scattered around the environment for some vital extra points. The last player will take on the special role of Storyteller, who uses the prewritten adventures (or their own) to run the story the other players participate in. They function as a referee of sorts, playing all the NPCs and baddies in the combat (in Dice Odyssey, the Storyteller will try to defeat the heroes in combat by choosing a good combination of baddies and selecting their actions carefully). The game is composed of 2 main systems, Exploration and Combat.

EXPLORATION SYSTEM
Each adventure will give the players a set number of rounds to complete it in. When a player takes a turn, he will tell the Storyteller what he plans to do, it’s up to the Storyteller to gauge how many rounds it would take to accomplish it. Another simple element that makes this game feel completely unique are the Arcane Keys. They are collectables that are scattered everywhere, each one having some sort of puzzle or trial involved in getting to it. The Arcane Keys allow more opportunities for each person on the team to be helpful. For example, if the main objective requires Stealth and Athletics, then the Arcane Keys that are close by, will be Wits and Lore based. At every moment, all attributes are useful, and Arcane Keys are the main reason why.

Whenever a player attempts to do something difficult, they will have to roll dice to see if they are successful. The number of dice they roll is determined by the attribute the Storyteller says is needed for the task and how many of that type of Attribute Card they have. For example, if a player needs to push a large sleeping giant out of the way, the Storyteller will tell him it will take an athletics roll, and what number he will have to roll to be successful, in this case, a 6. The player will look to see if he has an athletics Attribute Card, and will roll an additional die for each that he has. The base roll being 3 dice. There are 8 attributes; Athletics, Dungeoneering, Fortitude, Lore, Luck, Stealth, Vigilance and Wits. On each Attribute Card there is also some sort of boon, perhaps for Fortitude, a hero may have “Bark Skin”. This element can be used creatively to help the player throughout the quest, and ultimately is up to the Storyteller. Generally, the rule is, if they can explain how they are using it for a task, they can convert the Attribute Card to a different type. Using the card above “Bark Skin (Fortitude)”, a player hides next to a tree after stripping down. This could convert the Attribute Card from Fortitude to Stealth for the use of that one roll.

COMBAT SYSTEM
In most RPGs, heroes have some base stats that do not change, such as HP, defense, attacks, etc. But in Dice Odyssey, players can change their heroes “base stats”. Imagine a normally defensive, tough hero, who is putting his guard down to do extra damage this turn, in Dice Odyssey, that means he would have chosen a different Combat Card this turn. Players begin combat by assessing the baddies they are fighting, their teammates strengths and weaknesses and from that, what Combat Card would be most appropriate. Most heroes have 5 different Combat Cards, and can swap between those cards during the game by buying them at the store.

After the baddies have been laid out, the players will also each grab 4 of the dice from their bags and roll them to see which of their Loot Cards they can use this round of combat. Each point rolled on a die, will allow the player to activate that many points on the corresponding Loot Card. For example, if they roll a 1 on a Fey die, they can pick which Fey card they want to activate (if they have more than one) and then pick which of the 3 (1 point) powers they want to use. If they were to roll a 2 instead, they could choose 2 (1 point) powers on that card. The Loot Cards serve as an add-on to the player's Combat Card. After 2 uses the Loot Cards break, at which point, you have to discard it and put one of your dice of that type back in the main bag.
There is more to the combat system, but this covers most of it.

CONCLUSION
If the players are able to finish the main quest in the time allotted, they receive a point for each Arcane Key they were able to escape with. Depending on how many points they have, the heroes will be in 1st – 5th place. The actual victory is if they are able to complete the mission at all, the bonus points serve as a high score mechanic. It is also fun to replay the same quest to see if you can get the number one spot!
categories: Card Game, Dice, Exploration, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Role Playing, Storytelling, Turn Order: Time Track, Variable Player Powers

name: Tweety and Sylvester's "I Tawt I Taw a Puddy Tat" Game
description:
Spin the spinner and follow the colors (landed on) to run across the picket fence, away from Granny and out the gate.
—description from the box

A simple children's game featuring the cartoon characters Tweety, Sylvester, & Granny.

The goal is to be the first player to advance your Sylvester token across the 16 space picket fence. Each space is colored differently to correspond to different sections on the spinner. But you can be sent back to the start if you land on a broken piece of fence.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Einer für alle: alle für einen
description: Every player gets 4 token of one color and places them on the spaces of the same color on the outher circle on the game board. The big standard-bearer (s-b) is placed ob the black space. The players roll a die and move the s-b accordingly clockwise as indicated by the arrows on the game board. If the s-b gets on a space with a token, the token is placed on a space of the same color in the middle of the game board. The first player, whose four token are on the middle spaces wins the game.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Six Tigers Cards
description:
"Six Tigers" Cards (六虎牌) are traditional playing cards of the Hakka minority in China. They are arranged into four ranked suits with cards numbered from one to nine inclusive. Extra joker-like cards are optionally attached; any given deck may have from 0 to 5 of these extras (of which only two ever appear to be used in any published sets of rules).

The games played with these cards tend to be multi-trick games for three to four people; in these games when there's a fourth that person doesn't actively play but only deals and is active in the ensuing payouts. The deal changes each round depending on who won the previous.

Most cards of this variety have only the characters for suit and number (in Hakka traditional form, not normal Chinese characters) although some larger, more elaborate decks may have illustrations.

name: Taki Sugoroku
description:
Taki Sugoroku is a serious game that learns waterfall model.
Waterfall model is one of software development methods.
It simulates the flow from requirement specification to user test.
Each player becomes a project manager and aims to complete the project earlier than the opponent.

The game advances like squares and Monopoly.
In order to advance the squares, programmers must be placed.
Also, the people and methods you want are early first-come-first-served with your opponent.
It is interesting to figure out what is necessary for your project and to give the best instructions to programmers.
—description from the designer (English)

滝すごろくはソフトウェア開発手法の1つであるウォーターフォールモデルを学習できるシリアスゲームです。
要求仕様書からユーザーテストまでの流れをシミュレートしています。
各プレイヤーはプロジェクトマネージャとなり、対戦相手より早くプロジェクトを完成させることを目指します。

ゲームはすごろくやモノポリーのようにマス目を進んでいきます。
マス目を進むためには、プログラマーを配置しなければなりません。
また、自身の欲しい人材や手法は対戦相手と早い者勝ちです。
自分のプロジェクトには何が必要かを見極め、プログラマーに最適な指示を行うことに面白さがあります。
—description from the designer (Japanese)
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Simulation

name: IN:FLUX
description:
Available now on theGameCrafter store:
http://bit.ly/38geAe1

IN:FLUX is a sci-fi tabletop game set on Earth. The game involves four unique factions that fight for control of a map. Players expand across the map and vie for control of territory. A simplified user experience allows for fast play. The game has an economy which is simple enough to allow for focusing on strategy. Modular map tiles and various factions bonuses allow for re-play value. Players can upgrade their tech tree and play a bluffing game with opponents. Different technologies have different synergies.

This game's tokens and punchboards contain: reactors, factories, drones, walls.

You'll enjoy this game if you like: Area Control, Strategy, Combat, Damage, Territory, Economy, Empire

The twists are: bluffing, interrupting, technologies, and objectives.

The game core is made of: hexagonal modular map tiles, deep strategy, and factions.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Income, Investment, Modular Board, Tile Placement, Variable Player Powers, Zone of Control

name: Past Times
description: New US History trivia game. Comes packaged in a 25"x3" tube with game mat, score cards, scoring tokens, game pieces, and trivia questions in these categories: Rural Life, Industry, Business, Work Life, Transportaton and Social Change. Additional question packs available. For 2-4 players, and suitable for team play. First player or team to answer one question in each category correctly wins. Goal of the game: have fun exploring the history you think you know.

name: Cannonball
description:
One of the range of 1959/1960 games by Bell Toys that featured TV show themed board games.
This one is Cannonball, high speed action on the American-Canadian Highways. Typical counters, pieces to move game with spinner instead of dice.

name: Smurfarna Yatzy
description: Yahtzee variant where each side of the dice have a picture of different characters from The smurfs comic including Papa Smurf, Smurfette, Gargamel and Azrael. The score is counted in a different way, where each die in pair or three of a kind etc gives 1 point, but you also get point six times for collecting a character, where eg four Papa Smurf gives 4 points. Then there is Yahtzee that you get the first time rolling five of the same character, this gives 7 points. The game is played in 11 rounds.
categories: Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip, Dice

name: Rep Your City! Detroit Board Game
description:
A 2 to 10 player trivia and strategy board game all about Detroit sports, music and entertainment, politics, culture, and history. Use your knowledge of the city to make it from the outskirts of the board (blue zone) to the center of the city (red zone) in order to win the ultimate jackpot and the key to the city.

There's a Standard Edition, Collector's Edition (30 autographed and numbered boards), and Special Edition (includes the "Hood Stack" of 225 additional question cards, for example, a Wild Card called "You Got Jacked!"). This game has been called: "Insanely fun!", "A must have for all Detroiters!", and "The perfect gift!"

name: Combat Patrol: World War II – Supplement for the South Pacific.
description:
Provides a comprehensive set of rules for skirmishes set in World War II. This supplement provides guidance for adapting the rules to the unique conditions and tactics of fighting in the South Pacific. The Japanese began the campaign with elite forces at high morale. US Marine forces also began the campaign at a high level of training and morale, while with the exception of the 25th Infantry Division, the US Army began the campaign with little experience and poor training. Most of this changed after Guadalcanal, where elite Japanese forces and US Marines experienced heavy losses. By that time, US Army National Guard divisions had greatly improved. Throughout the fighting in the South Pacific the Australians were widely regarded as having provided the most proficient and effective infantry. Fighting in the South Pacific was not homogeneous.

Each campaign and island provided a unique set of circumstances.
This supplement adds Japanese morale result tables, Banzai Charges, Night Infiltration, Die in Place, Hidden Japanese Positions, with a detailed vehicle and weapons list.

The requirement for new action decks for the Japanese is not required but makes the game easier.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Simulation

name: Tower Capture
description:
Tower Capture combines the strategy of checkers and chess with the luck involved in a quick roll of the dice. The idea of Tower Capture is to simply capture the tower of your opponent by moving across the board of white and black hexagons. However, the movement of your 10 pieces is partially controlled by the two dice, which determine whether you move to a white or a black space, and whether you move through a red, yellow, or blue path. To win, make it to the space adjacent to the opposing tower, and capture opponent's pieces along the way by landing on the same space.

—description from designer

name: Scrollhammer
description:
Scrollhammer is an "open source" published set of miniatures rules that derives many concepts from Setting: Warhammer Fantasy Wargames while using a setting derived from the Elder Scrolls media franchise. The game was developed on a public forum and accepted input from users through two major revisions until a final publication date.

Play uses many methods common to traditional wargaming. Movement and distances are presented in "inches" and determined with the use of a tape measure. Modified six-sided dice rolls are used to determine many outcomes. Various arena tokens are used to denote alterations to the battlefield that occur during play.

Each player controls the units of an opposing force. Forces are built using a points pool. As these calculations can become rapidly tedious, numerous armies and forces are provided by a variety of forum users.

Each unit in each force is represented by a model that is placed on the play surface. Models have a paper record that tracks various statistics and play values such as speed, armor, ammunition, and so forth. Units may make attacks on opposing units as long as they have the range, remaining ammunition or power, and line of sight. Successful attacks deal damage that may destroy, disable, or partially disable targets.

Play proceeds in alternating player turns, each half-turn being sub-divided into movement, fire, and assault phases. Victory conditions are set before the scenario begins and typically involve force destruction or "capture the flag" goals. Rules disputes are resolved by a simple die throw.

—user summary

name: Scrollhammer 2nd Edition
description:
Scrollhammer 2nd Edition is a miniatures wargame with a setting derived from the Elder Scrolls media franchise. It is notably distinct from Scrollhammer because Scrollhammer 2nd Edition uses a completely original move and combat system. The game has gone through repetitive playtest/revision cycles, leading to numerous (iterative) versions, each published as a static PDF from 2013 through 2017.

Scrollhammer 2nd Edition focuses primarily on squad-based skirmishing where opposing players control a force composed of individual units, each unit represented on the play surface by a model. Each model has a corresponding data card. Scenarios may use either pre-determined setup or a deployment zone method.

Models should conform to a 25mm standard; the play surface is assumed to be flat (terrain is indicated but not created). Distance and movement are performed in "inches", determined by tape measure.

Each turn is divided into two half-turns, one for each player. Initiative determines which player acts first. During each turn, every model may take two Actions (during the controlling player phase) and take one Reaction (during the opposing player phase). Attacks may be made on any other model that is in range and which is in "line of sight" of the attacker. Attacks and other opposed situations are resolved by a modified six-sided die roll. Attacks may destroy, disable, or partially disable the target.

Special rules cover command influence, cover, missile and thrown weapons, dual-wielding combat weapons, blast attacks, and so forth. The game utilizes a magic system as an organic component; magical effects are circumscribed and are "low powered" in scope.

Scenarios use a pre-determined victory condition and play proceeds until the condition is achieved. Many pre-built units are presented in the rules (custom unit creation is supported but complex).

—user summary

name: Sacramento
description: Sacremento is a redevelopment of Take five by the same author. Like its predecessor, the game is played on a 6×6 board with 4 chess pieces: two bishops, a knight, and a rook. However, these tiles are printed with playing card values: aces, 3 royals, and the numbers 10–7 in four suits. Play proceeds just like Take Five, but the goal is to build the best poker hand.

name: All About Allentown
description: From the game instructions: The object of this game is for the players, using dice and playing pieces, to travel on the gameboard from a residence square to the bank and shopping locations shown on their shopping lists. The first player to return to his residence with the travel cards for all locations contained on his shopping list wins the game!
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: You Did What?
description:
Drinks not included!
​"You Did What?" is the first "Laminated Poster Board Game" for adults from Shim and D'rothy. The 18" x 24" game board features original black and white hand-drawn artwork on over 40 spaces. The laminated paper sheet can hang on a wall as a decoration and then be taken down to play the game. The surface is lamination-encapsulated so it can't be easily ruined by spilled drinks.
Players: 2 or more
Ages: 21+
Typical game duration: 60 minutes
Great for dorms, party rooms, bars, and your adult clubhouse!
Bring your own:
6-sided die
coins, bottlecaps, or other play markers
paper
pens/pencils
smartphone/camera (optional)
... and get to playing (and drinking, and smoking)!
publishers: Shim and D'rothy Products Worldwide LLC

name: Escape The Fest!
description:
Escape The Fest! (ETF!) is a multiplayer set collection card game for 2-6 players (13 and up) and takes 30-60 minutes to play. In ETF! players (attendees) take turns trying to complete objectives (responsibilities) in order to leave the festival and not lose themselves in it. The first attendee to take care of all their responsibilities or with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.

Each round (day) brings new rules to observe. Some of the other attendees may be looking for the same responsibilities as you making it harder for you to take care of them. Other attendees may just continue to remind you of how many other responsibilities you have, causing you to stay on the festival grounds longer. You may even make some drastic choices that can help or harm you on your journey. All these things will ensure that no two festivals will feel the same.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Points, Hand Management, Set Collection, Take That, Variable Player Powers

name: Act of Treason
description:
In Act of Treason, players take on the role of Royal Advisors tasked with ruling a Kingdom in the wake of the Kings death. Players are given a secret loyalty card, assigning them as a Traitor, Loyal, or the Heir in hiding. Loyals win by rooting out and eliminating the Traitors, or passing five Quests to safely herald in the new King. Traitors win when four Quests fail, or by finding and assassinating the Heir. Players will scheme, deceive, and persuade in order to complete their objectives.

Each round, players contribute Knowledge cards in secret towards a Quest. Knowledge that matches the colour of the Quest will increase the chance of it passing, whilst off-colour cards increases the chance of failure. Players may vie for powerful Court cards, plot assassinations, or simply pass their action while they garner information. Play continues until the Loyals win and the Heir is safe, or the Traitors win and the Kingdom is left to ruin. As the game progresses, tensions will rise. Players will resort to accusations and assassinations in a last ditch effort to save the Kingdom, or force its destruction.

Act of Treason was inspired by social deduction games like Mafia, Werewolf, and Battlestar Galactica. It takes many aspects of these games and seeks to amplify what makes them so much fun: the social interaction, suspicion and deception! In Act of Treason, the only thing that stands between you and victory is your ability to read, bluff, and persuade others.

name: Uglen Ulla og skovens hemmeligheder
description: Each player needs to collect six specific pieces on the wheel-shaped board. Roll and move.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Stahl und Eisen
description:
This game's box cover and spectacularly illustrated board provide a thorough tour of WWI Germany's military-industrial complex, from a coal mine and iron and steel making through the production of massive artillery pieces and warships.

In play, it is a basic spin-and-move game, but the artwork by Johann B. Maier made for effective wartime propaganda at the time and remains today a vivid historical picture of the role of heavy industry during the Great War.

name: The Game of Paul Pry
description:
This is a mid-19th century party game subtitled I Hope I Don't Intrude, and takes its name from the popular comedy play Paul Pry, which premiered in 1825.

The game consists of a deck of 13 cards. Once card has the instructions, and list of 12 questions labelled A through L. Each letter corresponds to an answer card with possible responses numbered from 1 through 15.

One player has custody of the cards, and reads a question. The remaining players in turn pick a number from 1 to 15, and the player with the cards then reads off the corresponding answer.

For instance, to question L ("What most occupies your thoughts?"), potential answers range from "The fashions" and "My dinner" to "My own virtues" and "In building air castles". Presumably the answer generating the most laughs wins.

name: Metro City Meltdown
description:
Metro City Meltdown is a co-operative disaster management game for 1-4 players, which takes around 1 hour to play.
Taking place over 8 days, can you and your team protect and serve a city gone crazy and leave it whole at the end of your term? Sounds easy? Budget restraints, wild weather and angry citizens all contribute to the city’s decline.
Oh and don't get me started on the 100 foot tall dinosaurs or flying saucers...

The game takes place over 8 game days and players take the roles of city officials trying to protect the city from damage, rioting and disease.

Players use their city budgets to put crews into the city blocks to counter the news events that bring further disaster and ruin to the streets.

If you can survive to the end of your watch and have most of the city still up and running you win as a team. But lose too many city blocks or too many citizens to disease rioting or other dangers and you are fired and removed from office.

Each Player has a set of budget dice and there are federal budget dice which are divided among players according to the needs of the city.

Your budget can be assigned to actions to counter damage that takes place during the game. (Each round event cards dictate the headlines for that round and the damage that is caused).
These actions could be to put out fires, heal the diseased, control unruly citizens repair infrastructure and reconnecting utilities. Be careful though you also need budget to move your work crews around the city.

If any of these issues get out of control they can spread very quickly. Losing 3 city blocks or all of the damage counters of any type results in instant dismissal from the City Disaster council and disgrace for your team.

Watch your HQ as well if that burns down or is damaged beyond repair the same result can take place.

With 4 difficulty levels this game can be a light entertaining game right through to nearly impossible odds. This might seem repressive but beating the game on Expert level is a great boost.
Solo play can be played in the normal way but the Solo story mode involves scenarios that build upon each other.
mechanics: Action Queue, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Simulation

name: PAM a game for children
description:
PAM is an educational game for younger children. A set of 12 unique illustrated 3x3 grids features images of things that are Plants (P) or Animals (A) or Minerals (M) and the players must match the images on the grid with a similar image on a randomly drawn card. The first child to match three images in a row on his or her 3x3 grid is declared the winner. The cards include an illustration plus a written description to enhance reading skills.

Includes grids, cards, score chips, and instruction sheet. Can be played solitaire. Adult supervision is not required for older children.

name: Recycling
description:
This is a simple web-published paper & pencil game intended to teach the benefits of recycling wastes of different kind to children and their families.

The game comes with a sheet for each player. Some dice and eraserable pencils are required to play.

On your turn, roll three dice. Each number is associated to a different material (1 = plastic, 2 = paper, 3 = glass, 4 = aluminuim, 5 = special stuff, 6 = organic waste), and each material has a different special effect.

For each die you can choose either to keep it or discard it. In the latter case, you get to activate the related special effect - i.e.: paper makes you roll 2 more dice, while glass makes you adjust the value of another die,... - . Mark a X on the Waste track (negative points!) for each die discarded in this way.

Then, for each die you kept, mark a X on the related "building track". When the 5th X of a building track has been marked, you have managed to build the Recycling Plant for the related material, thus you won't mark X on the Waste track anymore for using the related special effect. You also score some points depending on how many other players have preceded you in building the same Recycling Plant.

As soon as a player has built 4 Recycling plants, the game is over and whoever has the most points is the winner.
categories: City Building, Dice, Educational, Environmental, Print & Play

name: Monsters!!
description:
A card game where you play cards to earn or steal points. Players must gain the most points by the time Dracula is drawn from the deck. Each card features a different classic horror monster, each with their own action to use when played. Some cards give players the option to earn extra points by howling, groaning for brains or generally being monstrous.
There are 50 Monster cards, 25 Score Cards and 1 instruction sheet in each retail box.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Zombies

name: What's the Name of the Game?!
description:
Also known as The Colander Game, The Hat Game and The Celebrity Game, this is a fast-paced guessing game where players put cards with the names of famous people on them into a colander, bowl or hat and teams take turns to act, speak or dance clues. Guaranteed to bring out players’ competitive streaks!

Similar to Celebrities
categories: Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: Partition
description:
Partition is a 2-player campaign tournament system consisting of three card games all based on popular eSports gaming genres: FPS, MOBA and CCG. Each game can be played without even owning the other games, offering a familiar experience to their online counterparts, but with cards. When combined together with the Partition core box, the games form the Partition Grand Tournament, a three-match contest to decide once and for all who can build the best team of Gamers and lead them to victory!

—descro[topm frp, the designer
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Dice, Fantasy, Modern Warfare, Science Fiction, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Open Drafting, Secret Unit Deployment, Simultaneous Action Selection, Tile Placement

name: Les Recettes Pompettes: Le Jeu – Deuxième Tournée!
description:
Les Recettes pompettes - le jeu is back for a second round with 37 new challenges. An evening you will remember for a long time ... or not!

Just shuffle the new challenge cards in with the rest of them and proceed as normal.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Party Game

name: Lines of Battle: Game of Napoleonic Tactics
description:
The battle lines have been drawn! Lines of Battle is a simple yet clever Napoleonic game system that allows tactical situations to be played out with a minimum of rules in a short amount of time. It's all here: Infantry, Cavalry, Artillery but also a challenging system of command/control that adds a chess like feel to an otherwise straightforward wargame.

Each of your three leaders projects a horizontal, vertical and diagonal line of command. The length of this line depends on a leader's rank.
A simple and concise chit pull system determines initiative while a bare bones D6 combat system moves battles along quickly and decisively across a 13 x 13 square battle grid.

Numerous ways to win include: Capturing your opponents objectives, eliminating leaders or simply inflicting more casualties than you receive. Includes 6 scenarios or you may build your own!

This is a free print n play game, our way of saying thanks to a wargaming community that is both friendly and helpful.
mechanics: Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement

name: SlapStick
description: In SlapStick, a group of 3 to 8 players read among 110 cards with silly "would you rather" style questions. Answer convincingly and the leader holds up the "slap stick" (literally a long stick with a foam five-finger hand) teasing it near the player's cheek. Answer incorrectly, and oh, boy...mayhem ensues.

name: Keep Calm: Expansion One
description:
The first expansion. More situations and a renewed decision to make (only this pack comes with an EXPLICIT CONTENT warning label): do you panic or keep calm?

Keep Calm is a party game where players vie to take control of situations by suggesting the best course of action to their friends in sticky situations. What do you do if your prom date turns into a werewolf? Keep calm and accept your mortality? Keep calm and give up on finding love?

In addition, players can play Panic cards to mess with gameplay in various ways, from skipping a judge to discarding responses.

The first person to take control of 6 situations wins!
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game
mechanics: Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection, Voting

name: Game of Phones: Expansion 002 – Materialism Pack
description: The second expansion pack to the wildly popular Game of Phones game, where there are 30 all-new cards to play with the main game. Game of Phones is a race to find the best or weirdest things on your smartphone to win. Tap faster, out-culture and think cooler than the people around you to win!
categories: Card Game, Electronic, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Party Game

name: Hervé Tullet's ZaZaZoom!: A Game of Imagination
description:
One part matching game, one part dominoes, plus loads and loads of fun, this game is both a clever challenge to hone memory skills and a make-your-own visual adventure of colorful play pieces. With the tour-de-force inventiveness which fuels his already-classics Press Here, Mix It Up!, and Let's Play!, Hervé Tullet's open-ended game stimulates creative thinking and fosters imagination.

This open-ended game fosters creative thinking and imagination with lots of different ways to play. Here are a few to get you started.

MATCHING GAME: A clever memory challenge for 2 or more players
Spread the cards out color-side down in 4 rows of 11 cards each. The youngest player goes first and turns over 2 cards. If the pictures match, the player gets to keep the cards and take another turn. If the pictures don’t match, the player turns the cards back over, and it is the next player’s turn. Players take turns flipping the cards over and looking for matches. The game ends when all the cards have been matched. The player with the most matches wins. Note: For younger children, the game can be played with fewer cards; try 24 or 32 cards. For a more difficult game, spread the cards out not in rows but in a random pattern!

ROADBUILDER: Matching up lines for 2 to 4 players
Locate 1 of the black-and-white crossroads cards and place it in the center of the table. Each player picks 1 of the 4 sides of the card to build from. Place the remaining cards in the deck color-side down. Players take turns drawing a card from the deck and placing them on the table color-side up, matching up the lines to make as long a “road” as possible from their side. If a player reaches a dead end, he or she sits out the rest of the round. When no player can continue their “road,” all players collect the cards they’ve played and set them aside. Repeat, building new “roads” until all the cards are exhausted. The player with the most cards wins!

PATTERNGROWER: A collaborative visual adventure for 1 or more players.
This game should be played on the floor or another large surface, because the designs can get very big! Using both sides of the cards, players work together to make the largest possible design while still matching up all the lines. Try playing with all cards color-side up. Or try placing each fourth card black-side up.

See if you can come up with some variations of these games on your own!

-description from publisher

name: Takers
description:
The National Bank has hidden a load of money in one of four possible locations — but you have the time to rob only one! Will you be smarter than the other players and pull off the heist of the century?

In Takers, players have five criminal cards from potentially four different locations in hand and will be able to play one per turn. Each gang is the best at robbing one place, is the second best at robbing another, and can't rob the remaining two.

At the beginning of the game, the four location cards are placed face down and one is put aside: it will be the place that will be robbed. On their turn, players can look at an incorrect location card to get info on the right one, but then they have to discard a card, having only four in hand until the end of the game, although maybe they will be able to play their cards for powers, allowing them to take back discarded cards, draw a card, then discard one,...

They can also chose to flip a jewel token. When all the jewel tokens matching the player colors have been placed face up, the game ends and players get points depending on what kind of criminals they have remaining in their hand.

name: Kenophobia
description:
After a long captivity you and your companions have an opportunity to recover freedom. You are imprisoned in a spaceship abandoned by your captors. You were abducted to be exhibited in a traveling alien circus, but now that the ship is about to become uninhabitable, your kidnappers have simply opened the cells and fled.

Kenophobia is a game of exploration and survival of 2 to 4 players with a duration of 40 minutes.
Each player will lead a group of five abductees through the corridors and compartments of the ship. The objective is to drive them to some of the exit locks before they lose all air or are self-destructing. The abductees must explore the environment to find the most direct route to the center of the ship, where the vacuum suits that allow them to leave it. Along the way, they can investigate, looking in the compartments for equipment that will help them achieve their goal.
They will soon discover that they are not alone. Other victims accompany them in their race for salvation. But they can not expect any help from them. Their appearance is mutually repulsive and there is also fear. The fear of the vacuum of space.

OBJECTIVE OF THE GAME: to draw the maximum number of units equipped with a vacuum suit through one of the four locks of the ship before the air runs out (when no more exploration tiles are left) or before the ship is self-destructed (when the countdown reaches the last turn).

A player can perform a maximum of two actions during his turn.
Each of the 5 abductees that manages can only be activated once per turn. That is, each unit can only perform one action per turn. The units can act together or alone.
An abductee activated by the player can perform one of the following actions:

Explore box in white
Move on ship and explored shippacks
Investigate ship sticker


—description from the designer

name: Utopia
description:
Theme
Utopia, according to Sir Thomas More, is a model society in all aspects. This educational game is built upon the Utopian ideal as well as the practical matters in real life such as making a living, setting a family, investment, etc. Through Utopia players realize the importance of opportunities, knowledge and possessions in attaining personal goals.

Gameplay
The game is divided into 7 cycles, starting at 15-20 (years) and ending at retirement. Each player chooses a Chart of Personal Possessions, a colored horse head marker and receives $3000. Placing their horse head at the bottom left corner of the starting zone, players roll two six sided dice and move the number of spaces equal to the difference between the two numbers. If doubles are rolled, players earn either money or a Utopia card as indicated by the chart printed on the board. At the end of each cycle (circuit of the board), players received a Utopian card and $1200 or their salary.

Goal
The goal of the game is to be the person who retires with the most points based on markers, money and price of property owned.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Rival 5
description:
Objective: To be the first player to get 5 chips in a row horizontally, vertically or diagonally.

How to Play: Each player selects 1 color of chips and may use only 1 chip per turn. Players take turns rolling the dice and must use all 3 dice. With any sequence or combination, players add, subtract, multiply and divide the 3 numbers to reach a number that will help them get 5 chips in a row while blocking their opponents from doing the same.

If a player rolls 3 dice of the same number (triplets), he plays that roll and gets an additional turn. If he rolls triplets again (on the same turn) he removes from the board 1 chip of each opponent, and the next person takes his turn. The first player to get 5 chips in a row horizontally, vertically, or diagonally wins.

There are 4 Levels of play – Progressive Skill Builder

Introductory: Play entire board
Basic: Play within Blue Lines
Intermediate: Play within Green Lines
Advanced: Play within Red Lines

name: Do Not Die
description:
The game, Do Not Die, is a tile game that focuses on managing player vitals and resources while simply trying to stay alive and find rescue.

Players can build shelters, loot cabins, hunt and fish for food, even cozy up to a nice campfire. But make no mistake, the goal here is survival. Players must stay alive and find their way out, even if that means player vs. player combat.

"Do Not Die" is fast paced and exciting with deep complexity and many available strategies. It makes all players compete against each other but also has the game itself as the primary challenger.

The mechanics involved push the players forward and if they lose sight of their primary objective, survival becomes impossible. It can also be played cooperatively, eventually joining player tiles. The game even has a vast and engaging solitary mode for single player action. (Game length = 60 minutes / Players = 1-5 / Ages = 10+)

This turn-based game uses Player Boards where each player manages four individual vitals; Temperature, Hunger, Thirst, & Fatigue. At the end of their turn, each player adds up the HP damage associated with each vital and subtracts it from their health meter. The Health Meter starts at thirty and once the player reaches zero, they lose.

The game also has a Main Game Board. The Main Game Board has Player Cards that sets the environment for each player and Weather Cards that control the weather for the day. Distributed in the Weather Deck, there are six Exposure Cards that increase the Exposure Level. This Exposure Level lowers each players vitals at the beginning of each player turn. The player must perform six actions each turn to try to counteract this effect and manage their vitals to avoid dying.

There are sixty-four tiles in this game that the player uncovers by using actions to explore their surroundings. They consist of the following:

Frozen Ground Tile - Used for hunting Varment for food +1
Frozen Lake Tile - Used for Fishing for food +1
Forest Tile - Used for hunting Small Game for food +4
Mountain Tile - Used for hunting Large Game for food +6
Cabin Tile - Used for looting Tools and Items
Fire Tower Tile - Used for Rescue

In order to gain helpful resources in the game, the player can craft things like campfires, shelters, water, and some simple tools using player actions. Other Items and Tools can be found in the game by revealing a Cabin Tile and looting it. Each player can only loot a revealed cabin once. When a cabin is looted, the player rolls one black die (for an Item Card) and two white dice (for Tool Cards). If they roll an even number, then they select the corresponding Tool or Item Cards from the decks. The goal always remains, Do Not Die.

name: Blau-Weiß-Turnier
description:
The 15 pawns are placed in the first line of the game board, indicated with an arrow. The pawns may move one space per turn or jump over as many opposite pawns as possible. Jumped over pawns are removed from the game as are pawns that don't jump when it is possible to do so. Movement and jumping on ones own side of the gameboad is only forward or sideward. On the opponents side of the game board moving and jumping is allowed in any direction.

The player who gets the most pawns onto the opposite half of the game board wins the game.

name: Feuerwehr-Spiel
description:
This is a roll-and-move-game. The players start at home (numbered houses). Then they have to go to the fire station, where they get a blue card with their mission order. On the way to their mission location they don't have to mind any obstacles, but on the way back to the fire station, if they land on a red spot, they have to draw a red mission card. The blue spots mark traffic jams where movement is only one spot per turn.

The first player back to the fire station wins the game.
The last player has to tidy away the game.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: King of Liriam
description:
King of Liriam is a tactical & strategic, cutthroat area control boardgame for 2-4 players in which players take the role of medieval house lords that want to conquer the fantastical realm called Liriam.

On their turn, players spend gold to buy units, orders, neutral forces or buildings from the deployment panel. The higher an item is on the deployment panel the higher the cost players must pay, but sometimes the cost must be paid to get out of a tricky situation, or gain an undisputed advantage.

Once players decide what to buy they must deploy the item on the map of Liriam and this is where the tactical and strategical layers surface in King of Liriam. Each unit features a combination of 2 traits, the way it enters the map and the ability it performs once arrived. For instance units can conquer new territories, patrol existing ones, or siege nearby enemy settlements.

The goal of the game is to own more territories than the enemy by the time the map fills.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Grid Movement, Take That

name: Cheat Code
description:
Summary
Players form a hidden pattern of 4 colors with their cubes and try to form 3 unique instances of their hidden pattern on the Matrix while simultaneously trying to solve their Rivals' patterns and block them.

Goal
To form 3 copies of your hidden pattern on the pixel grid

Setup
Form a pattern of 4 unique colors from the cube pile and keep it hidden from the other players E.g. Red, Blue, Green, Yellow

Gameplay
The player with the most colorful shirt goes first and places 1 cube of any color onto the board. Gameplay then proceeds clockwise. On their turn, each player must place 1 cube of any color orthogonally adjacent to another existing cube.

name: Flying Match
description:
A dexterity game for any number of persons - engrossing, dynamic and entertaining.

The ball is placed in the hollow provided in the launching pad. The pad is then slightly pressed down and released suddenly. If the ball passes through a hole in the turret and falls through it, the number of points won is that marked on the hole plus that marked on the hollow in the field the ball comes to rest in.

The players can either agree on a certain number of rounds or on a certain figure to be reached.

name: One Up This
description: You know how, when you're sitting around with friends, you inevitably start telling old stories and unofficially trying to one up each other? This game takes that typical night and turns it into a competitive event. Players tell their best true life stories on the card topic and try to one up each other. Players vote on the best story - the person with the most votes wins the round. The person who wins the most rounds is crowned the One Upper.

name: Blokeo
description:
ENGLISH:

The objective of the game is to block your opponent's pawn.
