The goal is to race your donkey down the track (9 spaces) across the finish line. On your turn, move your donkey and play an action card that can help you or hinder your opponent. It's stunningly simple, surprisingly quick and deceptively strategic!

One of the quickest games you'll play (average game play with 3 players is 15 minutes), and you'll be hoot'n and holler'n the whole time.

—description from the publisher
categories: American West, Animals, Print & Play, Racing
mechanics: Action Queue, Grid Movement, Take That

name: Dimensions of Discord Online
description:
You are a guild leader in the hottest new massively multiplayer online role-playing game: Dimensions of Discord Online.

Since you're just starting out, you will recruit players to your guild as you earn reputation, then send those players to slay monstrous foes in the world, clear perilous raids, and compete with each other in a PvP format — all to earn that sweet, sweet loot and reputation. Each turn, you can choose to recruit players to your guild, purchase items from the auction house, challenge a raid, hunt a monstrous foe, participate in a PvP contest, or upgrade your guild hall. Your players are online only during certain times of day, and you have to balance when and how to use them together!

Raids include a press-your-luck element in which you have the chance to accrue a large amount of loot, reputation, and potentially, equipment, but only if you exit the raid before your party wipes! Monstrous foes are singular fights against powerful enemies that appear randomly. PvP allows you to wager on 2-on-2 battles between your guild members, and upgrading your guild hall provides various bonuses, not the least of which is increasing your maximum number of guild members!

The game ends after a certain number of turns. Can you accrue the most reputation to become the best guild on your server?
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Push Your Luck

name: Art Auction
description:
The Concept

The game was originally conceived with standard playing cards in my book 52+ New Card Games. I designed 20 cards with famous artwork and added some bad art and a set of forgery cards. Money cards are also included for players to make bids.

The Game

Players begin by getting three Forgery Cards and then choosing one each. The chosen Forgery Cards are set aside until the end of the game. Each Forgery Card matches each of the Art Cards.

Eight Art Cards are then chosen randomly and players look at all of them before the game begins so that a strategy can be considered. The eight Art Cards are then shuffled and put into a pile called the Catalog. Each player then gets ten Money Cards.

Play is done in rounds. For each round, the top Art Card from the Catalog is revealed and players make an initial bid. Players can then increase their bids until a winner for the round is determined. Special Cards can also be played during the round. Rounds continue until each Art Card is revealed and bid upon.

The challenge of the game is to win high priced artworks without running out of money or taking in a forgery.

At the end of the game, the Forgery Cards are revealed and their matching Art Cards are eliminated. Players then count up the values of the Art Cards they possess. The player with the highest value of art is the winner.

—description from the designer

name: Dhow
description:
A game played with a standard double-six or double-nine set of dominoes (depending on desired map size and game length).

The tiles (or dominoes cards) form a grid map of a virtual fictionalized Indian Ocean, and players manipulate wooden bits reprenting trade empires, merchant houses, and the sailing ships (dhow) that they'll use to accomplish the objective of having a majority representation (most merchant houses) in each of the expanding empires - without knowing which will be the largest and which will score the most before the game ends.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Auction/Bidding, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Trading

name: ゾンビマスター (Zombie Master)
description:
User summary
Abstract game from Japan, where the player first moves one of their own pieces, and then changes the direction of one of their opponent's pieces.

Publisher's summary
ゾンビマスター (Zombie Master) is a Japanese two player game where the two players are Zombie Masters! They will fight with their hordes of zombies to defeat and triumph over the other master.

But the zombies are quite stupid. Not only they will only move forward, but what's worse, they easily get distracted and change direction on their own depending on the opponent's movements.

ゾンビマスターとなったプレイヤーが敵のゾンビマスターを倒すため、自分のゾンビを操り戦うゲームです。
ゾンビは前に進むことしかできず、相手のゾンビの動きに反応して勝手に向きを変えてしまいます。

name: BullHockey! (Denver Coliseum 1972)
description:
In this 2P Sport & Logistics game each player is the Owner/Manager of a minor league hockey team in 1972, skating together as bitter rivals in the Denver Coliseum. The western league is on the rise & this contest could help put it on the map among HOCKEY's elite. However! In the same building: The Stock Show & Rodeo is preparing to open AND the BULLS have all escaped in chaos & are stampeding the rink. Manage your team & crew to profit from this unique situation. The puck must drop, so there will be a winner-- but today there might be BULLS.

GOAL: Have the most $$ after 3 periods of hockey

Players compete on several fronts to put some $$ on the scoreboard by a variety of mechanisms:

AREA CONTROL: Use barricades to control the four quadrants of the hockey rink in order to manipulate the routing of BULLS.

ROLL & MOVE: Each quadrant is subdivided into 16 sectors where actions may be selected by the end location of the erratic & rapid transit of the PUCK token. The PUCK moves according to hockey actions, it can be moved by TIME CARDS & PLAYER CARDS and it can travel by a strict P1/P2 roll & move procedure.

SIMULATION: Players compete in statistically realistic head-to-head hockey combat based in an abstracted dice & block war-game system. The puck-shaped timer cards provide situational responses as well acting as the "clock" for each period of hockey. Once the deck is depleted, the buzzer sounds.

STOCK HOLDING: Each barricade & player card are shares of the team & league value indexes represented by a 2-Axis 'tug of war' pawn index tracking the scaled value of each team's contribution to the night & establishing current market prices for removing bulls & scoring goals. The index is driven by the categorical accumulation of player actions. Judicious buy/sell strategies may be required.

HAND MANAGEMENT: Players must manage the multi-purpose TIMER CARDS & HOCKEY PLAYER CARDS for more effective operations in each phase of play, as well as more control over deterministic mechanisms within the game.

CAN ALSO BE PLAYED SOLO VS. THE AUTOMATED CONSOLE
NOTE: This speculative scenario is statistically & historically plausible & reflects accurately a confluence of scheduling in Denver, CO, January 1972.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation, Stock Holding

name: Jarebon
description:
Welcome to the fabulous world of short short story!

The players will write a short short story all together.
But it is not a difficult thing. Because we prepare a special
notebook only for writing a strange short short story.

The player can write the paragraph by just reading the previous one. Each player cannot read the whole story, so the story will be
changing little by little.

After the players wrote 8 paragraphs, it's done.
Let's read the story that all of you had just written now and laugh!

name: ウサギの都市計画 (Usagi no Toshi Keikaku)
description:
User summary
ウサギの都市計画 (Usagi no Toshi Keikaku) is a Japanese game for two players, about Rabbits' city planning.

The rabbits' civilization was so flourishing that they establish a city-state. In order to expand their territory, they began working on internal affairs and invasion.

Usagi no Toshi Keikaku is a two-player card game.

Each turn, both players choose four cards from five action cards, and place them face-down in order of their choice. Both player reveal their first cards simultaneously and take their actions, but some actions can negate other actions the opponent played, in which case negated action has no effect. Actions allow you gain resource, spend resouce to construct a building, etc. Repeat the process until their fourth actions are resolved, then next turn begins.

You immediately win the game if you have total of 10 points or more by constructing buildings.

Publisher's summary
ウサギの文明は栄え、都市国家を形成するまでになった。
更に文明を拡大せんとウサギたちは内政や外征に勤しんだ。

アクションプロット式のビルディングゲームです。
上手く行動を選択し相手より先に10勝利点獲得をめざします。
categories: Ancient, Animals, Card Game, City Building, Civilization

name: ウサギの火星劇団 (Usagi no Kasei Gekidan)
description:
User summary
ウサギの火星劇団 (Usagi no Kasei Gekidan) is a Japanese two player game about the Rabbits' theater company on Mars.

The rabbits who have departed into Space finally landed on Mars, where they built a theater, and eastablished a theater company.

Usagi no Kasei Gekidan is a two-player card game using a rondel. Each player has three cards, each of which shows a number of members and their belonging classes (colored with red, green, or yellow), face-up in front of that player. Each turn, you choose your action by advancing your pawn one or two sectors in the rondel wheel. Actions allow you reform your members or compete with your opponent with a specific class.

At the end of the game, you score points depending on how many competitions you won for each class, and the higher scorer wins the game.

Each card has a special effect which is activated during the game, or earns you additional points if you have it at end of the game.

Publisher's summary
宇宙に旅立ったウサギ達は火星に降立ち、
そこで劇場と劇団を創り興行を開始した。

ロンデルを回して行動を決定し、
ウサギの団員を集めます。
団員の組み合わせで3種の興行を多く成功させましょう。
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management, Rondel, Set Collection

name: Journal of an Outlaw: The Forbidden Treasure of Miftenmad
description:
Yahtzee mixes with D&D in this fast-paced, fun, dice-rolling game based on the popular Journal of an Outlaw book series!
Each character plays a rogue trying to open a treasure chest that is protected by 10 locks. Each player takes turns rolling their polyhedral dice to see if they make the combination and open the locks. If unsuccessful at opening a lock, they arm a trap. They get one more chance to pick the lock, and failure means taking damage!

Players take turns trying to open their treasure chest, they are not only trying to get the treasure, but must also live to the end! Hit points are exchanged for gold at the end of the game. Whoever winds up with the most gold wins! There are also special skills that can be earned to help your rogue achieve success.

—description from the publisher

name: ガイスターギャモン (Geister Gammon)
description:
Publisher's summary
ガイスターギャモン (Geister Gammon) is a game for two people combining Geister and Backgammon. Of course it is a matter of Backgammon to make points and race and aim for the goal.

But you can also aim for different ways of victory with a Geister element, such as hitting a bad ghost.

name: Headhunters Inc.
description:
Players try to hire the most productive employees to produce the most resources.

Equipment: 2 or 3 decks of cards (jokers removed) shuffled together; a sheet of paper per player to keep score (one column for bids; three for suits club, diamond, heart [spades are wild-added to other suits]; and rows for employees' cost/production values).

Game play: each round, 2 cards are dealt in the center of the table: the first is the cost of the employee, the second is the amount the employee will produce per round. Bidding takes place; the highest bid wins the employee and becomes the cost of the employee per round. After bidding is over, players add the production amount of their employees (if any) to the appropriate suit column, and subtract the cost employees (if any) from the matching column. Asign a suit to add Spades to.

Selling: once four employees are hired, the company can be sold. All resources are added and that number of points given. If resources are in negative numbers, those are subtracted from the points to pay off debt. Half of employees are shuffled back into the draw pile.

Goal: to have the most points after 20 rounds, or the lowest negative resources.

name: The Heroic Legend of Arslan (Pocket Edition)
description: Pocket edition of the homonymous big-box game: The Heroic Legend of Arslan (アルスラーン戦記　盤上演義), with some bonus contents.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Cooperative Game, Role Playing

name: Get With The Program
description:
The future has arrived. The first artificially intelligent robots have come online. Unforeseen instability splits their source code apart and two new programs emerge; one good and one evil. Will they be mankind’s greatest strength or its destruction? Our fate is in their hands.

Get with the Program is a deduction game with a unique blind team mechanic for 4 to 8 players. You take on the role of an artificially intelligent robot vying for the fate of humanity. At the beginning of the game all players will work together to secretly assign each other in to two teams. Good robots and evil robots. Because this is done in secret no one knows what team they are on. The good robots want stability by decrypting robots with pure code. The evil robots want to sow instability by installing corrupt code.

Game play consists of two phases. During phase one players assign code cards to robot cards by placing code cards face down below robot cards. A robot’s programming is complete when it has 3 code cards. These code cards determine which team that player is on. During phase two, players will be revealing code cards to discover which team the robots are on. As code cards are revealed they will score stability points. Two code cards of the same color will give one point to the blue team. If the code cards are different colors the Red team will score a point. Instead of a revealing a code card a player can place a tracking chip. If they are on the blue team they are trying to match a player to their robot card. Red players want robots to be guessed incorrectly. Play continues until one team has reached enough stability points to win the game.

name: SPL Battlegrounds: The Legends Edition
description:
SPL Battlegrounds: Legends Edition allows you to build the systems of car audio legends like Alma Gates, the Grandmother of car audio! The objective of this game is to have a blast building the systems of car audio legends using the cards in your hand, the cards you draw, or the cards you 'buy'. The challenge is to be the one at the end of the hand and ultimately, the end of the game, who has racked up the highest score. Scoring in this game is calculated by db (decibels) as measured in car audio competitions as the SPL (sound pressure level) of your system.

Suitable for children under 12 with adult assistance, and crazy fun for the whole family! Customize your fun by setting your own time, goal or scoring limits. Each Legend's card offers unique legendary abilities such as drawing 4 cards per turn instead of three, reducing the cost of buying class cards, or allowing you to fish cards from the discard pile.

Each player is dealt a hand of cards and can take a number of actions on their turn such as drawing cards from the draw deck and discard pile, buying a class card / legendary card to build on, buying a 2x amplifier card, building on a class, closing a class and ending a turn by discarding. As you move along in the game you add subwoofers and amplifiers to complete your system and close it out,gaining bonus points for each build you've completed. Once the draw deck runs out, players add up their points to see who is the champion.

Created by car audio guru Donald Hebig (dBDon) and his wife Ferne (Nerfblat), the world's first and only car audio card game is a great way to share a love for car audio with family and friends.

—description from the designer

name: Crazy Queens
description:
Classic card game fun for the whole family!
Outwit your opponents and attempt to score the most points possible in this family friendly game.

The Queen of Spades is worth 10 times what the other queens are worth, and with only three available to collect it's a crazy fight to the finish. Play every person for themselves, or divide into two even teams. To play cards into your/your team's bank that aren't already in play, you need to have a minimum of three of a kind or two with one wild card. Once a collection is started for a number in the bank, each player of your team that follows can add as many cards to the bank as they may have in their hand. For example, if your team could not yet collect queens because no one had laid any in the bank, and on your turn, you put three queens in the bank, the next player in your team to play, can add a single queen on top of that pile. Every card laid in your team's bank counts as points for your team, while every card remaining in your hand counts against your team at the end of the hand. The goal is to be the first team to get to 1600 points.

What's your playing style? Do you hold on to those high scoring cards, never discarding them? Do you play with risky strategy, only banking three of a kind when you actually have five? Will you end the round and catch the other team with handfuls of cards to count against them? This game can get as crazy and entertaining as you make it.

This deck of 162 cards (three unique and custom designed decks of 54 playing cards including Jokers) will allow play for 2-8 players. The instructive rule book is user friendly and easy to follow.

As a bonus, you can split the cards into three standards playing decks to use playing your other favorite card games!

name: BN1: Escape From The Lanes
description:
BN1: Escape From The Lanes is the first bagged mini-game from Bedsit Games. Designed to be quick to play, easy to set up and highly portable, it comes as a fold-over A3 sheet containing the board and the rules, contained inside a resealable polythene bag along with all the playing pieces, tokens and dice required.

2-4 players must race to get all 4 of their pawns out of the labyrinthine Lanes. Players can hide in shops and attempt to knock enemy pawns back to the start. A simple and tactical game for ages 8 and above.

HOW TO PLAY:
Players must compete to get their 4 pawns out of the maze-like Lanes. The first player to get 1 pawn out of each exit wins. Players roll dice to move a pawn each turn. If they land on a coffee shop they take another turn. If they land on an antique shop they can hide until its safe to come out. Players can also fast-travel the board through the use of sewers.

During the game, players will accrue numbered coins which can protect them if another player lands on one of their pawns. If they hold a coin bearing the number rolled, they can send the opposing pawn back to the start.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: ZomBN1: Sewage Panic
description:
ZomBN1 Sewage Panic is the second of Bedsit Games' bagged mini-games, designed to be quick to play, easy to set up and very portable. A co-operative game for 1-4 players, Sewage Panic takes place inside Brighton's sewer network while the action of the main game rages in the streets above. Survivors must fight, scavenge and craft their way through ever-increasing waves of zombies. Can they survive until sunrise? This fold-out A3 board comes with rulebook, plastic playing pieces, 60 cards and even a bonus game on the back. Limited to 250 copies.

HOW TO PLAY:
A co-operative game, players must work together to survive the zombie hordes. Players each get 2 actions per turn, which can be spent moving around the sewer base, fighting a zombie, scavenging for scraps, or crafting those scraps into survival tools.

Each player has a coloured pawn, which means they can attack any like-coloured tiles (so a red pawn can attack red tiles and so on), so some tactical manoeuvring is required to make the best use of fighting, scavenging and crafting.

Some turns, players will come across equipment which can be added to what they manage to craft. Other turns an unfortunate event will occur, which can see zombies gaining in number, or survivors being hindered.

When all players have used their actions, all zombies on the board move one space towards the base, then more spawn depending on how many turns have been taken. The more turns, the more zombies will spawn.

If a zombie reaches the base then the players have lost. If they make it through 20 turns then mop up any remaining zombies, then they have won.

NB: If you have a copy of ZomBN1: A Board Game All About Brighton, then you can use the components from that game to replace the standard plastic pieces with this.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Set Collection, Turn Order: Time Track

name: Rollbahn to Nowhere
description:
Rollbahn to Nowhere is a game about KG Peiper in the Ardennes, from Stavelot to La Gleize and Stoumont.

Units are platoons and companies (artillery only). One hex is 300m. One turn is 2 hours (day) or 4 hours (night).

The game begins the 18 of December 1944 and ends the 24 of december (one week of fight).

RtN is a DTP game. It is free.

—description from the designer

name: Battlecraft: Paper Combat
description:
Welcome to BattleCraft: Paper Combat, a game of skill and strategy set in a world at war.

Build your followers and lead them in the battle to free Jurop.... or conquer it!

THE BATTLE FOR JUROP
All heck has broken loose across the planet as the second big war rages on. The Black X army, led by Durp Furror has embarked on a campaign called the Third Strike to conquer Jurop. Nothing seems to stop them as they send their forces into nearby villages to beat up old men and steal candy from babies. With their modern machines of mechanized mayhem they seek to enslave the entire globe under their malevolent rule. At first, other nations were content to stay out of the war, but with the Third Strike's reach growing ever closer, they find themselves thrust into the conflict.

—description from the publisher

Battlecraft: Paper Combat is the third edition of FlipIt Paper Combat. Most mechanisms have undergones some changes, and the coin fliping mechanic is completely gone, hence the name change.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Point to Point Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Mucho Deck: Francais –  English
description:
This educational card game will have players practicing their speaking and listening skills in either French or English. Game-play will have them asking for and receiving cards. Players receive points when they get an opponent's card. The player with the most points wins.

The cards are divided in two suits and each suit has pairs of cards numbered 1 to 13 and with 13 different colors. The web page has many game templates that can be used to have the cards represent targeted grammar or vocabulary.
Great for the language classroom or at home with your family.

name: Embargo
description:
Embargo is a 2-6 player game where players run their own logistics company and compete to complete as many contracts as possible.

Each player is represented with a player board, there they can hold freight at their warehouse and accept and fulfill contracts.

In the middle of the table is the Transport Hub containing red, blue, black, green, yellow and white cubes. This represents freight for the different industries and contracts available in the contract deck. There are contract deck of cards that outline goals for the players. Players use an action-checklist to take pick up contracts and move freight from the hub to the warehouse and onto contracts.

To fulfill a contract, players must place that much of the required freight colour onto the corresponding contract on their control board. Each contract has a certain number of victory points attached to it as well as engine building bonuses.

The player that reaches 25 victory points first wins.

-description from designer

name: Constellation Cosplay
description: A free print and play game to be played at conventions. Each player or team prints out a copy of the game, then writes a character you might see someone dressed up as next to each constellation. Whenever you see someone with that cosplay, fill in one star for that constellation. Challenge your friends to see who fills in their page first!
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Exploration, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Print & Play, Real-time, Science Fiction, Video Game Theme

name: Empires: D10 Edition
description:
Empires: D10 Edition follows from the popular Empires: Core Rules rulebook, but with one BIG exception, a diced wargame mechanic; the first published diced wargame from War of Life Gaming.

Immerse yourself in the living rulebook that brings diversity to the old world; fighting Greek Hoplites with Napoleon’s Hussars, or Praetorian Cavalry with Templar Knights, or Elves with Dwarves.

Defeat you're opponents with tactical prowess and superior skill. Using small to large units of troops, ranging from the ancients to the Napoleonics and from any scale, you hope to weaken the enemy so that they flee, or are wiped out.

Empires is suitable for all war-gamers, beginner or veteran; as the rules can be basic or advanced depending on how many upgrades are taken for each unit; and with over 16 unit types/variances, and more than 50 upgrades/modifiers, no battles will be the same.

As a core rulebook, players are able to take the rules and expand on them, introducing new armies or wargear at their own leisure; to share with others and/or for their own entertainment.

The Empires rulebook is a guideline only. You take control of the game.

—description from the publisher
categories: Ancient, Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Konkvest
description:
Konkvest is a chess-type board game specifically made to be played by two players. It is played on a hexagonal board with 142 tiles, as players alternate taking their turns to move their pieces. The tiles are distributed in 13 rows, the middle row has 12 tiles in total and each subsequent row on the higher and the lower level has one tile less, ending with 6 tiles in the final rows. There are additional 28 tiles with specific use defined in the manual.

The game is intended to serve as an official chess in the fantasy world of Atharon. After its conception, the game took on a life of its own and, rather than remaining just a footnote and a mere mention in the world of Atharon, it became a fully-realized project.

Since its intention is to basically be Atharon chess, it's played similarly to the regular game of chess we all know. Players alternate turns moving their pieces across the board in accordance with the rules of movement. The rules of movement are too complicated to be described in text so they are explained in pictorial form in the rulebook.

The main goal is to win the game by beating the opponent by toppling his Queen. Alternative ways include capturing the opponent's base by placing one's Queen on the specific tile the opponent's Queen started off, which is easier said than done. Another alternative way to win the game is to force the opponent's timer to expire.

By standard a Konkvest game is timed using a 10 minute hourglass, which is balanced out at the start of the game so each player has 5 minutes at his disposal. Once set, the hourglass is laid horizontally. The player who makes the first move lifts the hourglass vertically and the time measurement begins. At that moment, the top chamber of the hourglass represents the time available to the second player. Once the second player makes his move, he flips the hourglass upside down so his chamber is at the bottom. Then it's the first player's turn again. The more one player spends on thinking, the less time he will have for future moves and the more time he will provide to his opponent, and vice versa. The player who's time runs out loses the game.

During his turn, a player can do one of the following things:
1.) He can move one of his pieces according to the rules of movement on a different tile. If that piece ends its move within that player's promotional zone and hasn't captured an opponent piece, the player can promote that piece. If that piece ends its move on a tile occupied by an opponent's piece, the player takes that piece and adds it into his reserve pool, effectively capturing it. The only piece that cannot be captured is the Queen, once she's toppled the game is over.
2.) He can pick up one of his pieces from his reserve pool and return it on the board as an active piece, strictly within the territory he currently controls.

At the end of his turn, the player flips the hourglass and then it's his opponent's turn to do the same procedure.

Konkvest is an abstract battle simulation, meaning all of its resources are limited. Players have a limited amount of pieces and a limited amount of movement, they have a limited amount of spots in their reserve pool and they have a limited amount of time to spend on making their move.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Grid Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Mad Dog Cards
description:
Mad Dog Cards is a fun, family friendly game for 2-6 players from age 7+. Mad Dog Cards was created to increase awareness of how many animals are sad, lonely, and even "mad", awaiting a forever home. A "Mad Dog" represents a homeless or shelter dog.
Mad Dog Cards is a simple card game. The main objective is find a "Mad Dog" a home or owner. Players take turns drawing cards and completing up to 2 actions. If a "Mad Dog" card is drawn, player must find an owner. If the player can't find it a home or owner, that player loses. The winner is the last man standing.
Yellow personality cards are collected to swipe other players' cards or even retrieve cards from the discard deck. Action cards are used to stack the game in one's favor. One can choose to pick on a player and force their hand in playing a "Mad Dog." However, with a "Crazy Cat Lady" card, there is no telling how a setup will turn out!

name: Faerie Haven
description:
"The Fast Fun Card game, designed by David Harmer (author of Aftermath! Technology!, Aftermath! Magic!, and Aftermath! Survival Guide). This single-deck card game is a quick to learn game for 2-6 players. Only 5 minutes to learn, but can be played for hours. Many of the cards change the game rules, but the details are printed on the card."

-- publisher description


From the publisher's former website, as of 2002:

" Faerie Haven Basic Deck - Faerie Haven is a Single Deck Card game for 2-6 players. The basic deck includes 78 cards, each with their own unique artwork, and a simple Rule Book. Price: $USD 12.00

Faerie Haven Limited Edition Expansion - The Faerie Haven Limited Edition Expansion is the first Faerie Haven Expansion Set! Originally produced for Chatton XXVII, the response was so well recieved we decided to offer them for sale! This Expansion adds 12 new cards each with their own unique artwork to the Faerie Haven Basic Deck (FH-012002s), and upgrades 3 Heroes and 1 Item. Only 2000 of these Limited Edition Expansions will be printed, so be sure and get your copy today! - Price: $USD 3.00

Faerie Haven Collectors Pack Volume 1 - The Faerie Haven Collectors Pack Volume 1 contains the Faerie Haven Basic Deck (FH-012002s) and the Limited Edition Expansion (Fh-012002CHE). Only 2000 Limited Editon Expansions will be printed, so be sure and get yours today! - Price: $USD 14.00 "


After the publisher Mushroom Circle Games shut down their website, this card game was then sold online through the Fantasy Games Unlimited website. The shrink-wrapped deck of cards had card backs marked "FH", and included the first expansion which adds new cards to the game.

name: Tarzan Lord of the Jungle
description:
Lord of the Jungle is a cooperative game for 1 to 4 players that can be played in 60 to 90 minutes.

In this thematic adventure game, you play as Tarzan, Jane, and their allies. Lay out cards to create a map of Africa, and then fight your way across the map to reach the lost city of Opar! Each map card that you choose in your journey reveals your next encounter. Each encounter pits you against a specific tile layout, and an assortment of enemies and interactive 3D trees. Fight enemies by using your equipment cards and rolling dice.

Be careful to keep Tarzan and Jane out of danger. If either of them perish, the game is lost! If you're able to fight through the scenarios and make your way to Opar, all that's left in front of you is a final boss fight. Work together and take down the boss to win the game!

-description from designer
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board

name: Zombie Apocalypse
description:
Zombie Apocalypse is a light roll-and-move game in which you must navigate through a building filled with zombies and escape to safety.

At the start of the game, a gun is randomly placed on the board via die roll and 6 zombies are placed in the indicated starting positions. You move by rolling a dice and moving that number of squares on the board - which can be diagonal or orthogonal movement. The zombies also move by die roll with each result indicating the direction they'll move.

If you're able to find the gun you can shoot the zombies, but otherwise you must just carefully avoid them and try to reach the bomb shelter on the far side of the board.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Halloween
description:
In Halloween, each player is a monster trying to be the first to capture a human in the center of the board. The game uses a simple roll and move mechanic to advance along the track, but if you hit a space with a dot in it, you will have to draw a card - which could send you a certain number of spaces forward or backward.

Each card has instructions for each monster on it. You will just read the instruction relevant to you. If you run out of cards, shuffle the discard pile to form a new draw deck.

The first player to reach the center of the board is the winner!
categories: Children's Game, Horror, Print & Play, Zombies
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: AARU
description:
In AARU players take on the role of one of the great and powerful Egyptian deities trying to draw worthy souls to their particular celestial palace in the Field of Reeds. To gather souls the gods play a game called AARU. Souls are won by winning tricks.

The souls of the Pharaohs are the most sought after by the gods. To win a Pharaohs soul you must deduce the value of one hidden card you own! Every time a player plays a card that could have been the Pharaoh card the opponents shout AARU!

AARU is a trick-taking deduction game for 2 to 4 players aged 8+. Each game takes 15 to 30 minutes to play.

GAME OVERVIEW

A game of AARU is played over 3 rounds and points are scored by winning tricks and by deducing and playing your Pharaoh card at the right time! Points can be lost if a Pharaoh is played incorrectly.

At the start of each round the players are dealt a hand of cards. All players pick a Pharaoh for the opponent to their left and add it to the opponents hand facing away from them.

In turn, players play a card from their hands with the highest value of the leading type played winning unless a Power card has beaten it. The twist is that in AARU whenever a player could have played their Pharaoh card (the one that faces away from them) the other Players say AARU to them to indicate they missed the chance of playing their Pharaoh. This way they can eventually deduce when is the best time to play their Pharaoh card for bonus points!

Points are totaled for each of the three rounds with the winner being declared by having the most points at the end.

name: Siege!
description:
In Siege!, one player controls an army that is attacking a castle and trying to capture the other player's king. The other player is defending.

Pieces in the turn are placed upside-down to hide their values. Each player has 10 pieces ranging in value from 1 to 4. The king is placed on a marked square on the far side of the board. Each turn, the players choose one piece and move it one square orthogonally (there is no diagonal) movement in the game.

When a piece moves adjacent to an opponent piece, the values of both are revealed and the lower one is removed. There are also "trap" units which will automatically eliminate any unit they are adjacent to.

The game ends when the defending king is captured or when the the invaders run our of pieces.
categories: Deduction, Fighting, Medieval, Memory, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Grid Movement, Memory, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Shipping & Chartering
description:
Tactical trading and travel game for 2 to 6 people.

The players each receives a colored ship owner (character) and the appropriate charge! The locomotion occurs with a W6 in five trades.
The shipowner can buy ships in cash or on credit on his train, the ship arrives at the home port of the corresponding area.

There are various instructions on "telex" cards, which means: "travel" the voyages from port to port and "round trips" the voyages from the home port to a destination port and back to the home port.
Only fully loaded ships can travel, if they are not fully loaded, they will cost you a "mooring fee" every time the player rolls a dice!

If you have his charge (you get this in certain fields of the orbit!) Completely, then the color chips are turned with the closed side up.
The shipowner and all his loaded ships move forward after rolling the dice with the thrown number on all their ways.
Ships can be bought or sold in their home port, and the area of use can also be changed.

A charter ship and the possible meetings of the ships in the same fields bring some additional options in the game.
You agree on the end of the game at a certain time, who then has the highest total amount wins the game.

—user summary

name: Da Capo
description:
Is a quite elaborate music quiz in which the 2 - 5 players on several colored tracks with their 1 - 3 figures draw and depending on the field and train different technical questions to the music must answer!
The questions are on 30 cards, they are all designed with pictures, you do not need to read aloud!
The rules are very detailed and written in five languages (German, French, English, Italian, Dutch)!

There are several game variants:

the game with question cards and cassette
the game without cassette:
Variant 1: the player determines his number of dice himself
Different conditions apply here, the rule contains examples.

It is played without a game board, either with cassette and playing cards or just with the question cards


The game ends when you play with the board when a player has all of his pieces in the finish field!
In the other variants, the correct answers are rewarded with chips, whoever has the most chips in the end, wins or the one who can first drop his cards he has received!

—user summary

name: Kingdom
description:
Kingdom is a solitaire game. The rightful king has been killed by a usurper. You are a farmboy who is determined to get revenge for your beloved king.

You must travel to several different areas of the kingdom and solve problems for the inhabitants there. By doing this, you can eventually raise a mercenary army to overthrow the usurper.

Typically, the game uses a pickup and deliver mechanic. You will identify what the inhabitants of a certain area of the Kingdom need, and then find and bring that item to them. (You need to remember what they need since there is no reminder when you leave their area.)

The game does not use typical movement rules. You are free to travel from anywhere in the kingdom to anywhere in the kingdom on your turn.

You win the game by raising the mercenary army and moving into the castle.

name: Running with the Bulls: The Big Game Convention
description:
Everyone who has ever been to "The Big Game Convention" knows what it's like trying to get into the exhibitor hall when the doors first open.

Well, now you'll have a reason to run! In the Running with the Bulls: The Big Game Convention mini-expansion, the bulls from the city of El Toro are charging and you need to get out of the way. Replace one of the restaurant cards with "The Big Game Convention" card, and you are ready to play...
categories: Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game

name: Menu Masters: Tofu
description:
Sometimes a chef runs out of an ingredient, but being resourceful, you have decided to substitute tofu for the required ingredient.

With the Menu Masters: Tofu mini-expansion in play, when completing a menu card, a tofu card can substitute for any ingredient of the same type.

name: Baketage Museum
description:
To get out of Baketage Museum (バケタージュ美術館), you must first free the four ghosts that are guarding the exits — and to do that, you must find the paired objects where these ghosts have placed their spirit.

To set up the game, create the stage inside the game box, then place your phone in the stage once you've downloaded the app needed for the game. Place the cards in a circle around the stage, then place each of the playing figures on a separate card.

On a turn, you roll the die, then move your figure the indicated number of spaces in either direction. You then take the card you've landed on and any other card in the circle and you hold those cards near your face within view of the phone's camera. The app reads the image on the back of each card and transforms each half of your face in some way. Perhaps your left eye grows to an enormous balloon, while your right eye curls like a rainbow. If the cards don't transform your face in the same eye, you return them to their places in the circle, with everyone else remembering what they saw on your face. Perhaps they should tell a story about what the objects you saw in the museum and why they made you look that way.

If you don't make a match, you lose one of your life tokens, and if someone runs out of tokens, you lose the game. If you do find a match, then great! Remove those cards from play. You're one step closer to escaping the museum.

The app randomizes which cards have which effects each game.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Memory, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Rawkahh! Launch
description:
To win the game by leaving the planet with most points before the meteor hits the planet!

Each player gets 6 game cards and an action card, while the crystals are store in the tin

Depending on how many players are playing, 2-5 game cards will be dealt in the center

All players can choose to scavenge for materials or raid other player’s warehouse by showing their action card altogether
Players that are aiming for the same card during scavenging needs to battle each other to win the card
There are 3 mini games to choose for battle!

At the diplomacy phrase, players can trade/forge/assemble/mine

The game will end in 3 turns when 2 “Doomsday” card are dealt

Players that are able to build a spaceship can tally up the points and the most points wins!

Make allies or betray them! There could be 2 or more winners or no one wins!

—description from the publisher

name: Rawkahh! Whiz
description:
Each player starts with 1pc 8 sided and 10 sided white dice
Vote for a player to go first and choose 1 of 2 actions

Re roll the Green or Red 10 sided dice, can re roll both
Call out A, B, or C and reveal a game card from deck

When the game card is revealed, all players can solve the equation by arranging the dice to provide the missing variables!

Players who got the right equation wins the card, they are disqualified for that round if they got it wrong
1 card = 1 point, players with most card wins

Games end when no more cards can be drawn or players can set the match point!

—description from the publisher

name: Rawkahh! Oops
description:
Draw 4 characters and place on the side
A starting player can choose 1 of 3 actions
A. Redraw the 1 to 4 character cards
B. Challenge a player to win their card by playing the mini games
C. Flip a game card to start the fun!
If there is a matching character between the character card and game card, players can yell the character names/species to win the card
When 2 or more players yell the correct match at the same time, we can refer this as “collide”
These players need to quickly yell “Oops!” and yell the matching names again
The player who is left standing wins the card!
Players that yells the wrong match will be disqualified for that round and if they are disqualified for 3 rounds in a roll, they lose 1 card

1 card = 1 point, most point wins the games when no more card can be drawn!

—description from the designer

name: Från ingenting till randig tandkräm
description:
Litteral translation of title: "From nothing to striped toothpaste".

The game starts at nothing, before light and dark, and ends with the invention of striped toothpaste. A pedagogical game about the meaning of life and the purpose of humankind.

Cards follow a sequence a'la dominoes. A turn consists of the player who has the next card in sequence on hand placing it on the table. This player then has the choice of playing an event card, making players switch cards in various ways.

The goal of the game is to lay out all the cards, depicting a sort of evolution. The winner being the player who places the "striped toothpaste" card. Box contains 76 cards.

name: Hive Mind: Dice Tower 4 card promo set
description: This set of 4 Hive Mind cards were created for the 2018 Dice Tower Kickstarter campaign. They add 24 new pop culture based questions to the base game. Many question were based on suggestions from The Dice Tower.

name: Lifeform: Calibos
description:
Lifeform: Calibos is a modular big-box expansion that adds many new elements to the main game:


The option to add a fifth player - who starts on the Crew team...
The occupants of Bay Twelve - six new Crew mining company characters, who have just been woken from their sleep-pods.
An extra secondary role: a murderous Rogue Synthetic who helps the alien lifeform.
Cooperative mode - so that ALL players are starship Crewmembers against the extraterrestrial threat.
And many new cards to expand the existing decks.
categories: Bluffing, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Horror, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Points, Hand Management, Point to Point Movement, Secret Unit Deployment, Team-Based Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Mensch verdrück' dich!
description:
The players have to get their 4 pawns from the spaces of their color on the light blue "strategic field" to the yellow space ringed by their color and from there around the game board to their destination spaces.

On the strategic field movement is one space per turn. Movement is blocked by other pawns.

On the track around the game board, movement is determined by a die. If a pawn gets on a space on the outer track, which is already occupied by an opponent's pawn, the later is thrown out and has to start anew.

—user summary
mechanics: Grid Movement, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Das Karussell des Lebens
description:
The Players have to get their 5 pawns from their starting spaces on the blue ring to their destination spaces in the center of the game board. Movement is determined by 2 dice for 2 pawns each turn.

After completing a turn around the game board, the pawns reach a big numbered space og their own color, at which they advance to the next inner ring. A pawn reaching a star-space, also advances to the next inner ring.

If a pawn reaches a space, which is already occupied by an opponent's pawn, the later is thrown out to the same free space on the next available outer ring.

If a pawn reaches a space with an opponent's pawn on the neighboring space on the next inner ring, both pawns exchange their positions. This can start a chain reaction.

—user summary
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Schwarz oder Rot
description:
The players have to get 1 pawn from the staring space ("Anfang") to the black finish space in the center of the game board.

Movement is determined by a spinner, which shows how much spaces of which color (black or red) the pawn may advance. If a pawn gets on a space with a yellow dot, it hast to move to the space indicated by the arrow.

If a pawn gets on a space that is already occupied by an opponent's pawn, the later is thrown out and has to start anew.

—user summary
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Die verhexte Brücke
description:
The pawns move from one end of the bridge to the other and back again. This continues till the game ends. Movement is determined by a die.

If a pawn gets on a colored space the player may buy this space and mark it with a property marker. If the player decides not to buy the space it is auctioned by the bank.

If a pawn gets on a space owned by another player, the player has to pay rent to the owner.

If a pawn reaches a space, marked with a diamond, it jumps forth or back to the next diamond of the same color, depending if he has yet reached the middle of the bridge or not.

If a pawn passes from the stairs to the bridge the player has to pay a bridge toll. Upon crossing the middle of the bridge (space with 3 diamonds) the player gets an income from the bank. If a pawn gets on the space with the 3 diamonds, the player gets double the income.

The game ends if one player goes bankrupt and the richest player wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Maulwurfs bunte Blumenwiese
description:
Contents:

4 Player figures – these are children, whose names you can imagine yourselves.
1 Playing board, which represents a meadow with lots of colourful flowers, divided in 38 spaces.
28 Animal tiles.
1 six sided dice with the numbers 1, 2 and 3 (each number twice).

Goal of the game and game idea:

The children are playing at the flower meadow of the Mole. Other animals grow curious of their cheerful laughter and, as they begin to approach the flower meadow, are invited one after the other to join them. The meadow is small, though, and the children must consider which is the best way to distribute the space on it so that as many animals as possible can get a spot, or maybe even all 28!

Setup:


Distribute the player figures randomly on the playing board (2, 3 or 4 pieces, one per player).
Place the tile with the Mole on one of the corner spaces, and the rest of the tiles face up or face down beside the board.


Note: it is suggested to play with 20 animal tiles on the first, introductory game. The rest of the tiles are then put back in the box and are not used in that game.

Gameplay:


The youngest kid begins. After rolling the dice, they move they player piece as many spaces on the meadow grid as the number rolled. They are allowed to move on any direction on the grid, but only forwards. That is, they can't turn or change direction midway.
If the player figure lands on a new space (not occupied), an animal tile is freely chosen and placed on the space the player just left when moving (on the first roll, the space from which the player started, and so on).
Going around the table, each player then does the same on their turn, bringing more and more animal tiles onto the board.
While moving, both other player pieces and occupied spaces can be jumped over, but they still count as spaces moved towards matching the total rolled on the dice.
As the game goes on, the available space for placing tiles becomes more and more scarce, and one can't land beside another player's figure!
If a player can't place a tile on their turn, they can move another player's figure instead of their own. To do so, though, they must ask the figure's owner for permission first.
The children are allowed to discuss and give advice to each other regarding where to best place the animal tiles. Nevertheless, the decision is always on the hands of the currently active player.


Mainly through the rule that makes the players ask for permission to move another player's figure in case that they can't move their own, children are motivated to play fairly and respectfully, which ends up being of benefit to all players as a group.

End of the Game:

If the players manage to lay down all the animal tiles, they win. If they don't manage to do so, they lose.

For subsequent games, add or subtract one tile from the 20 tiles used in the introductory game, depending on whether you won or lost the last game respectively. For example, if the introductory game played using 20 tiles is lost, try with 19 tiles next time; if that game is won, try with 20 tiles again – if the introductory game is won, try with 21 tiles next time and work your way up to using all 28 animal tiles at once.

—description from the manual (translated)
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Tile Placement

name: Dishonor Among Thieves
description:
Five to seven players band together to steal gold and treasures from three buildings. They must work together to be successful, but as any thief knows, your own gain is your number one priority. Competitive Cooperation is needed to win!

Players will either all fail together, or will work together to make it to the end of the game where the player with the most victory points is the winner.

Players will have a set of actions available every turn that will help (or hurt) each other success in their missions.

As dishonorable a thief as you are, open negotiation is part of the game. For example, why don't I give you two gold pieces to play that bad card on Ryan (sorry Ryan) instead of me?

—description from the designer
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Cooperative Game, Negotiation, Simultaneous Action Selection, Trading

name: Bitka na Drini
description:
Bitka na Drini ("Battle of Drina") is a sublimation of a chess-like games, like Parchesi and Risk, which in educative form and true to historical facts, place the players in a commanding role of the Austro-Hungarian Balkan Army or rather the Royal Serbian Army (with help of the Montenigrin Sandžak Army Division) with each other.

In the heat of the battle, players have the opportunity to directly command the Austro-Hungarian Balkan Army - the Austro-Hungarian 5th (VII and XIII Corps), 6th (XV and XVI Corps), and parts of the 2nd Army (parts of the IX Corps), unique rebellions and the Danube River Flotlla aka the Serbian I, II and III Armies, the Užice Army Corps, the Army of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the Braničevo Detachment, the Belgrade Defense Command, the Serbian Army Artillery Reserve and the Montenegrin Sandžak Army - ALL AT THE LEVEL OF BATTALIONS/AIR FLEETS/BATTERIES - with a total of 494 Austro-Hungarian units and 458 Serbian-Montenigrin units!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Enclosure, Player Elimination

name: Proboj solunskog fronta
description:
Proboj solunskog fronta ("Breakthrough of Salonika Front") gives the players the ability to control the commanders of either the Entente or the Central Powers. If they play on the side of the Entente, they directly command the Italian XVI Corps, the French Army of the Orient, The Royal Serbian Army, the 1st Group of Divisions (Army of General Philippe d'Anselm), the British Salonika Army and the Greek Army; or if on the side of the Central Powers, they directly command the Austro-Hungarian XIX Corps, the 11th German Army (LXI and LXII German Corps)and the 1st Bulgarian Army (aka Army Group Scholtz), as well as the 2nd and 4th Bulgarian Army (under the direct command of Bulgarian High Command) - all at the level of regiments and squadrons - with 133 various units on each of the battling sides!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Majority / Influence, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination

name: Onderduik spel
description:
Translates roughly to "hiding game" or "off the grid game": during WW-2 in the Netherlands, people who ran the risk of being deported to Germany regularly went in hiding. Anne Frank obviously being the most well known example. Not just Jews, also men in the prime of their age, eligible for draft to work basically as slaves in the German factories. For instance lots of Dutch soldiers who fought the German invasion were either deported directly as POW right after the war or "arrested" in the years after.

After the liberation a number of Dutch games were produced, based on events during WW-2.

This game is based upon that theme: going into hiding to prevent being caught by the German occupiers.

—user summary

name: Wakin' the Dead
description:
A game for 2-6 players.

You've been just lying around for as long as you can remember. BORING. It's time to do something. It's time to have a party. All you've got to do now is find enough people in your situation to be able to have a good party. Why says just because you're dead, you can't have any fun?

Well, probably those guys with the pitchforks, so stay out of their way.

—description from the game box (envelope)

name: Het Grote Nieuws van 2001 Spel
description:
A journalism themed trivia game.

Each player gets a card. There are 6 different categories. The player start his/her turn with throwing the die and move the pawn in the direction the player wants. The player has to answer a quetion in the category he or she lands on. If the player answers the question correctly, he/she places a Right-chip on the christmas card. Otherwise he/she places a Wrong-chip on the christmas card.
When a player has collected 6 chips, the game ends. The player with the most Right-chips, wins the game.

name: Gib acht!: Das hochinteressante Farben-Kreiselspiel
description: The players have to move their pawn from the starting space of their color to their destination at the center of the game board. movement is determined by the spin of a color top. the pawn of the resulting color moves 1 space in forward. If a player spins his own color, he gets to spin again. To beginn and to reach the finish, the players have to spin their own color.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Greatest Snake: Kickstarter Exclusive Booster Pack
description: A Kickstarter Exclusive booster pack with 25 additional cards (originally 18), making a 5 player game possible. With 5 players, you can now become the Even Greaterest Snake!
categories: Animals, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Party Game

name: The Savings Game
description:
A simplistic roll & move game deriving from Landlord game variants like Monopoly. In this game the players receive 'income' cards which earn them money and 'expenditure' cards which cost them money, and can keep their money either in cash or savings account, that latter of which recieve interest (the game includes a calculator) based on the current interest rates.
The game is intended as an educational tool and was supported by the Britannia Building Society 'borne out of our desire for financila education to be made available for all school children'.

name: Root Guy Farm
description:
Shim and D'rothy's first board game for kids and people of all ages, Root Guy Farm is an old-fashioned roll-the-dice board game that encourages interaction and storytelling. Some of the spaces are just silly, while others prompt your kids to talk about their favorite food, items they would bring on a trip, or to tell a joke. The winner is prompted to make up a story about the mysterious "Root Guy Farm." This game will bring the family together with laughs, creativity, and imagination.
The game board is printed in full-color at actual size of the original colored pencil artwork, 24" by 18". The paper game board is fully laminated, so it can't be easily ruined by spills. The game is shipped with a 6-sided die and 5 colorful game pieces.

—description from the publisher
publishers: Shim and D'rothy Products Worldwide LLC

name: Dogeza in the Pacific
description: Dogeza in the Pacific is a strategic level wargame of the Pacific War. In a two-player case, the flavor of this game is a compact edition of Avalon Hill's Victory in the Pacific, but in a four-player case, each player (Japanese Army, Japanese Navy, U.S. Army and U.S. Navy) fights each other in order to save face of each organization. Sometimes army player cannot help using navy units. Sometimes navy player cannot help using army units. If so, they cannot help performing dogeza (prostration, kowtow) to borrow the unit even though it is losing face. Therefore, they fight each other for their organization's face rather than their motherland's future.

name: Masasuke
description: Masasuke is a card game of color-coordinate battle among female servants of the nobility in the Heian period, Japanese medieval times. The playing cards are divided into two decks: coordinate cards and color cards. At first, each player draws six color cards and one coordinate card, and then, in order to make nice color coordination of dresses, they continue drawing and discarding by following the instructions of the coordinate card.
